div.p: HERBERT'S DEVOTIONS: OR A Companion for a Christian.
CONTAINING, Meditations & Prayers, fitted for all Conditions, Persons, Times and Places.

Either for the
Church,
Closet,
Shop,
Chamber, or
Bed.
Being seasonable and Usefull for these sad unsetled Times.
LONDON, Printed for Simon Miller at the Star in St Pauls Church-yard. 1657.

div.head: To the Learned, Pious and Reverend Pastors, Elders and Deacons of all the French and Dutch Congregations in great Britain.
div.p:
TO you, whose Zeale is great and wise, for the perfection of Christs Church, I present my Meditations. To you, whose
Pietie is reall and constant, I Dedicate my Ejaculations. If you esteem them as they are, good (though perhaps weake) helps, for mans spirituall growth, you shall receive them courteously, reade them judiciously, and earnestly commend them to your Wives, Children, Friends and Servants; praising, praying the Lord, for his past and future mercies to me

closer.signed: Your sincere Friend and humble Servant, W. Herbert.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
OLd Grecians did wisely, to put their Children to those trades, which they did most fancie: for though all men be of one nature; yet they are not all drawne with the selfe same pleasure: but some doe delight in one thing, whose contrarie others affect. He is then wise, who can follow his particular inclination, chiefly when reason approves it, and religion is his object. I might perhaps have in my Youth, produc'd some fruits of wit, had not my Teachers hindred me, to attaine then to that knowledge, which (as they said) they did foresee, should withdraw me from them to a contrarie Religion call'd by them Heresie: for since I knew my selfe, I had alwayes a great desire, to adorne my mind with knowledge, and to commit my conceits to paper; that I
might find them there, when my memorie should lose them. Now of conceptions I hold those the best, which God inspires to make us good. Such I greatly esteeme, and God grant, I love them till death. Since then I am in this Countrie, in which 'tis lawfull to be good, and where goodnes is taught by examples and counsels; I think it verie convenient, to lose no occasion of aspiring unto goodnes and pietie, by the description of those thoughts, wherewith God doth daily blesse me. They may do me much good in reading them sometimes, and perhaps serve some friends, to whom I'le communicate them. Besides, my intention is to leave them to my Issue, for helps unto wisdome, vertue and godlines. I have in other books divers matters for instruction: but this chiefly containes precepts for devotion, and digested Meditations upon manie subjects, which (in my opinion) may give both light unto the mind, and heat unto the affections of my posteritie, I may now say of the
publick: for sith this Book is licens'd for the presse, I hope, thousands shall find in it (besides manie points of Beliefe) such prudent rules to order their affaires, such Christian helps to raise nature above her element in her daylie operations; that blessing the most gracious God, who hath inspir'd these conceptions into my heart; they shall gladly behold, and cordially receive this Devotion as theirs; theirs by my donation, and theirs againe by their imitation, till Gods Spirit working effectually with theirs, shall make them flie higher then my region, and so leave me behind in speculation and practice. And here I would commend my religious labors to the pious Reader, him to the Lord, and so end this Preface; but that I must in charitie warne him not to suffer anie, to cheat him of my gift: for I suppose, there are manie persons, who will (if they can) persuade him to sleight it, upon divers pretexts, according to their various affections.

One will tell him: My Devotions are
vaine, because there are manie far better penn'd then mine.
Another: that I have too manie Meditations and Ejaculations on one subject.
A third: that this Devotion being mine, he hath nothing to doe with it, as that which is not fit for him.
A fourth: that these and all other printed, yea premeditated prayers are altogether unlawfull.
A fift: that though they be good in themselves, yet they are stint prayers, and so ties on the Spirit.

And so these whisperers shall defraud my Reader of his right in my gift; unles he be truly Wise and Pious: which all men being not, chiefly in this Generation, in which folie and impietie reigne, I must give here some antidots against all these poisons. Let then the Reader heark to me, and mark thus my defence, or rather Truths Apologie.

First, I make Devotions, although there be manie, which may be said to excell mine, because those are not mine, and that
I will do more (though not better) then those persons, who have preceded me in time, learning and pietie. He's a provident Child, who improves his Fathers estate.

Secondly, I compose manie upon one subject, because subjects are not alwayes the same to me, or I varie in the subjects. All nights are not alike to me. I Awake not daily in the same case or temper. I Read not alwayes the same bookes, nor books on one subject. I Eat not daily the same meat, nor with the like appetit. My Conversation is various; so are my Talkes, Mirth and Sadnes, Love and Hatred. I might run thus through all other subjects, which yet suppose to be alwaies semblable, yet I will have diversitie of thoughts, and choice of affections: for, as my appetit cannot be set long on one sort of meat, but desires some varietie; so my mind should be cloy'd with one conception or prayer. Besides, my intention in this composition being to give precepts or directions for a prudent, vertuous and pious life; I conceive, this can not be
done so conveniently in one article, as in manie. If on the contrarie unto the second Objection, anie wise man shall think, he could find more and better conceits then these are; I wish, he will beleeve, I am both willing that he should, and well persuaded, that he may: for, I my selfe (although foolish and ignorant) could (with Gods help) have done better, for the amplification of matters, and invention of new Conceptions and Subjects, if I had not row'd against wind and tide; forcing myThis word (Pen) makes me remember a mistake in the short and small lines of the 104. page, where pen should be instead of tongue. Who knowes, that David call'd his tongue the pen of a readie writer, shall not esteem that a great fault. pen to write, not when my wit was quick (if ever it was so) and my mind most tranquill; but when I was well occupy'd in an unpleasant profession, or could steal some minuts from it. Besides, other subjects and conceptions being not fit for everie man in generall, but in particular, in regard of some publick or privat calling, are intended by me for other Devotions, which both time and leasure may (with
Gods assistance) produce, if these be gladly intertain'd: so that both sexes shal then severally find Directions, for a discreet and godlie life, in ev'rie Age, Relation, Vocation, Estate.

Thirdly, although this Devotion be mine, because compos'd by and for me: yet Ev'rie man may challenge it, because given to the publick. 'Tis true, I made it first, for mine owne privat use, because I would not be like the Oxe, plowing alwaies the ground for other men: yet I suppose, that what is fit for me, as I am a Christian, is convenient for anie man of the same holie profession. What is fit for me in particular, or for few of myWhat this condition is and was, may be knowne hereafter, in one of my Colloques. Condition, or of some vocation, as Physicians, Lawyers and Historians, in whose names I speak once in the title Writing, may be easily observ'd; and who is judicious, may find with great facilitie what's convenient for him. But printed Devotions being of late cry'd downe by zeal without knowledge, or by knowledg
without honestie & pietie, as unlawfull & abominable to right Christians, I say.

Fourthly, they were otherwise reputed in the Jewish and Christian Church,Concerning Pray'rs ex tempore and premeditated, See my Catechism, Quest. 1139. &c. whose ancient and constant practice should be sufficient to condemn the censurers of Liturgies. If yet they sleight this old and religious custome, and will not consider with feare, That God himselfe appointed a form of blessing to Aaron and his successors: That Moses, David and other holie men compos'd Psalmes to be sung in their Congregations: That John did teach his disciples to pray: and finally, That Christ the eternall wisdome of God directed his in that dutie, and left them a short and perfect prayer: I shall take it for no disgrace, if they approve not mine. Nay rather I might suspect them as foolish and erroneous, if commended by those persons, who with intolerable impudence disdain to pray God in the words of Christ, in whom onlie he is well pleas'd, and who
is or should be our onelie light, way, truth and life.

Fiftly, I give not my prayers for limits to anie, but rather for dilatation: for in them I may teach manie, yea thousands of them, who despise such helps, to have pious conceits upon divers subjects, in which yet they did never find anie religious thoughts; no, not so much as morall instructions. Who teaches me to gaine 10. li. on a bargain, shewes me (if I have anie wit) to profit upon more. Neither Gods spirit, nor mans ought to be ty'd: nay they cannot be so. The first is infinit, & like the wind blows where he lists: the second free and quick, yea so quick in his devotions, that for want of pious matters, he flies often upon worldlie affaires. Is it not therfore good, to give him work enough in religion, and please him with godlie varietie? Truly, I think, it is; and that as manie as are perfect, are thus minded. But because I know, that manie are otherwise minded, I pray God in Pauls words, to reveale even this to them.

div.head: HERBERTS QUADRIPARTIT DEVOTION. For the Day, Week, Month, Yeare. THE FIRST PART. FOR THE DAY.
His Waking in the Morning.
div.p:
1 I Have sweetly rested this night, free from terrors, sights, noises, dreames and paines, which afflict manie men; and from those nocturne sins, which pollute manie more, both in soule and bodie. I then lift up my eyes, and open my heart and mouth to thee, gracious God, giving thee cordiall and verball thanks, for thy favors to me. I acknowledge them such, meere favors to thy poore servant, and unworthie creature, who therefore vow
thee all love and service. Accept, confirme my vow.

2. How manie men have lost their lives this night, or led them in feare and sorrow; whilst I have slept soundly, and refresht my bodie? Then let my soule praise now her preserver: And thou, good God, receive of me what thou hast given me, •• thankfull heart for thy favors, a joyfull mind for my preservation, and a pious resolution, to love thee sincerely, and serve thee faithfully. This I willingly offer thee for morning sacrifice, without either reservation, or power of revocation.

3. This night hath been unpleasant to my thoughts, and unquiet to my bodie: yea, I have done both sleeping and waking what hath displeas'd that glorious God, by whose power I live. The troubles or feares of the mind, the distemper or paines of the bodie, the sins of both, and causes of those troubles, feare • , distempers and paines are the motive of my present humiliation and supplication. Acknowledging therefore my selfe a vile sinner, and a weak thing; I pray thee, holie and great God, to be gracious to me, in the remission of my sins, and in the donation of thy comforting spirit, by which my whole person be sanctifi'd for thy service, and strengthned for mine owne affaires.

4. Have I not slept enough? Why then doe I delay to rise? Will I now make my bed a
grave of corruption, and not a place of rest? The Lord forbid. I have been made for other ends, then to sleep out the time, which is due to action. O then, my God, help me to resist slo •• b, and rise now cheerfully, to follow my calling.

5. Yet a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands: but this little may procure great, a little sleep great povertie: for, who loves that, shall come to this. I'le then unfold my armes, stretch out my lims, open my eyes, rise, work; that I be satisfi'd with bread. Yet I may rise early, and sit up late in vaine; Ʋnles, O God, thou blesse my diligence, care and labor. I then beg thy blessing on them and me, which I wholy dedicate unto thy glorie.

6. Fie, fie on the sluggard. He should be sent with a good whipping to the Ant, to consider her wayes, and so be wise. Indeed since man lost the right use of his reason, he may well learne of those creatures, which doe not know, what reason is. Ants, Bees and such small things may teach him to order his familie and common-wealth, and so to humble his proud thoughts, considering, sin hath made him inferior to his underlings. I acknowledge this truth, O God, and since my great Sun is eclips'd, I will gladly borrow some light of these earthlie stars, and in them admire thy wisdome. Make me a docible scholar to their naturall instructions, and
from them raise me to a higher schoole, thy holie and most perfect word.

7. Now my flesh is refresh't, and begins to rebell. I feele lustfull motions, which (unles they be quail'd) shall defile the bodie, and make the soule guiltie. What shall I doe in this case? I will quickly get up, and give her some hard bone to gnaw, thus to keep her busie, for idlenes breeds wantonnes, and lust is fomented in doune. In the meane time coole, O Lord, this heat with thy grace, and as a naile doth expell another; so let the feare of an eternall fire quench the flames of sensualitie, and abate carnall lust.

8. What makes me thus wanton? Good diet and full sleep, plentie, ease, pleasures, strength and health. Should I (as thousands of poore men) want all these things; or some of them, as manie of the greatest sort, my flesh should not be so lustie, as I with griefe find her. Were I halfe starv'd, on a hard and cold floore, or in the open fields, cross'd in all my desires, weakned by long disease, burnt with feavers or plague, tormented with the stone, gout and the like: then I should groane and crie unto my God for help. Should I doe so? Then since I am not so, and know, that these blessings of plentie, ease, pleasures, strength, health proceed from God, I must sing praises
unto him, yea my flesh must rejoyce in him. If I doe otherwise, listening to the lust of the flesh, I prove my selfe an ingrat wretch, and so may draw curse for blessing, penurie for plentie, trouble for ease, griefe for pleasures, infirmitie for strength, and diseases instead of health. Then I will not doe so, not take delight in these thoughts or motions: for those things should torture my flesh, and vexe my spirit. Nay rather I will not doe so: for thus I should offend my God, who commands me inward and outward puritie. Thou, who command'st, give to obey. Thou, who delight'st in pure minds, and chast flesh; make mine such as thou lov'st. Thou Christ, who didst assume our flesh, yea whole nature, let me not henceforth defile that in me, which thou hast purifi'd in thee, and forgive me all my past pollutions.

div.head: In Opening his Eyes.
div.p: 1 I See before my eyes th' effects of Gods mercie, my selfe alive, and my goods safe. Then I lift up these eyes to thee, and with them my heart, gracious God, acknowledging thy love to me, and offring mine to thee.

2. My eyes are open, yet I see nothing, for want of light. The Sun hath not yet wholy forsaken th' other part of the earth. So it happens
inwardly to thousands, yea to millions of men. They have curious and acute wits, grave and judicious intellects, yet cannot see what belongs to their salvation, because they want that light, which fully shines on us, the word of truth and life. O God, let this Sun rise to them, yet never set to us. Send thy Gospel to them, yet let it still remaine with us, and chiefly with me thy servant.

3. Sith the eyes of the Lord are upon the righteous, for care; this must fix his upon the Lord, for hope and dependence. Though I be a sinner, yet my eyes are on thee, my God: I expect all good things from thee, and will be rul'd by thee.

4. All things are vanitie, yet I will, and doe pray, Lord, turne my eyes, from beholding vanitie. Must thou then make me blind? No, but I pray thee, not to permit me, to set my affections on vanitie; or to turne into vanitie, what thou hast made for excellent and necessarie uses.

5. Strengthen, O God, my carnall eyes, that I daily see thy wondrous creatures, with love and admiration; reade thy converting word, with delight and profit; look prudently to my affaires: and open my spirituall, that I may behold marvellous things out of thy Law.

6. The wise mans eyes are in his head, sees afarre off; and wisely considers all things: but the foole walketh in darknes, hath no foresight,
no judicious counsell. Make me, O God from foolish wise, and wise with honestie.

7. Truly the light is sweet, and a pleasant thing it is for the eyes, to behold the Sun: yet these eyes must not be too bold with it, not staring 'gainst the light, assoon as we awake; but by few turnes being open and shut, thus to preserve their strength. We must doe so with knowledge and wisdome; not presume to get all at once, but by degrees: in infancie feeding on milke, the first rudiments of knowledge: then on stronger and stronger meat, higher maximes of art, and mysteries of religion. Lord, let me seeke knowledge, according to my capacitie: give me capacitie, to conceive what I ought, chiefly, concerning thee and me; and make me wise unto sobrietie.

8. As the eyes are the windores of the soule, it concernes her to looke to them; least death enter by them, and so kill her. My God, preserve my eyes for the safetie of the bodie, and make my soule so watchfull over them; that neither gift blind them; nor beautie allure them lewdly; nor vaine honors make them loftie; nor brotherlie prosperitie envious; and if they have been such, as I confesse it with sorrow, pardon their transgression.

div.head: In Shifting his Shirt.
div.p: 1 THere is such corruption in man, so much uncleannes in his flesh, that unles he use much washing, rubbing, linnen; he shall be offensive to himselfe and others. I will therefore take care of the puritie of the flesh, not forgetting that of the soule. My God, let me not be like the cups of old Pharisees, cleane without, foule within: or like the aples of Sodom, faire and pleasant in the outside, but rotten inwardly. Purifie thou my soule, and make her sound and sweet, by the graces of thy right Spirit; and so let likewise my flesh be, both sound and sweet.

2. Nastie persons are not fit to live amongst men: for, man should be a pure creature both in bodie and soule, if he would, could follow the dictat of reason, concerning the bodie; and the rules of Gods word, for the puritie of the soule. Give me, O Lord, to follow both. Let reason direct me in naturall actions; thy word guide me, in spirituall operations.

3. This Shirt is foule: therefore I put it off, to put on another, which is both sweet and cleane. Could I doe so with the old man, how happie should I be! My hearts inclinations are naught, his corruptions most foule, old Adam is hid there. But thou, my God, who
didst cast him out of Eden, help me to put him off, with all his vicious workes; and to put on the new, thy Son Jesus, with his divine vertues.

4. I put off this foule Shirt, but for a little while. When it is wash't, I'le put it on again. Time is comming, in which I shall leave this corruptible flesh; but God, in the last day, shall restore it againe to me, immortall. Grant, sweet Jesu, it be also glorious; and therefore make me here stedfast in faith, aboundant alwayes in thy worke, and looking still for thy comming.

5. Now I am as naked, as I came from the wombe. O no: I have now more, then I brought thence. I had then but one sin, and now I have thousands. Yet, why should I say so? Have I not truly griev'd for them, and hath not God forgiv'n them me for Christ? Then I am free from them: and then againe, I must be thankfull and carefull. Make me both, my good Lord; thankfull for thy mercie, carefull to avoid sin, yea the lest occasion of it.

6. While I put on this Shirt, clothe me, O God, clothe me, I beseech thee, with the precious robe of Christs Innocence; that I be not naked before thy glorious majestie. Indue me with knowledge, righteousnes, holines.

7. This Shirt refreshes me, because 'tis cleane, sweet, warme. Gods grace is such unto the soule, and makes the soule such as it is.
O then, my God, let me now feele thy grace, to worke in me these blest effects. Let thy face shine on me, and be thou gracious unto me.

8. Have I not manie Shirts, and other changes of garments, while manie goe naked, or not clothed sufficiently for the weather, or according to their qualitie and merits? If it be so, I will spare of my aboundance, chiefly to them, who deserve well of Church or State. Let not, O God, the rich permit, that the poore goe naked, or those in rags and course garments, whose learning, vertue, pietie adorne thy Church, and grace our State.

div.head: His Rising.
div.p: 1. I Rise, to follow my calling, and my chiefe vocation is to serve God, sith I am his profest servant. O then, my God, grant, thy service be my principall care: and as thou art gracious, accept my workes, yea indeavours; and pardon my imperfections, yea grievous transgressions.
2. I Rise, but shall speedily fall, unles God support me: for, nothing can subsist without his providence. Withdraw then not thy gracious hand from me, O God my onlie supporter.

3. I am (by Gods help) on my legs; but in what posture is my soule? Creeping on earth, or flying to heaven? Lying in vice and sin, or
standing in vertue and grace? If in the first, raise her, my good Lord, and pardon her sins. If in the last, assist her in her flight; that she flie still higher, and never fall.

4. Now legs, look to your selves. Doe, like good servants, your dutie, to carie the bodie in modest postures, and to good companies. Grant, gracious God, I remember with shame and griefe my past and sinfull wayes, which I beseech thee to forget: and then I think o wisely upon the present and future, standing not in that of sinners, but humbly turning now my feet to thy testimonies.

div.head: His Dressing.
div.p:
1 SHame followes pride, and confusion is the usuall end of ambition. As long as man kept his distance from God, he was both glorious and content: but when he would goe too neere his Maker in knowledge, shame sat upon his face, and spred it selfe upon all his outside; while within sorrow fill'd his heart, and feare possest his mind. Then the flesh begun to beare sway; for, Adam sought to adorne her, little caring for the spirit: since then he hid himselfe from God, who could repaire what man had marr'd. Lord, let me not doe so. Let me first seeke the soules ornament, thy saving grace and those Christian vertues, thou dost command
me in thy word: then let me provide those garments, which may cover my shame, and shelter me from the weather.

2. The first garments our parents had, were aprons of fig-leaves, and coats of skins: this last (belike) being made by God, to shew, how pride had made those like beasts, who would be as gods. Though our attire be more costlie; yet it should still represent us our fall, from a blessed to a cursed estate. Let, O God, mine doe so. When I put on my clothes, let me think on my sins, which (when I was immortall) made me subject to corruption in the bodie, and unto damnation both in bodie and soule, unles in mercie thou sav'st me.

3. It is hard to leave old customes. As pride was mans first sin; so we can hardly put it off. Rather 'tis fed by us, both inwardly and outwardly; inwardly, with conceits of bloud, wit and vertue; and outwardly, with beautie, strength, riches, attire: and of these, the last is the worst: for, in that we glorie in weeds, we shew, we sorrow not for sin, the first cause of garments. O God! let nothing make thy servant proud; chiefly, let me not take for foundation of my ostentation, the marke of my parents disgrace.

4. Why are men so busie, in seeking curious apparell, to cover a dunghill? Indeed I cannot much blame them; for, in that they
imitate God himselfe, who in the frame of our bodies doth hide our inward parts, as unpleasant unto the sight; and least perhaps we should dislike our old mother the Earth, attires her with flowr's and green grasse. Our fault is, that with proud exces we vaile our nakednes. Lord, keep me from these sins, and grant, I desire no more clothes, then need and decencie require.

5. Man is made of soule and bodie, a noble spirit and a vile flesh. The bodie ought to serve the soule; for the sense should yeeld to reason. Yet it happens quite otherwise; for, vile flesh rules, and noble sp'rit obeyes. At least the bodie hath the best. I have slept long, and I am long to make my selfe readie, though I will make as much hast, as I can: then I must walk, play, eat and worke, for the pleasure and profit of the flesh, whiles the poore soule lies still unregarded. Yet it shall not be so. I will spend some time upon her, in reading bookes, to increase her knowledge; and praying God, to obtaine grace. Yea since the soule may be busie, while the bodie is in action; rest and lie still, whilst he is in motion, I will take care, that in the midst of my occupations, she think often on God, speak unto him, and heare what he sayes unto her. O Lord! blesse this resolution, and grant, this day I looke so well unto my selfe, that
the bodie be subject to the soule, the soule faithfull to thee, and both belov'd of thee.

6. Now I must wash my hands and face, and see, all things be decent about me. In the meane time, speake thus my soule, unto thy God. O Lord! cleanse my soule heart from 〈◊〉 impurities; and so replenish it with grace; that it enjoy and feele continually thy gratuit and preventing love: and so likewise blesse my bodie and externall actions; that all persons like me, nor with an eye of flesh, to stirre their lust; but of the sp'rit, to marke my courteous behaviour, vertuous and religious conversation; to give thee the glorie of them, and indeavour to follow me.

div.head: His Looking in a Glasse.
div.p:
1 WHere's the mirrour, in which I may see, how I looke; seeke in my face markes of health or sicknes; tokens of joy or griefe, and whether it be clean? I see all things are well, as farre as this glasse can shew me. But how are things within? How fares my heart? In what case is my soule? I must examine this; and if I will consult my God, he will tell me: and if I reade wisely his booke, I shall see there my spirituall estate. I'le trie that presently. I will reade it, then pray; yet pray a little, ere I reade. My God, shew me what I desire, and if the sight be not good, make it so: and if
good, perfect it. If my soule be diseas'd, heale her; and if well, maintaine her in health. Cleanse her from sin, adorne her with thy grace.

2. This glasse flatters, and so 'tis fit for me: for, I flatter likewise, great men, for preferment; the rich, for helpe; the strong, for feare; the faire, for love, or perhaps lust. But what basenes in the adulator, and what follie in the adulated? The first sells the truth and his owne credit, for a dish of pottage: and the second is cheated of the truth, by a flattering tongue, which charmes his eyes and heart so pow'rfully, that he beleeves the contrarie of what he sees, feeles, knowes. If then I doe flatter others, and love to be flattered, am I not a base foole? And if I doe flatter my selfe, imagining me faire, vertuous, gracious, when beautie, vertue, grace are more remote from me, then the globe of the Sun: what shall I say, I am? Worse then anie mad man, and more blind then a Mole. Then I may say so now; sith I have often flattred my selfe thus: for which being asham'd and full of griefe, I pray thee, Lord, to be gracious to me, in the free remission of this great transgression, and future prevention of this base, foolish and mad vice. O let me not flatter others, and let not others flatter me: or if they doe't, let me not regard their false words, but shew them my strong aversion of their base wayes, by a sincere acknowledgement
of my infirmities, and diligent flight from their companie.

3. This Glasse represents me faire or comlie, with that due proportion and right color, which manie thousands want. So it gives me a double lesson, of vertue and gratitude: for, sith I am faire in bodie, I must not be uglie in mind; and sith my beautie comes from God, I must render him thankes and love. I doe so now, most glorious Spirit, who art the first and chiefe beautie; I thanke and love thee heartily, for my amiable feature; beseeching thee to beautifie my soule, with all morall vertues, Christian graces, and to free my heart from those vanities, which are inherent to beautie.

4. What homelie face have I? How course, yellow or tawnie my skin is? If I am in my selfe, as this Glasse doth represent me, I am a good remedie against love. I should say against lust: for, who is wise, will not love me the lesse, because I want fading and deceitfull beautie: sith I am Gods noble creature, who (belike) made me thus, to shew his infinit pow'r and wisdome, in our diversitie. I will not then repine 'gainst him, but rather acknowledge his love, in making me not lesse perfect and lovelie: for, he might have made me a Toad, or a Hedge-hog. I will neither borrow the help of art, to counterfeit beautie: but will studie to
have that inwardly, which I want outwardly. I'le make provision of vertue. I'le beg of God humilitie, meeknes, prudence, temperance, justice, fortitude, faith, love. If I have these, am I not faire enough? O then, my God, give me these and all other graces, to cover my corporall imperfections. Give me an upright heart in this crooked bodie; pure affections, and sweet disposition, that my squint eyes and stinking breath be not so offensive. Be thus gracious to those, whom thou hast made like me; and let me and them be to the perfect in outward shape, motives of compassion, and not subjects of derision. Direct us all to the possible and lawfull meanes, to rectifie what is amisse in our bodies: or if there be no meanes, then give us patient hearts, to remaine cheerfully amongst th' outward vessels of worldlie dishonor; till that time comes, in which the world shall see by our glorious resurrection, that we were truly vessels of honor.

5. How fresh am I? What fine color doth my young bloud give my smooth skin? And so, how fresh are Roses in their buds; yet how soone doe they fade? Not so soone as my life may doe. I will not then trust in the strength of youth, thus to addict my selfe to voluptie: but rather imploy it to the service of its giver, beginning now to beare his yoak. My God, put it about my necke, and thy bit in my mouth; that I run not away from thee. Let me not looke upon long life
as a pretext to carnall libertie, but as faire opportunities, to manifest my gratitude to my bounteous Maker, by a long and faithfull service. Shall I now live lewdly, because I may live long? Nay rather, I must live better; because if I live long, it is by thy mercie, and mercie must not be abus'd: otherwise justice succeeds it. O let thy mercie continue, in preserving these holie thoughts, and fortifying me, against all tentations and occasions of sin.

6. Fie on this dead color! How dull and dim is now my sight? how black and rotten all my teeth? and how full of wrinkles my face? Well, well. All these tokens are good. The more wrinkles I have, the fewer dayes to live. My weak sight declares me, I am neerer my journies end, if I lose not the way, by looking too much on this flesh, and exces of love to this world. If I doe so, I am a wretched foole. Then, my God, let me not doe so. Give me grace, to bewaile the folies of my youth; wisdome, to take now better course; fortitude, to overcome all opposition; perseverance, to end it happily.

div.head: His Morning Pray'r.
div.p:
1 THough we be commanded, to pray alwayes, as alwayes having need of God, Seek the Prayer • for the Lords Day in the Weeks Devotion. and may in all modest postures adore him in spirit
and truth, who is both an infinit Spirit, and the eternall Truth: yet we may have speciall times and postures, to testifie our submission to that great God, and dependence on him. All mornings and evenings are the fit times for dailie sacrifice; and kneeling is a convenient posture to offer it in all humilitie. I now then bow my knees before thee, glorious God, confessing my basenes, and acknowledging thy greatnes. I am weake, and thou art mightie: I am sillie, thou wise: I sinfull and injust, thou holie and righteous: I poore, thou rich. How then dare I present my selfe, before thy majestie, in my rags, uncleannes, folie, weaknes? Nay rather, what should I doe else? Must not the poore beg of the rich, that so they be reliev'd? Must not sinfull, injust persons frequent the holie and righteous, to learne goodnes in their conversation? Must not fools resort to the schoole of the wise & prudent, to know wisdome and instruction, and perceive the words of understanding? Must not the weake leane on the strong, adhere to the mightie, to find support by them? Yes certainly. I must therefore approch thee now, by holie desires of my heart, from whom I have often withdrawne my selfe, by impure affections, wicked actions. Looke now, my God, upon this poore begger. Thou art rich in mercie: O then have compassion on me, and forgive all my sins, my most frequent and grievous sins of pride and ambition, malice and infirmitie, knowledge and ignorance, idolatrie &
infidelitie, presumption, despaire and mistrust, profanation and superstition, avarice and prodigalitie, unkindnes and ingratitude, love and hatred, feare and desires, joy and sadnes, gluttonie and drunkennes, wantonnes and all uncleannes, wearines and drowzines, coldnes and negligence in thy service, injustice and partialitie, severitie and crueltie to my brethren, and whatsoever else hath been in my thoughts, affections, words and actions unpleasant in thy sight, and injurious to my neighbour. Wash these and all other impurities in the fountaine of thy Christs bloud: and then with his originall and actuall holines cover my nakednes: that so I be righteous at least by imputation, and so he be my righteousnes and sanctification. I pray likewise, that he be my wisdome, that so my folies appeare not before thee and men; but that he give me such subtilitie, knowledge and discretion, that I attaine unto thy wise counsels concerning my salvation; and unto those meanes to work it with feare. And that in this and in all other things, I doe thy knowne will from my heart, strengthen me with thy pow'r, in the practice of all vertues and religious duties. Let me not live in ignorance, and let not my knowledge be vaine. And because thou hast alreadie done manie great things for me, in me, I blesse thy glorious name, for thy excessive love to me and all thy Church. Continue thy favors, multiplie thy mercies, because dangers increase. Let not the gates of hell, the power of Satan, the subtilitie of Papists, malice of Hereticks,
pride of Schismaticks, furie of blasphemers, policie of the worldlie wise, insolencie of the mightie, ambition of some Ministers, pusillanimitie of others, ignorance of manie prevaile against thy Church: but give thy elect such knowledge of thee, faith in thee, love to thee, zeale for thee, that no power separate them from thee; no waters extinguish their love, no affliction daunt their courage; no perill make them leave their way; no sword divide their hearts, either from thee, or from themselves. Now is the time to be gracious unto Sion, and to support the walls of thy Jerusalem. O then hide not thy face, neither withdraw thy helpe. Otherwise all our faces shall gather blacknes, our hearts faintnes, our hands weaknes. Then, gracious Lord, make now thy face shine upon thy servants, and save us for thy mercies sake. O preserve thy truth amongst us, and let our soules, bodies, friends, goods be alwayes in the gracious protection of thee, of whom I doe crave these and all other mercies, for the onelie merits, and in the words of my Saviour Jesus. Our Father, &c.

2. If I must be all day in the feare of the Lord, as Solomon advises me, I must early begin to consider, what feare he meanes: not that apprehension of Gods judgements upon sinners; of his plagues, thunder, hell: for, this feare is servile and proper to sinners, whom I must not envie, nor in whose way I must not stand. They feare but the justice of
God, his pow'r to deprive them of their delights, and to fill them with miserie. I will not then be in this cloudie feare, but in that, which is cleane and cleere. I will feare God and his goodnes, studie and beg that feare, in which there is strong confidence, which is call'd a fountaine of life, and the beginning of wisdome. My God, give me this feare. Let me so fully consider the greatnes of thy love, conceive th' exces of thy mercie, that the lest sin appeare more horrible to me, because opposit unto thee; then all the torments of this world and hell, because grievous unto my flesh and spirit. Ʋnite my heart to feare thy name, and so feare it, that I never willingly displease thee: and so feare it, that I wholy relie on thee, whom who feares, never wants. O let me tast and see, how good thou art! Let me seeke thee, in whom is fulnes of good things. Let me feare thee, that so I feare no man, knowing, that who puts his trust in thee, shall be safe. Let me feare thee, and depart from evill; feare and serve thee with all my heart, considering how great things thou hast done for me. For them I doe thanke thee, and them with this godly feare I beg for all men, chiefly for this Nation. Behold us with pittie. Turne not away from us, to doe us good; but put thy feare in all our hearts, that we returne to thee, never more to depart from thee. Cleanse us from all iniquitie, from violence and bloud, from injustice and oppression, from cruell hearts, deceitfull tongues,
envious eyes, theevish hands. Let truth, goodnes, love, peace, plentie flourish againe: and let againe the voice of joy be heard in all our houses, streets and fields; and above all, the voice of them, who shall say, Praise the Lord of hosts; for, the Lord God is good, and his mercie endureth for ever. Amen, Amen.

3. As all things are subordinate, our affections must be wisely ordred, and our duties rendred, first, unto the highest and most excellent pow'r; then from him to the next, and so by degrees to the last. To teach us this, holie Paul counsels us in generall, to give honor to whom honor is due. God commands us in particular, to honor our Parents. Solomon exhorts us, to feare God and the King. Thus then I learne, that after God, I must Honor my Father and Mother, and Feare the King. And as I learne the commandements; so I resolve to yeeld them obedience. I will then Honor my Parents, and I will Feare the King. But because I can doe neither, unles my God helpe me, I will thus beg his assistance. Almighty Spirit, to whom honor chiefly belongs, and to whom the first feare is due! assist me thy servant, to honor and feare thee above all things; then my Parents and Governors next thee. Let me behold, love and feare them, as those, whom thou hast set in authoritie over me. Let me serve and helpe them, as those, whose cares, paines, feares are great for me. Let me
speake of them, and to them, as my relations to them oblige me: as of and to persons, whose honor is my glorie, and their disgrace my infamie. Though then they were not such, as their places require: though not so religious, wise, loving and carefull, as such should be; but ungodlie, foolish, unkind and negligent: yet let me never despise them: for, I must not curse my Parents; neither is it fit to say to the King, Thou art wicked; and to Princes, You are ungodlie. O let me rather pittie them, beare their infirmities, and pray thee heartily for them: and be thou gracious unto them, in covering their sins of negligence, crueltie, folie, ungodlines, and all others, if yet they are guiltie of these, I have exprest: and giving them the contrarie vertues, yea all the qualities, which are necessarie to persons of their ranke. Where they have been wanting in their duties, forgive mercifully: and that they nere be so, assist them pow'rfully. Pardon likewise my offences to them, my harsh censures of them; cold affections to them; sleight words of them; irreverent behaviour towards them; want of helpe in their needs, of patience to their corrections, of submission to their prudent, honest counsels, of obedience to their just wills and lawfull commandements. Permit me not to continue in these, much lesse to goe beyond. If they command some injustice, require of me what thou forbid'st; grant me reverend denialls. And if they forbid what thou dost command, let me tell them with great respect: thou art the greatest
Lord, and so ought'st to be obey'd first. And if they'le compell me to injust obedience, give me a prudent and stout heart: prudent, to appease their anger by satisfactorie reasons; or avoid their furie by flight: and courageous, to endure their torments, with Christian fortitude. Give the same heart unto all Children and Subjects, and generally to all men, under authoritie. Let no more Hams be found in privat families; no Jeroboams in Kingdomes. Let likewise no drunken fathers give occasions of derision to their children; nor hard Rehoboams provoke Subjects to rebellion, by grievous servitude. Let Parents be sober, discreet, loving to their Children. Let Kings be kind to their people, please them, and speake good words to them, following the counsell of the prudent old men. That all this be, and till this be, by thy effectuall grace, pitie and relieve those, who are opprest, abus'd by them, who should ease, honor them. Regard the heavie yoakes about the necks of manie children, subjects and servants, and make them light. Consider the disgrace of Parents, Kings, Princes, great men, whose honor lies now in the dust, whose glorie is eclips'd, whose faces are covered with shame, and whose hearts are full of sorrow. And amongst Princes and Subjects, consider ours and us, the King and People of this Land: the King once potent and glorious; tho People rich, great and happie: but now made weake, poore, despis'd, unhappie, by the child of our lusts, and effect of our jealousies, a long and unnaturall warre.
I will not say, who began it, or which of us gave the first occasion: but I confesse, our sins did deserve it, our transgressions were the causes of it, our folies did strike the first blow. Our King hath sinn'd: for, he is a man; our Nobles have committed wickednes, and delighted in vanitie; the strong opprest the weake; the prudent err'd, the poore repin'd and robb'd, and all are gone astray. But is not thy mercie above our injustice, and thy wisdome greater then our folies? O then forgive, redresse: forgive our wickednes, redresse our disorders. Convert our hearts to thee, and one to the other. Let the King embrace his Subjects; let the Subjects exalt their King: all weep for griefe at their past injustice: all laugh for joy at their present or shortly future reconciliation. Hasten it, gracious Lord, hasten it for thy love to Christ, whose bloud is our propitiation, and whose life should be our imitation, chiefly in meeknes and humilitie, two vertues, which we greatly want, and therefore beg of thee, as necessarie to our peace, either with thee or men.

4. The weak must not leane on that thing, which may break or fall under him. I must not then leane upon Man, my Riches, Merits, or Wisdome. Not upon Man, because his help is vaine, and his heart deceitfull, the brother supplanting, the neighbour walking with slanders. Not upon my Riches: for, they are incertaine. Not upon my Merits, because
my righteousnes is but as filthie rags, whose touch should pollute me. Not upon my Wisdome: for, I must not glorie in it, and there is none against the Lord, nor without him. I must therefore denie my selfe, and mistrusting all men and wordlie things, acknowledge God in all my wayes; that he direct my pathes. This I will freely doe, yea now, my God, I declare before thee, I have no confidence in Man; no trust in my Riches; no hope in my best Workes; no assurance in my Wisdome; but wholy trust in thy mercie: which that I alwayes doe, shew me fully the vanitie of all other subjects of confidence: and because I have not alwayes done it, forgive me my folies, in leaning on weake reeds; and heale all the bruises and wounds, I have got by my frequent falls. O let me this day and alwayes acknowledge thee in all my wayes; depend upon thy providence; expect thy wisdome in all my counsels; crave thy blessing on my words and actions, for delight and succes; that they please thee, and succeed well. Direct my pathes, shew me the wayes of temporall contentment, and eternall felicitie, least I misse them; yea beare me in those wayes, least I run too farre in the first, because it is smooth and pleasant: and faint in the second, because rough, hard & long. My soule shal praise thee for thy help: my heart love thee for thy goodnes.

5. When I seriously consider, how few persons in this wide world, have the knowledge
of God: how manie live in ignorance, are misled by errors, possest by the spirit of blasphemie, and infected with heresies; I am toucht with a double sense, of gratitude and compassion. Of gratitude, unto my loving God, for the light, I enjoy, while millions grope in thick darknes: then of compassion towards them, who sit in the shadow of death, stumbling, wandring for want of light. And as who pitties well, is willing and readie to helpe; so I will doe the best, I can, to shew the realitie of my compassion, towards the blind sons of Adam. I will with tongue and pen indevour to give them the right knowledge of God, and by my Christian life invite them unto his service: and besides this, I will call upon God, to give efficacie to my words, writings and actions, illuminating their understandings, moving, mollifying their hearts. O God, be mercifull to me and them, blesse us, and cause thy face to shine on us: that thy way be knowne upon earth, thy saving health amangst all Nations. Disperse those mists of ignorance, doubts, error, infidelitie, which hinder millions of poore soules, to see thy light, discerne thy truth, follow thy wayes. Display thy heames so pow'rfully, that all men see, there is no God, but thou; no Saviour, but thy Son; no divine truth, but in thy word; no comfort, but in thy Gospel; no salvation, but in thy Church; no Church,
but ours, which acknowledges Christ her onlie Husband, Head, Life, Light. Send faithfull and sufficient Messengers, to declare them thy will; men, who will lose corporall lives, to win a soule to thee; men, who seeke not themselves, their honor or profit; but chiefly thy glorie; men mightie both in words and deeds, in learning and good life, speaking the truth, walking in truth. Within few dayes I pray'd thee to maintaine thy Church: but now I beseech thee, to enlarge her borders to the ends of the earth. Contract, yea destroy Satans black kingdome, and extend thy glorious dominion upon all Nations of the earth. Holie and heavenlie Father, let now thy name be sanctified by all men, let them acknowledge thy Kingdome, and let thy will be done in all the earth, as it is in heaven. Then shall the earth yeeld her increase, and God, even our owne God shall blesse us.

6. The pray'r of that man shall be abomination, who turnes his eare from hearing the Law. 'Tis then folie to speak to God, when we will not heare him: yea 'tis great incivilitie. Sith then I have Meditations and Ejaculations upon manie subjects, thus to be talking with my God, in all affaires and occasions, I must be diligent to search, whether my Devotions please him. And I may know it by this marke; if I delight to heare his voice: for, this is the marke of Christs sheep. They heare his voice, he knowes them, and they follow
him. They heare him, he knowes them: and as they heare, and he knowes them, they follow him. So that who heares, must follow Christ, otherwise, he's not of his sheep, and the Shepherd doth not know him, doth not acknowledge him: for, his knowledge makes men happie; and he declares not those happie, who heare the word of God, unles in hearing they keep it. Gods word must not then onely touch the eare, but must enter the heart; neither must it onely stay there, but be brought forth into action. If then I earnestly desire, that my frequent prayers be as sweet odors before God, his Law must be in my eares, more pleasant then the sound of gold; in my eyes, more precious then jewells; and unto my soule, sweeter then honey. I must love it, and I must practise it. It must be kept in my memorie, intertain'd in my heart, heard in my words, and seen in my actions. That it be so, assist me, gracious Lord, with thy effectuall grace, in my outward and inward vocation. Send me those men, or me to them, who shall preach me the word of truth, in demonstration of the spirit; and let thy spirit illuminat and move my heart, to understand and beleeve it. Let me reade it often, not by custome, and so in vaine; but as the word of truth, salvation, life; and so to instruct and save me. Let it informe my understanding, affect my heart, direct my intentions,
season my words, vivifie my actions. Let it have this operation in all Christians. Grant, it richly dwell in us all. As 'tis the word of faith, so let us beleeve it, and by it judge of all doctrines, and end controversies in religion. As 'tis the word of reconciliation, let's seeke in it the meanes, to be reconciled to thee, by saith in Christ, and repentance from all dead workes; and one to another, by a just and meeke spirit: just, in making satisfaction for injuries; meeke, in pardoning them. As 'tis the word of life, let it be a rule to our present life, and way to the future; giving us prescriptions, to order the present; shewing the way to the future, the holines and sufferings of Christ, my onelie way, truth, life; in whose almightie name, and by whose infinit merits I beg all these mercies of thee; and in the holie words, which he my Wisdome hath taught me, comprehend manie more. Our Father, &c.

div.head: His Reading the Bible.
div.p:
1 OUr Parents ambition, to increase their knowledge, is the cause of our ignorance. They would know more, then was lawfull; and therefore we know lesse, then is needfull. They burnt our candle, and left us in the darke. There we grope long, before we can see anie thing. We must studie, heare and reade much, to get some glimpse of that great light,
they lost: yea of our paines we reape but little fruit, unles God blesse our indevours. Blesse mine good Lord, that I lose not my time, in reading this good booke.

2. O thou the maker of my wit! let me never dislike this booke, because 'tis not full of choice words, such as tickle the eare; nor containes manie Logicke arguments, or Rhetoricall phrases, such as manie vaine men affect: but rather grant, that knowing, thy thoughts are not like ours, I submit my weake judgement to that divine wisdome, by which thou hast lay'd the foundation of the earth, establisht the heavens, and fram'd all things in that great perfection, which drawes our admiration, and surpasses our apprehension.

3. Jesu the word made flesh, vouchsafe to expound unto me in all these Scriptures, the things concerning thee and me. Be thou my Prophet and Doctor, in teaching me thy Law, and unfolding before my eyes the mysteries of thy Kingdome: and since eternall life consists in thy knowledge, Lord, shew thy selfe to me such as thou art, and I must conceive thee to be, a perfect God and man.

4. Thou holie Ghost, who hast spoken by the Prophets and Apostles, for the instruction of thy Church! breath now into my heart the breath of understanding; that I conceive aright the holy mysteries and religious secrets, which are contained in this booke. Let my soule, gracious God, long for the heavenlie
Manna, and Angelicall bread, which is now offred me in it; rather then lust after the fish and cucumbers of human wit.

5. The Sunne casts a delightfull light, and fire hath a comfortable heat; yet he, who with bold eyes gazes too much upon the Sunne, may lose his fight; and he likewise, who goes too neere the fire, is in great danger of burning. A wise distance must be observ'd. So this Scripture is both pleasant and comfortable: yet we must not reade it in the presumption of our strength, out of a curious mind to know more then we should; least our short wits be drown'd in the deep sea of divine mysteries. Lord, teach me my distance, and shew me the method. I must observe in the lecture of thy word, to my best advantage. Direct and stay my feet, in the shallow places of this Ocean; and in the unmeasurable depth of it, beare up my chin, least I doe sinke.

6. The Scripture is like Moses rod transformed into a Serpent: for, as he was afraid at the strange sight of it, till God taught him, to take it by the taile; so no doubt this great Book should make a man start back, unles he take it by the end: for, all its beginning is full of curses 'gainst sinners; but its end containes sweet comforts. The Law doth load, fright and curse us; but by the Gospel we are eas'd, assur'd and blest. Christ, by whose death we liv • ,
and whose curse hath been our blessing, vouchsafe to applie to my soule the merit of his bloud, deliver her from those violent feares, I may conceive of Gods anger by reason of my sins, and fill her with those unspeakable joyes, he hath purchast for them, whose hopes relie on him.

7. This Book is the touch-stone of all human learning: for, by it I doe see what's good, or ill in all others. O then, my soule, love it above others. And thou, my God, open my mind, that I understand it.

8. This is a Book, whose instructions are true, whose precepts are all good, and whose promises are happie; for, 'tis the word of God, who is the truth, goodnes and happines it selfe. O let me, gracious Lord, follow these instructions, keep these precepts, beleeve these promises; that I be here both true to thee, and good to me and men, and hereafter happie.

9. This is a glasse, in which I see my selfe in a threefold estate, of innocence, corruption and regeneration. Then, Lord, give me good eyes, that I now see, in which of the two last I am; then forme my heart according unto that knowledge, to Beg mercie, if I find my selfe in the first, and thanke thee for mercie, if I am in the last.

10. This is againe a glasse, in which I see both my selfe and all things in three different times, past, present and future. The first concernes
me not, the second is but a moment, the last is perpetuall. Yet time past gives me instructions, to order the presen •• this worked for the future, and this futur • d shall be happie or unhappie, as the present makes it. O Lord, give me wisdome by the remembrance of the first, grace to make use of the second, and let me find the third blessed. Let me bewaile what I did yesterday, live holily to day, and trust not upon the morrow. Let not hope of long life make me doe ill for the present, to repent afterwards; but grant, good God, I heare thy voice this day; that hereafter I may enter into thy rest.

11. This is a light, which discovers most hidden things. With this torch I see mine owne heart stuft with malice, and compassed with miserie; but withall I spie • one, by whose grace malice's rooted out, and miserie exil'd. Lord, let never this Suns eclipse leave my soule in darknes; but grant, that both he shine alwayes on me, and I doe walke, while I have light.

12. Here are threatnings for obstinat sinners; pardon for mourning soules, and rewards for good men. Here the poore wretch finds comfort against want, and the rich man distrust of his riches. Here are cordialls for faint persons, and cooling brothe • for selfepresuming • en. Here's a wedding for wise Virgins, and a fire for hot Whoremongers.
Here humble ignorance becomes wisdome, and proud wisdome is accounted folie. What other book can hold so much as this? O then, my God, let my heart love it above gold, and preferre it before worldlie wisdome. Grave in my mind what it containes, and let the lims of my bodie, and the faculties of my soule be day and night exercis'd in thy Law.

13. Here Christ appeares as a way, truth and life; way, to leade us to salvation; truth, to keep our minds from error; and life, to free our soules from everlasting death. Father, let me ever walke in that way, beleeve that truth, and seeke that life.

14. What fearfull speech is this? Am I guiltie of those accursed sins, which kindle Gods wrath against men? If I am so, convert me, Lord, that my soule may escape what is threatned to such, as offend without repentance.

15. How comfortable is this sentence! Can I applie it to my selfe, as being one of them, to whom such things are meant? Then, Lord, I blesse thy name: for, it is by thy grace, and not for my merits, that I feele thy present comfort, and shall shortly enjoy thy glorie.

16. My soule is toucht with heavines at the reading of this: griefe melts my heart, so that I seem to be another man, then I was even now. Surely this change proceeds from God;
to shew his love he gives me these godlie motions; thus to withdraw my soule from sin. O Lord! let them last long, and bend me pow'rfully unto a better life.

17. This is a good counsell. Would my soule follow it, how happie should she be? In earth she should have peace, and in heaven glorie. O God, who command'st me to doe, grant me both will and strength to doe.

18. Here vice and vertue are set forth in their severall hues; vice clothed with darknes, vertue adorn'd with light: vice most uglie, vertue most faire: vice sitting downe upon the brim of the infernall pit, vertue standing at the gate of heaven. Let me, O Lord, loath-vice and love vertue; and when thy word shewes me either of them, let my passions follow my eyes, so that the very name of vice draw my hatred and • version; but my love and desire wait alwayes or vertue.

19. Here error is discredited, and hereticks condemn'd. Should all Christians rule their faith and actions by the principles of this book, they would find but one way to heaven, and none at all to hell. Their swords and armes should gather rust, and their divided hearts should be link't againe together. Let it shortly be so, O thou the worker of union! Make a quick end of our irreligious disagreements about thy religion, and let thy sp'rit so resolve
〈…〉
that truth being once knowne, we adhere all to it.

20. These words are darke; therefore I thinke, that either their knowledge is not necessarie unto my salvation, or that God is angrie with me, because he holds my eyes, that I may not know him, although himselfe speake unto me. If this be the true cause, why I understand not this place, I beseech thee, my God, to let me see my faults; that in bewailing them, thine anger be appeas'd, and so my mind cleared, that I conceive the sense of this.

div.head: His Reading human Bookes.
div.p:
1 HUman writings may be well compar'd to the Moone: for, as she borrowes her light from the Sun; so these have their splendor from the holie Scripture, which is the center of knowledge, and that great light, which God hath made, to rule over the day in the spirituall world, If there be anie bookes (as I know too manie) which seeme to have another and contrarie light, it is but a false fire, which mis-leads men. Let me, O Lord, never follow such flashes; but grant, I worke in the Suns light, and (in his absence) in the Moones. Let me reade the Scripture, and regard all other writings, which ground their doctrine on thy word, or are not 〈…〉
• rd.

2. 'Tis delightfull to reade, both to increase knowledge, & passe away the time, we may well spare from our affaires: yet we must looke what bookes we reade; not those, which shew us ill, and want remedies against it; give us an ounce of strong poison, but not a dram of antidote; commend us the sweetnes of the fruits of the flesh, but hide their soure relish. Lord, give me grace to scorne such bookes, esteem • them as the Devils snares, and flie from them, as from a greedie Lyons clawes.

3. Hard meat agrees not with all mens stomachs, and high knowledge cannot enter into all minds. He's therefore wise, who knowes the strength of both, and feeds them with what they can beare. Lord, let my wit be quicke, to understand hie things, and withall judicious, to marke mine owne abilitie. Let me not seeke to know more then I ought; but make me wise unto sobrietie.

4. As he doth not grow fat, who loads his stomach with more meat, then he can well digest; so he doth not become learned, who reades more, then he can conceive and commit to his memorie. Grant me therefore, O Lord, a good understanding and faithfull memorie, to apprehend and remember what I doe reade.

5. The greatest part of men takes great delight in diversitie of bookes, as gluttons like severall dishes: but who is wise, will fasten
upon a good booke, and the sober upon a wholsome dish: for, as varietie of meat is forbid by good Physicians; so multitude of books is dislikt by wise men. Lord, grant, I love to reade good bookes, and let not my curiositie of manie hinder me to profit with few.

6. As those flow'rs are the best, which, besides their color and sweetnes, have some vertue, to preserve or recover health; so I esteeme those writings 'bove others, which with a pleasant stile, rich conceits, subtile arguments, and sound knowledge of things naturall and divine, have strong reasons to divert us from vice, and sweet allurements to draw us to vertue. Lord, let me find such bookes, and give me grace, I learne from them eloquence, philosophie and divinitie: and grant likewise, they work in me these two blessed effects of hating vice and affecting vertue.

7. I thinke, this booke is good; yet its author being a man, it may have some error. Therefore, my God, I beseech thee, to give me the spirit of discretion, that I may discerne good from ill; then strengthen me to follow that, and eschew this.

8. This is a godlie booke, whose drift is to teach truth against error and heresie. Let, gracious God, its reasons be receiv'd both by me and all men; and suffer not that the contrarie arguments gaine anie beliefe in the world.

9. This book is full of hereticall positions,
and pernicious doctrines. I will then either forbeare it, or reade it with such warines, that I may take no harme by it. Strengthen my faith, O Lord, against the grosse errors, which are spred through this worke, to poison mens hearts by their eyes.

10. By historie we learne what's done out of our sight; yea before we had anie sight, both in forraine countries, and in our native soile. Curious wits find in it delight, and wise men gather out of it instructions, to order their life. Let me, O Lord, find both these in this booke, and make in my studies a happie match of good, delightfull and usefull.

11. How punctuall is this Chronicler to observe other mens actions! He commends this, and censures that, as his affections carrie him, or he thinkes, the fact doth deserve. Was he ever so diligent, to marke his owne good or bad deeds? Whether he was or no, is a thing, which concernes me not: but this I must observe, that selfe-knowledge is of all the most profitable. Lord, grant, I weigh other mens deeds and words in the right scale of sound judgement, imitating the good, and eschewing the contrarie: but first of all, let me take a full view of my selfe, and strive to mend what is amisse, and perfect what's alreadie good.

12. This Law-booke may teach some to
wrangle, and make others warie, to fall at strife with their neighbours. What's meat for one, is poison for others. With the same knife one cuts his bread, the other his fingers. Through wisdome we use things for service, and by folie we turne the same to our owne ruine. O God! make me so wise, that I make the best of all things, and in the lecture of this book learn to keep well mine owne estate, and not encroach on another mans right.

13. This is a Physician not like those of our age; for, they hide their cunning, lest their profits decrease: whereas this publishes his skill, that all the world gaine by it. Those, like wicked and slothfull servants, hide their lords money in the earth; and this, as a good and faithfull steward, puts his talents to use, to increase his masters profit. Let me, Lord, imitate this man, in not concealing that knowledge, which may doe good unto anie, and also give me wit to understand this booke aright, and make good use of its precepts, for the preservation or recoverie of my health.

14. Here's a booke of Divinitie, which teaches man the knowledge of his God, a most noble science in respect of its object, utilitie, necessitie and certitude; for, it is grounded on Gods word, which is an infallible truth: if not, 'tis no divinitie, but meere dotage. Open
my mind, good Lord, that I may know whether this man was guided by thy sp'rit, in the penning of this volume, that so I beleeve him: or whether tares be sowne among this wheat, either by thine enemie, or human ignorance; that I take them not for good corne.

15. All sciences are vaine without divinitie. The seven arts are but like windie meats, which blow up man, instead of feeding him. Histories are but tales, which for a while delight the eare. Physick concernes but the bodie, and lawes are made for the bodie and goods, which both in spight of all remedies and wranglings shall vanish and corrupt. This science belongs to the soule, which being immortall, must after this short life be led unto a place, where she shall feele perpetuall joy or griefe. Divinitie shewes us to avoid this, and obtaine that. O then, my God, grant, I love it, and ever take delight in the studie of it. And because it handles hie things farre above the reach of mans wit, vouchsafe to strengthen mine, that I may both conceive and practise what is here set downe.

div.head: His Writing.
div.p:
1 BY Reading we doe light our torch, and by Writing we blow our neighbours fire-Happie is he, whose knowledge makes first his
soule good, then betters that of his brother. Let me, O God, be thus happie, in making my theorie divine, and my practice Christian; and then blessing my pen, that it may give both light and heat unto all those, who shall reade, or heare what I write.

2. We must beware to write what's not good to be read. Cursed is he, who poisons publick springs. Keep me, Lord, from being thus curs'd; and let me rather die, then write what doth bewray a wicked mind, and may make others naught, in infecting their hearts with wantonnes, lust, riot, pride, ungodlines, and the like vices.

3. Mens spirits are as divers as their faces: none can be found so like, but that there is some difference, which is chiefly discern'd in their words and writings; and in that we may well admire the infinit wisdome of God. As I praise thee in thy Saints gifts, so let them, Lord, praise thee in mine, and let both they and I seeke in our workes and bookes the glorie of thy name.

4. As it grieves not, but rather delights us, to see a man very like another; so we should not dislike our workes, for their likenes unto others, unles they be altogether the same, and stolne rather then made. If my Writing be like anie other, which yet I never read nor heard, I like them not the worse: if they be singular both in matter and invention, then I doe like them best. And will, O God, thanke thee,
for blessing me with a quicke wit, and a solid judgement.

5. This invention is borrowed, these conceits are not mine, these phrases are common, and this expression most vulgar. Why then should I write this, which is printed in manie bookes, and others would challenge from me, if ever it should come to light? Let me not, Lord, trifle my time, in doing that, which is alreadie better done: but either grant me wit, to compose new things of mine owne; or wisdome, to keepe my renowne, in not exposing it unto the publick view, out of a fond desire, to see my name in print.

6. Mens minds differ as well as their appetites; and therefore there must be diversitie of bookes. There is no meat so hard or leane, but some man will like it; nor book so plaine and poorly penn'd, but it shall find readers, who, for the rudenes of their wit, will think it elegant. If I cannot please learned men, let me, O Lord, instruct the ignorant, and doe some good unto the simple people.

7. There are few men which desire not issue, in which they may live after death; and manie will make bookes, that so their names may be divulg'd, and their memorie, may flourish, after wormes have eat their bodies. I can but praise this intention, if so be, that they likewise aime at the glorie of their Maker, and
at the good of their brethren. Let, Lord, my intentions be such. If I desire, that my name be famous in all succeeding ages, let me grave it upon such workes, as increase thy glorie, in drawing my readers to thy love and service.

8. As writings are the children of the mind, a wise man saith, we love them more, then the issue of the bodie; yet I cannot doe so with mine: for, I would give or burne my bookes, to benefit myWhen I ra •• thi • I had •• t my D ••••
ter, to whom my Catechisme is dedicated▪ and for whom this was •• te • ded. child. Lord, keep both these safe manie yeares; my bookes for my childs use, my child for thy service.

9. That man does well, who provides for his child moderate meanes to live; he does better, who gives it good breeding, and leaves it holie instructions; and he does best of all, who takes care of both these, provision and education. Blesse, O good God, my meanes, that they may passe unto, and suffice my issue; and blesse likewise my tongue and pen, that they utter and write such things, as serve to my posteritie, for helpes to godlines, wisdome and all vertues.

10. As 'tis not so grievous to the wise and godlie, to have no children, then to have them wicked; so they had rather make no bookes, then make them ill: for, both disgrace our names, and make them infamous to them, who see our lewd children, or reade our corrupt
workes. Lord, give me not the first, unles they be well addicted, neither let me make the second, unles they be devoutly penn'd.

11. We may as well writ for our selves, as for others: for, in writing we find often conceits, we never thought upon, and which should soone vanish, unles we keep them in writing. Let me, O God, be the first man, who shall receive good of my workes, and profit of my instructions, indevouring with all my strength to practise those counsels, I shall set downe in them.

12. That man may break his back, who will carrie more then he can; and he may likewise crack his braines, or venture his credit, who will write that, which is beyond his reach. Let me not, O Lord, undertake what is too hard for me; nor presume to handle those matters, whose height is above my knowledge.

13. Pens are as tongues, yet have more priviledge: for, the last can but informe them, who are present with the speaker: but the first can help the absent, to know what we will impart them; and may convey unto the last age of the world what was done in the first. I have a friend absent, with whom I will speake with my pen. Teach me, O God of love, to write what may delight his mind, and to forbeare what may give him offence.

14. This mans vein and pen offend me,
and (I thinke) I could well answer him, and shew him, my vein is as hot, my pen as sharp, my inke as black as his: but so I should likewise shew a black mind, incense him more, and offend his master and mine, that God which commands love, and desires union amongst us. Therefore I will either forbeare to write; or my letters shall be so mildly penn'd, that he shall see, and (I hope) grieve, he hath injur'd a man, who hath no gall nor sting. Let me, O Lord, have alwayes such mild mind, and give the like (I beseech thee) to the maker of these offensive lines.

15. Our law is so obscure, that some lose their time, paines and meanes, in suing and pleading for that, which manie men challenge, not knowing, to whom it belongs. I thinke therefore both to please God, and doe service to my countrie, in making a good booke, to instruct the commons in the lawes of this Land. Help me, O God, to make it such; as may cut off manie wranglings, about titles of goods and lands.

16. I know some secrets in physick, which being once divulg'd and knowne should benefit manie, who want money enough to pay the Physicians large sees. I will, O Lord, with thy help publish them. Regard my affection unto the common good, and blesse both me and thy servants, with health and holines.

17. Historie is a witnes, a messenger and an image. The witnes must be true, the messenger faithfull, the image lively drawne, representing both in color and proportion the thing, for which 'tis made. Since then I doe purpose to write an historie, Help me, O God, to make it such, as may teach all posteritie, not onely how things were carried in this age, what were our chiefe actors, the causes and effects, the places, times and meanes of the matters I shall set downe; but also how our children may frame their owne actions upon ours, following those good rules, by which we did flourish, and avoiding those disorders, which were a blurre unto our age, and a hinderance to our State. Grant, I praise and blame men according to desert: condemning vice, and commending vertue, in whomsoever I find them.

18. Whosoever handles Divinitie, must have a divine sp'rit; and to make devotions, requires a godlie mind. Since then, O Lord, my matters are divine, and my subjects godlie, let thy spirit purifie mine, and blesse me with conceits, which may well suit the thing, I have in hand. And where I shall touch that, which is oppos'd by anie Sect, let me, good God, doe it with such forcible arguments against all false doctrines, and such meek terms against all opponents: that the first be discredited, and truth greatly esteem'd; and the last converted to thee, and
we strength'ned by their union; so that we be all but one flocke, under Christ our blessed Shepherd.

div.head: His Going out.
div.p: 1 LOrd, blesse my Going out, and so be thou with me, that I offend no man, and nothing offend me. Let not my outward senses fasten upon vicious objects; but give my soule wisdome, to shun ill, and chuse good.

2. Let not, O Lord, my secret sins procure me open shame, but both forgive them me, and divert the paines, they deserve, and let all the things, I leave here, be in thy gracious protection. Keep these soules in thy truth, bodies in health, goods in safetie.
3. Let thy Angels, O gracious God, goe forth with me, and thy holie sp'rit within me; those to keep me in all my wayes, and this to teach me the right way.

4. I am loath to goe out, because all things here are pleasant. O how manie good soules would be glad to say so, if truth could permit them! But they find Christs speech true; Mans domesticks are his enemies. Pitie their case, my God, and give them ease of their molestations. Let thy peace be in their dwellings, and continue in mine: and let plentie or sufficiencie accompanie thy peace, least penurie hinder our pietie.

5. How willing am I to goe out, thus to avoid the troubles of this familie, and seek abroad what is deni'd at home, a blest tranquillitie? My God, rebuke these winds, these strong passions, unquiet minds, and angrie hearts; that at my returne I find ease, and see this whole house in a calme.

6. Nets are spred abroad to catch me, and snares are hid for me; but, breake them all, O Lord; that my soule may escape. Then as a bird escaped out of the fowlers snare, I will joyfully sing, and give thee thankes for my preservation, from spirituall and corporall dangers.

7. Since man did sin, God hath turn'd against him what he had made for him; so that we doe now feare what before stood in awe of us. Living creatures ow'd us service, but now they doe rebell, and warre 'gainst us. The Elements likewise have perverted the end of their creation: for, being made for mans service, they seem to plot his destruction. What therefore can we doe, to live secure 'mongst so manie dangers? Repent for sin, and trust in God. O then, good Lord, let my heart conceive true sorrow for my past transgressions, and assurance of protection from thee. Let no creature annoy me now abroad, but keep me safe under thy wings, and let my thoughts and love be ever fixt on thee. Grant I feare thee, that I feare nothing else.

8. All things are to wise men motives, to draw their love unto the Maker of the world: yet fooles turne them to their owne ruine, sucking gall from that flow'r, of which Bees make honie. The godlie and wise man can seldome see, heare, smell, tast, or feele any thing, which doe not better his knowledge, and purifie his affections: whereas other mens senses doe but gather what blows up the understanding, and doth pervert the will. Let me not, O God, be like these; but give me wit, to make the best use of all things, and take in this my going forth good instructions of thy creatures.

9. He is not wise, who goes with his mortall enemie, unles he stands well on his guard: and he's sillie, who carries such burdens, as may make him faint under them, and perhaps break his back. Then what am I, if I carrie with me the sinnes, I have committed here? A man undone: for, they may lie so heavie upon me, that I shall miscarrie, and never returne home. They may draw Gods wrath upon me, and what am I, to withstand it? O then who will help me, to throw downe my burden? Manie may be willing, but none able to ease me perfectly, except the Lambe of God, who taketh away the sins of the world. Then, sweet Jesu, take off this heavie yoake, these thousands of sins from my necke; these evill thoughts, lewd affections,
injust actions, and idle, yea worse words, of which I am guiltie before thy majestie. Then I may now goe out, with assurance of thy blessing: for, blessed is the man, whose iniquities are forgiv'n.

div.head: His Coming in.
div.p: 1 AS I went out, so I come in: no ill hath befalne my bodie, no wilfull sin defil'd my soule. Therefore I thanke thee, gracious God; and withall intreat thee, to pardon now all my offences, and keep me still from sin and harme.

2. Wretched man that I am! what have I done abroad? What grievous sins have I committed in short time? They lie heavie upon my heart. But thou, meeke Lambe of God, take them away I beseech thee, and from henceforth preserve me from the like.

3. Have I done anie good abroad? Have my eyes pitied, and my hands, tongue and purse helped my poore brother? Have I meekly and charitably, without hypocrisie shew'd my neighbour his faults, in taking the Lords Name in vaine, lying, cheating, fighting, and doing anie thing amisse? Or have I reprov'd his error, increased his knowledge, and confirmed his faith? Then let my God receive the praise of all my well-doings, and forgive me the slips, which are mixt with my best actions.

4. Manie goe home with heavie hearts, because the cries of their children, severitie of their parents, fretting of their husbands, or scolding of their wives, make them hate their owne houses. I praise God, that I am not so; and pray him, I never be so. Let not, Lord, those procure me griefe, who should be my help and comfort: and let me not likewise grieve them, whom I ought to honor, love and cherish.
