5. Manie goe home with merrie hearts, to be cherisht by their parents, truly welcome to their children, delighted by their wives, embrac'd by their husbands. But alas! my case is not such. Therefore that it be shortly such, I powre my prayers before thee, O God of all consolation. Regard my present griefe, and to remove it, precede me. Goe, goe before, and rectifie my familie.

6. Death is the reward of mans sin, and as it happens everie where, and manie wayes; we are safe in no place. There are perils both in earth and waters, in the citie and wildernes, abroad and at home. Abroad men and beasts might hurt me; here thunders may find me. This floore may sinke under my feet, and that seeling fall on my head. Therefore I call on thee, O thou the Maker of all things, beseeching thee, either to keep me safe in this my solitude; or give patience, to beare the harme, I shall receive.

7. Now that I am at home, I must looke to
doe some good thing. Idlenes is a vice, which breeds either melancholie, or malice; for, mans sp'rit being active, will gnaw himselfe, or worke upon some ill subject, unles it be set on good things. Blesse me, Lord, from that vice; keep my thoughts upon thee, and prosper the workes of my hands, and the conceptions of my braines.

8. Is this house mine? Or if not mine, can I lawfully, safely and quietly dwell in it? Then I enjoy what manie want: for, millions wander in the world, having no certain place of rest; no house, to receive them; no hole, to shelter their wearied bodies, from th' injuries of the weather, or violence of their enemies, or furie of wild beasts. I pitie now their case, and finding mine much different, I will (before I doe anie thing else) meditate here a while, how and why I am thus at ease, when my equall, yea betters are not so. I cannot say, my industrie does this; nor, my wisdome hath laid the foundation of my tranquillitie: neither dare I alledge merit for anie cause of it, but humbly acknowledge, God is gracious to me, in giving me what he denies others: or that I am not fit to beare what he layes upon them. My Lord, I thanke thee for mercie: my Rocke, I intreat thee for strength. When thy hand is soft to stroke me, make my heart melt in love and gratitude to thee: when it is hard to strike, make me
strong to beare it, patient in paines, joyfull in affliction: and give these graces to all men.

div.head: His Working.
div.p: 1 ALl things in the world are in continuall motion, action or passion: therefore man must not thinke, to exempt himselfe from the common course of nature. He must be still doing something, either in the faculties of the mind, or with the lims of the bodie. Grant, gracious God, I thinke on this, and so studie to imploy my selfe about honest affaires.

2. That man resists his creation, who refuses to worke; for, he is borne unto labor: yea, before man had sinn'd, he was commanded to dresse and keep Eden: Why then should I loath to take paine, since sweating hath been added unto all mankind, for the offence of the first man? O God! make me willing to share in Adams sweat, since I am partaker of his sin; and applie to my soule the merit of Christs bloudie sweat; that in confidence of thy love, and certaine hope of an eternall rest, I labor cheerfully.

3. Ants gather in Summer their Winter-provision: and wise men worke in youth, that they may rest in their old dayes. Let me, O Lord, imitate them, taking paines whilst strength
serves, that I may, when 'tis spent, enjoy in peace the fruit of my labors.

4. As we love the laborious Bee, and hate the idle Drone; so God is well pleas'd with those men, who, by a lawfull profession, get honestly some meanes to live; and is angrie with them, whose hand is weake to worke, but strong to steale; or who, with a base mind and fawning tongue, seeke at other mens tables what theirs cannot afford. O God! let me not be so slacke, that I refuse to worke; nor so vile, that I seeke my living by abject meanes and vicious courses.

5. Running waters are more wholesome, then standing pooles; and stirring bodies more healthie, then the slow. As for the soule, she does evill, who doth nothing. Then, Lord, let me be still doing something, as well to keep the flesh in health, as the sp'rit in vertue.

6. If this my trade or profession seem hard, let me but thinke, how manie there are in the world of farre greater labor; then I will esteem it easie. Besides, let my soule lay her hope of help in God, who hath made heav'n and earth. So, my Lord, grant I doe; and so he thou with me, that I doe worke in this calling, both skilfully and cheerfully.

div.head: His Walking.
div.p: 1 BY labor man gets strength both of bodie and soule; yet it must be moderate, else it doth much weaken the flesh, and dull the mind. Rest is needfull to both; for, after a little breathing we run with more swiftnes. Now then I leave my worke, to rest or walke a while. O Lord, blesse so my rest and recreation, that it be no offence to thee, nor hind'rance unto my labor.

2. 'Tis both easie and most wholesome to walke; for, of all exercices 'tis the lest violent. Besides, the senses find abroad what delight them, and through them may convey knowledge into the mind. Let now, O God, my bodie get strength by walking, and my soule receive instructions by beholding the beautie of thy creatures, hearing their melodie, smelling their sweetnes, and observing their severall proprieties.

3. I walke in health and mirth, whilst manie men lie languishing, depriv'd of all comfort. Some are walking in heavines, others possest with feare run away from their owne countries. Am I better then they? No, no; but God spares me, because he pities me. O then I blesse his Name, beseeching him to deale still graciously with me, and looke in compassion upon all afflicted persons.

4. In walking I see, that my feet beare the whole weight of my bodie, and are the first in motion: and so I doe observe, that godlie affections are the next foundation, and the forerunners of good workes; for, good thoughts goe before good deeds. Let therefore, Lord, my affections be such, as beare fruit of a sweet relish; and grant, that both affections and actions be grounded upon faith and hope.

5. As I doe walke, no part of me touches the ground, but the soles of my feet; yet searching mine owne heart, I find it full of earth. But how is that earth come thither? Surely I got it by a fall, when I was in the wombe. My mother fell, and she and I were all bemir'd: yea, the durt is so old and drie, that no rubbing or washing can take it away. We doe love earth and earthly things, and unles God himselfe cleanse, or alter our hearts, they can receive but earth. Therefore, my God, wash my foule heart with thine owne bloud, or create in me another, which be as faire as this is blacke.

6. I have now walkt enough; I must then returne home. And what learne I by this? That as I came out but to walke, then must retire to my habitation; so I am borne to stay here but a while, from my everlasting dwelling. As then I were a foole, to walke so far, that I could not find the way home; so I am
most wretched, if, in my short journey on earth, I forget the way to heaven. Lord, let me not doe so; but keep me still in the right path of everlasting life, and forgive me the sins of my present recreation.

div.head: His Playing.
div.p: 1 ALl things have their seasons. The night succeeds the day, and againe this doth expell that. Could the Sun stand still in our horizon, he should burne all our fruits; and might darknes last long, all things should die for want of heat. We should in our actions imitate the course of nature, chuse time to watch and sleep, fast and feast, work and play, and never confound them. The best time to play is in the morning, and before meales; for then bodies are lighter, and naturall heat is by easie motion prepar'd for the digestion of the meat, which after meales is hindred by violent exercices, yea also by singing and speaking too much. O thou the Maker of nature! teach thy servant so to order his time, that his whole frame be kept in good temper.

2. To weep alwayes with sad Heraclitus, or continue laughter with light-hearted Democritus, is alike censurable. The meane is the best in all things. I will weep, when there's
cause; then I will laugh, least sorrow should contract my heart too much. I am wearie to work, or read: therefore I'le play a little, that by, ease and recreation I get new forces to labor. As thou, O Lord, hast been with me in the functions of my calling, so vouchsafe now, to be with me in all my playes, and direct them thy selfe, both to thy glorie and my good.

3. All playes are not fit for all men. We must chuse those, which best besuit either our nature, or calling. Then we must looke, they be lawfull, and that if we play for money, we never venture more, then we can lose, without injurie to our selves, wives, children, friends and poore: for certainly, if these want what we lose, we stake our soules with the money. Let me, O God, observe all these, and never suffer me to play that, which may procure me griefe, or my friends want.

4. It is not good to make toile of a toy: yet those doe it, and so doe ill, who play at too hard games, either for the bodie or soule; those doe much worse, who in their playes have a covetous mind: and those the worst of all, who by deceit win other mens money; for, that's a theft, which argues a base mind. Such gamesters would never refuse to cut a purse, should they not feare shame, or hanging. Lord, grant, that in my playes, I avoid these three faults,
and never play with them, whose minds are so corrupt.

5. Doe they begin to sweare and wrangle, and to turne jeast into earnest? Hath our play bred anger, and anger contention? Then either the play's naught, or the gamesters foolish. Quiet our minds, good Lord; and suffer not, we lose our peace and mutuall love, to win a game, whose profit can never equall our losse.

6. 'Tis play'd enough. As too much labor or studie dulls the mind, and consumes the bodie; so long playes slacken both, and make us loath to worke againe. I will therefore retire, beseeching thee, my God, to pardon all the faults, which my fellowes and I have committed in this our sport, both against thee and everie one of us. And because in these playes, I have receiv'd no harme, whereas manie in the like games, lose often their money by ill playing, their friends by cheates, mistakes, quarrells; and their lims and lives by fighting; I heartily thanke thee, good God, for my present preservation from all dangers, deceits and losses.

div.head: His Blessing on the Meat.
div.p:
1 TAke, good Father, from these creatures all hurtfull qualities, blesse them for my nutriment, and whilst I feed on them, let not my mouth sin in
exces, my tongue in foolish and vaine talkes, my heart in sinfull thoughts: but rather, Lord, make my conceits holie, my words grave, and my mouth sober, through Christ thy Son my Redeemer.

2. Lord, blesse these meates and drinke; that kindly they feed my bodie: blesse my bodie, that it be subject to the soule; and blesse my soule, with submission unto thy holie will, and obedience unto thy perfect Law.

3. The earth, O God, is full of thy riches; the sea, of thy wonders. Both afford me my present meat, which I take as given by thee: and that I take it not in vaine, let thy hand blesse it for the food of my bodie, my bodie with sobrietie, my soule with gratitude.

4. Here is meat for the flesh, but a perishing meat for a corruptible flesh: yet manie labor hard for it, not regarding that better meat, which endureth to everlasting life. Blessed Jesus, give me this last, thy flesh and bloud for the nutriment of my soule; the merits of thy life and death, thy holines and sufferings, for my redemption and felicitie: then let this outward meat be blest by thee, for the strength and health of my flesh.

5. Blesse, O God, these things for my use, that by them my flesh receive strength, and for them my spirit give thee thankes. While I feed on them bodily, let my soule be fed with good thoughts, and with the words, which proceed from thy mouth.

6. O God, Creator of all things, and preserver of men, in whose power it is to feed with little, or kee • with nothing! give, I pray thee, give thy blessing t • these few and course bits; that in the strength of the • I follow my affaires, not forgetting the duties, I owe thee.

div.head: His Eating and Drinking.
div.p: 1 NAturall heat is a wolfe in our breasts, which daily consumes us, unles we feed it with strange flesh. We need therefore eat twice, or thrice a day, either to hinder it from working upon us, or renew what it hath impair'd. Lord, give me meat enough to keep nature it strength; and grant, my strength be ever spent for thy glorie, in vertuous exercices, and religious actions.

2. Naturall heat is within us, as the fire in a lamp, which as it vanishes for want of oile; so it is quenched by too much. Moderate meat feeds our bodies, immoderate food destroye • them. O Lord! either give me not too much meat, or let me have wisdome, to take it in sobrietie.

3. Salt is the first dish laid at meales, and the last taken from the board: for, 'tis of common use. No sauce nor meat relish well without salt. Is not discretion the moderatrix of vertues much like it? No doubt, it is; for, without it they lose their grace, yea (some say)
their nature. Lord, season my heart with that salt, that I alwayes discerne good from ill, and now know what I need, for my just refection.

4. This bread is good; yet had I sweat in the sowing, reaping, threshing, grinding and baking of it, it should (no doubt) better relish; for, the pleasure purchast with paine is esteem'd as things dearly bought. As I am glad to have pleasure; so let me, Lord, be willing to take paine, and blesse thou my labors, that ease doe succeed them.

5. This bread is good: but doe those unregarded and Sun-burnt husbandmen, by whose paines I have it, eat it so pure as I? Not so perhaps. Their Landlords have muzled their mouthes, and racking their livings, keep them like asses from cleane provender; so that as their oxen, though they turne the ground to sow corn, yet must feed upon hay or straw; so those poore soules, notwithstanding they sow good wheat, must eat their bread made of barlie or rie. Lord, pitie them, and be as courteous unto them, in blessing their soules with contentment, their bodies with health, and their goods with increase, as their Landlords are hard to them.

6. Mans flesh is fed with bread, and his soule with the word of God. The bread is converted into our substance, but the word unites us to God. O Lord! give my stomach sufficient
heat, to digest well my meat; and give thy word vertue, to convert my soule into thee.

7. This drinke is good, and shall (doubtles) cheere up my heart, if I take it moderately; otherwise it shall dull my mind, and quite drowne my reason. False measures are forbid. Let me not then, O God, use them, in defrauding my flesh by too short sizes, or oppressing it by too great.

8. This sall • t, roots and fruits put me in mind of our Grandsires diet; for, they fed on such things, and drunk but cold water, yet lived long: whereas we have diversitie of cates, and live here so short while, that even our old age is but their infancie. Sobrietie kept them in health, gluttonie fils us with infirmities. Lord, teach me their vertue, and keep my soule from the vice of our time, and staine of this nation, exces in meat and drinke. Let not my bellie be my God, my paunch my temple, the meat my devotions.

9. Here is flesh to feed flesh. These poore creatures have lost their lives to maintaine mine. The flying birds, swimming fishes, creeping snailes, strong oxe, quick hare, innocent sheep, and simple dove cannot save their poore lives from men, but manie must die for one man. O God! how bountifull art thou to me; how thankfull then should I be unto thee? Thou hast made all these things for me, and they feed me; and thou hast made my selfe for thee; yet I will not serve
thee. Will I not? Then, gracious God, make me willing, and withall strong, to bring my desires to effect.

10. This meat is sw • et, but my mouth is now out of tast; and so Gods Law is good, but my soule being corrupt doth not like it. A soure sauce, or a fast may sharpen my stomach, and affliction recall my mind. This I will not refuse, when thou. O Lord, shall judge it expedient; but, good God, let not my soule fast: take never thy holie sp'rit from me, nor remove thy Gospel from the place, where I live.

11. I have here but course meat: yet I may think it d • licat, if I compare it to my merit or appetit: for, what doe I deserve of God, but to be starv'd to death, as manie, not so bad as I? Yet he gives meat to preserve life, and so good appetit, that a bit of rus • ie bakon, or dish of beanes, may be to me as sweet as a pheasant to the Courtier. Let it be so, my God. Give me an appetit according to my meat, or meat to my appetit: yet not for my merit, but for the dignitie of Christ, by whose riches relieve my povertie. Give me his graces, to supplie my want.

12. This meat is of hard digestion, therefore I'le forbeare it. Here is another more tender, on which I'le make this meale. Just so doe I in my spirituall refection. Good motions of vertue are too hard for my weake stomach, but vicious allurements are dainties unto my
palate. But so I doe mistake: for, what is harder then poison, which can never make good substance, but rather doth infect our bloud, and take away our lives? Vice and sin are yet harder: for, they poison the soule; whereas vertue and grace doe make her grow fat, plump and faire. O Lord! let me feed on such meates: teach me vertue, fill me with grace.

13. If I abound, I must not eat my morsell alone; but as Job, call the poore, fatherles and widow, whom God, who hath fashion'd me in the wombe, hath made. My God, give me the right heart of a man, to take compassion on my poore brethren, feed, clothe, warme, lodge, ease them, according to my meanes: and regard thou in thy mercie what I shall doe to them, by and for thee; by thy help, for thy sake. O let it not be said, that a man be worth a thousand, ten thousand, yea hundred thousand, while thousands want a piece of bread, a glasse of beare, a whole garment, a poore cottage, a hard bed to lie in: for, that man is not a right man, and he lies most basely, if he doth call himselfe Christian. O let the rich consider this, and so be wise.

14. 'Tis time to leave eating; my bellie hath enough, and in reason can crave no more. If he does it, he shall but lose his paine; for, 'tis better to rise with appetit, nimble to follow my calling, then with a full stomach, which should hinder my labor or studie. Now,
Lord, let me thanke thee for this good refection, and let my praises and prayers pierce the skies, and be receiv'd in thy presence; and, good God, lay not to my charge the sins, I have committed now.

div.head: His Grace after meales.
div.p: 1 MY bodie fed with thy creatures, and my soule with holie motions, give thee thankes, gracious God, for this great kindnes towards me. As thou art good to me, so will I be thankfull to thee: and when thou crown'st me with blessings both of plentie and pietie, I will returne thee praise, love and service. Blesse thou my will, that it bring forth all these, and blesse likewise all men, with holie wils and good effects.
2. Thou hast, O God, bountifully fed me, therefore I blesse thy Name, beseeching thee, to give me grace, to spend my strength in thy service, and not wast it in sin and vice.

3. Having now eat, and being satisfi'd, I blesse thee, O Lord God, as thou command'st and well deserv'st, for the good land, which thou hast given this nation: for which, as for my selfe, I beg the grace of humble gratitude; that we forget thee not our free benefactor, but keep thy commandements.

4. Love deserves love. What I have eat and drunke are tokens of thy love to me, O thou the ever loving God. Then grant, I returne love for love. O
let my heart ever love thee, my eternall lover, my soule and tongue blesse thee, my loving preserver, and liberall feeder.
5. I thanke thee, gracious God, for this good refection, and beg of thee the continuation of thy care; that by thee I doe live in health, safetie and holines.

6. Manie better then I, or rather not so bad as I, have not this meale been fed so well as I. It is thy goodnes towards me, O God, the giver of good things: therefore my heart and lips thanke thee. Continue, Lord, thy bountie towards me; and grant I continue, or rather begin now, my gratitude to thee, in keeping thy holie statutes.

div.head: His Feasting.
div.p: 1 I Will call my friends to a feast, and be merrie with them: and that nothing trouble our mirth, I will not send for them, whose minds are divided, or should strive for the place. But what a wise worldling am I in this, and what a foole in better things? How doe God and Satan disagree? yet I would daily receive them in my heart, by halting between both. But now, my soule, if the Lord be thy God, intertaine him alone, and shut the Devill out. Come then, my God, come and enter into my heart, that it may be at rest.

2. I will provide such things, as I know my
friends love: but I will looke, that none of them surfet with meats, exceed in drink, offend his God with oathes, the absent with slanders, the present with fiouts or quarrels, and the chast eares with lewd discourses. Look thou with me, O Lord; and let not my table be a snare either to my friends or my selfe.

3. This is a table well furnisht: but doe I not sit here, like that rich man in the Gospel, finely clothed and faring well, whilst manie Lazarus lie and crie at my gate? Not so I trust; for I neither doe this daily, nor (thankes to God) eat greedily my meat. As for beggers, none must lie at my doore, in expectation of my crums: for, God forbid, I should send the scraps of my table and trenchers to them, who in nature are as good as I, and in vertue and grace perhaps better. They shall have store of good, cleane and well-drest meat, that their bowels blesse me. Lord, pitie them, and accept that poore reliefe, I give them for thy sake. And because much talking and feasting are never without sin, forgive, good God, both these my friends and me our exces in words and diet, and the evill thoughts of our hearts.

4. I am bid to a feast, and I purpose to goe, that I be merrie with my friends. But that mirth exceed no measure, and friendship wrong not my conscience, vouchsafe, O Lord, to come
with me, and teach my soule the way to keep her selfe so warily, that I come in better, then I goe out.

5. I am bid to a feast, yet I will stay at home; for, some are bid likewise, whose companie may make me worse. They are usually drunke, then pick quarrell with their best friends. Keep me, O Lord, from such mens companies, least they teach me their evill wayes.

6. It is better to goe to burials, then to feasts: for, there we have images of death before us, which draw our soules to sad thoughts of dissolution: and here we find musick, pastime, good cheere, which so sweeten our lives, that we love them above measure. But thou, O Lord! let not my soule be drawne away from the meditation of her assured end, to the desire of longer life, then that, thou hast appointed me.

7. It burials make us thinke on death, why should not feasts represent us heaven? My bodie must be as that corps, laid in earth to feed wormes; and so my soule may be as merrie in heaven, as I am at a feast, yea thousand times merrier. Lord, let burials put me in mind of death, and let my feasts be so full of innocent pleasures; that my heart be on those heavenlie joyes, thou hast prepar'd for thine elect.

8. When I goe to a feast Christ forbids me, to sit in the highest place; and Solomon, to eat and drink first. The one shewes pride, the
other greedines, which is likewise bewray'd by an eye rounding all the dishes. I must then sit and eat, according to my state and need: If I doe more, I shall draw both envie and shame. Let, sweet Saviour, thy counsels take root in my heart, that by humilitie and sobrietie, I please thee and all men.

9. I goe to a Wedding, which is a divine institution, grac'd with Christs presence and first miracle. The same vouchsafe to be at this marriage, that as at such celebration, he did change water into wine; so he turne all the crosses and afflictions of these persons into ease and consolation. Blesse them, good Lord, with sincere love, united wits, prudent minds, sober bodies, sufficient meanes, vertuous children.

10. This man hath spar'd no cost, for here is varietie of meat; so that his guests may chuse what they like best, as indeed I see, they doe all; for, they eat with good appetit: at which our feast-maker seemes to take great delight. God hath daily a greater feast, to which all men are call'd: but some refuse to come, others come without cleane garments, the third sort hath crasie stomachs, and the fourth eats his meat. If I will not come, Lord, force me in: if I want the wedding garment; Lord, give it me: If my stomach is weake; Lord, strengthen it; so that (to make good thy eternall election) I receive thy
proffered grace of vocation, get health by justification, grow strong by sanctification, and after death be crown'd with glorious immortalitie.

11. I goe to a Baptisme, where before or after the Infant be baptiz'd, there is some meat and drinke, to shew the Parents joy, in the birth of their child. Indeed children are Gods blessing, and subjects of joy to their friends, when they take godlie courses. If not, they are causes of griefe, and breeders of sorrow. O Lord! blesse this with such quietnes in its infancie, and honestie through all its age, that its parents rejoyce, and thou be glorifi'd in it.

12. I am bid to a House-warming, and being willing to goe, I will send my meat before me, according to the custome of this countrie. Have these new housholders invited thee likewise, O thou the Maker of heaven, and the builder of a strong house? If they have not; yet thou maist goe, and offer thy selfe unto them; for, both they and their house are thine: but if they have; then, Lord, be there betimes, and blesse their persons and dwelling. Make them prosper in all spirituall graces, corporall health, worldlie riches.

div.head: His Fasting.
div.p:
1 A Wise mans diet should be such, that as he should never feast with exces; so
neither should he need fasting: but fooles, who glut themselves with meat,This and the five next are gr • unded on the V • ti •
• A • s • l •• es a t ••• g • us • cus ••• , • u •• , • imi • , vi •• us. when they have it plentifully, must sometimes fast, least they be • ick, or being sick, to recover their health. Make me, O Lord, so wise and temperate; that I never need such fasting.

2. Who hath no meat must fast; but if his want proceeds from his riot, not from just povertie, then his fast is the more tedious. Lord, keep me from this fast. Give me meanes enough to buy meat, and wit enough to rule my meanes, and eat my meat.

3. The Covetous man fasts, because he loves his coine, better then his bellie, which he pinches in youthlie age, least he should want in his old dayes: and in that he is as foolish, as he who dies for feare of death. Keep me, O God, from such folie. Let me give nature present need, and soberly provide for her future necessities.

4. Gluttons doe likewise fast, to have better appetits, and so their meat may the better relish. Then they fall to't, as the wolfe to her prey. Sensualitie is the aime of all their actions, and voluptie their paradise. Let not, Lord, my soule be like theirs, taken with the love of the flesh, and busie to fulfill her lust; seeing, her end is corruption, and her desert eternall damnation.

5. Hypocrites fast, to cloak their wickednes,
and so deceive their well meaning neighbours. So they pray long, to shew their zeale, whilst they devise, how they may deceive their best friends. Such fast is but a sacrifice to their father the Devill. From whose power, workes and members, good Lord, deliver me.

6. There is a fast which vertue bids; and that is both measure in meats, and abstinence from vice. So good mens lives are continuall fastings; for, they never exceed in the first, nor give themselves to the second. Such fast is pleasant unto God: for, his eyes love a sober flesh, and a pure mind. O Lord! make me such, as thou lov'st. Let me avoid exces in meats, and keep me from vicious humors, and all sinfull actions.

7. There is another vertuous fast, which is when the soule sees, the flesh hath got the start on her, and defil'd her immortall substance, by her lewd affections, then she cuts short her allowance, till she be brought under againe. This fast is likewise pleasant unto God, and of great use 'mongst godlie men. Yet, as preservatives are better then purgations, so let me, Lord, use this fasting, before the flesh rebell, and wound the soule to death.

8. This is a fasting day. My good Mother the Church knowing, all her children breake Gods and Natures lawes, hath in her tender love found remedies for their disease. She hath
set times to fast, that by humiliation of the soule, and punishment of the flesh, they recover what they have lost by pride and greedines. Lord, give me grace to heare my mothers instructions, and not forsake her law.

9. Healthie men need no Physician, and lawes are not made for the just. The Church ordaines fasting to them, whose heat of bloud, and fulnes of humors hinder the soules godlie functions. If I am one of them, I will observe her prescriptions; but if without selfe love I see, my flesh needs rather cherishing then chastening, I will not fast to day; for, I know, my Mother meanes not to destroy my nature, but to tame my sensualitie. O God! let me know mine owne strength, to eat and fast as need requires.

10. I know, fasting is good, when it is observ'd in humilitie, to shew sorrow for sinne, weane the flesh from all lust,See the Table of my Catechisme, • t the word Fasting. mortifie the whole man: yet I dare not by an exces of Rhetorique call it the root of grace, nor by pride esteem it meritorious; for neither meat, nor want of meat commends us unto God. It is enough that it be good and pleasant unto God, but 'twere too much, it should make my God my debtor. O Lord, accept my fast, and as thou lik'st it, reward it; yet not as 'tis my worke, but thine owne gift.

11. Whosoever washes away his spots, labors
in vaine, if presently he gets others; and he, who fasts for sin, doth lose his paine, if willingly he sin againe: therefore, my soule, put on a strong resolution, to flie henceforth from the lest sin, as from a greedie wolfe. And thou, good God, let thy grace strengthen me, that si • reigne not in me.

div.head: In Civill Warres.
div.p: 12. The sword is drawne upon our Land, and we, who hitherto have liv'd secure from hostile inva • ion, are falne amongst our selves unto a wofull division. What is the cause of this, but our unthankfulnes to our common Maker, who hath so long blest us with peace? Now by what meanes can we remove this threatning ill, but by a speedie repentance? O then, my soule, enter into thy selfe, take a full view of thy grievous offences, and unfainedly mourne for them, fast for them, and from them, and in this wise beg for mercie from God, before the hie throne of his grace. See the prayer, in the Yearlie Devotion.

div.head: In Forrain Warres.
div.p:
13. We heare rumors of warre, which the more affright us, because we have enjoy'd a sweet and plenteous peace. Both fire and sword have raged long amongst our poore neighbors,
and now begin to glimmer in our eyes, and make our hearts pant in our breasts. What shall we doe to save our selves? Seek out the cause of all these jarres, and in the beginning cut it off. Is sin the cause of them? O then, my soule, away with it. Remove it by detestation, vent it by confession, wash it with teares, drie it up with hunger, and by frequent and fervent pray'rs trie to asswage thy Gods anger. See the prayer in the Yearlie Devotion.

div.head: In time of Famine.
div.p:
14. Those begin to lack bread, whose dogs would hardly eat it drie. Now our exces should doe us good, if we in this necessitie had our past superfluitie. But wishes are to no purpose, but to increase our paines, and the remembrance of our past abundance doth but adde sorrow to our want. O cursed sin, what evils dost thou cause? By thee these are even readie to starve, for whose sake this great world was made. Base gluttonie, how manie dost thou kill? Now we must fast, because we have eat all, and we may fast till death, before God accept our fasting; for, it is forc't, and he regards but willing sacrifices. Then I will force my selfe to approve this constrained abstinence, that it may please my Lord, and with anguish of heart, for my past villanies, beg of
his grace remission of my sins, and my dailie bread, in these words. See the Yearlie Devotion.

div.head: In time of Plague.
div.p: 15. God hath sent his plague on our Land, and his servant our King hath proclaimed a fast. Surely I will keep it, as well as I am able: that is, I will forbeare all meat, till my bellie cries for hunger; and because that's but little in the sight of the Lord, I will abstaine from all lawfull pleasures and delightfull pastimes, much more from sin and transgression: then I will studie to doe good, and with an humble mind prostrate my selfe before my God, and earnestly intreat him thus. See the Yearlie Devotion.

div.head: His Abstinence.
div.p: 1 AS abstinence is a forbearance from meat and drinke for the correction of the flesh, it is a religious fasting: but as it is a refraining from flesh and certaine other meats; then 'tis a civill ordinance, or a voluntarie penance: for, the Church forbids us no meat, but leaves them all to our discreet and sober use. Let me not, Lord, abuse my libertie, for an occasion to the flesh; but give me grace, to forbeare all those meats, which either feed my lust, or the Prince allowes not.

2. The Church is an indulgent Mother, who, following her Husbands steps, gives free leave unto her children, to eat of everie thing, which God hath made: yet Princes seeing, all beasts and fowles should be shortly devour'd by us, and drown'd in our greedie bellies, have for certaine dayes and times forbid all flesh, to preserve young cattle, and bring fish in request. Suffer me not, O Lord, to take my Mothers indulgence for a pretext to despise my Governours lawes.

3. If when I fast, I doe abstaine from flesh, and feed upon dainties, what fast is that? It is rather a Glutton's feast. And if I fast till night, then glut my selfe with meat, what availeth my abstinence? Yet th • se passe for custome, the first amongst our pretended Catholicks, and the second among too many Protestants. Keep me, O God, from both errors. Grant that after my fast I feed soberly on those meats, which content my nature, and tickle not sensualitie.

4. The best abstinence of all is to have a constant diet, both for measure and time, avoid varietie and superfluitie either of flesh or fish, of wine or beere. Happie is he, who keeps such abstinence; for so with Gods blessing his flesh shall be healthie and strong, his mind subtile, his heart light and merrie, his counsels wise, his thoughts chast and holie. O God!
teach me such abstinence, and blesse it with these sweet effects.

5. Abstinence was the triall of Adams obedience, and if he had forborne a tree, his posteritie had been blest. All our sorrowes come from a bit, whose soure relish sets all his childrens teeth on edge. O Lord! put me ever in mind of the cause of my Parents fall; that my soule be warie of the like tentations.

6. Christ being hungrie was tempted to eat bread; whence I doe learne, that it is not the qualitie of the meat, which makes us guiltie before God, but the greedines of the mind. A weake stomach may eat dainties without offence, whilst others lose their foules for pork, as Esau sold his birth-right for Jacobs red pottage. Blesse me, O Lord, with a temperate mind, to eat for need, and not for voluptie; drinke to quench thirst, not to stirre lust.

7. Here is a Catholique, at least so pretended, whose conscience being weak, and his understanding darkened, he thinkes that on this day, it is a great sin to eat flesh. Shall I then forbeare it, and so forgoe the libertie, by which Christ made me free? Yes, for otherwise my libertie should become a stumbling-block to him, for whom the same Christ perhaps dy'd; and so may convert him: for either he will eat flesh with me, against his own conscience;
or judge hard of me, against charitie. Woe unto him, through whom offences come. Then, Lord, let me never doe that, which gives offence to anie man, unles it be just and needfull; but grant, that for my neighbours sake I forbeare that, which he dislikes, and I can lawfully omit.

8. My fast should be the poore mans feast, and my abstinence his abundance. Let then now his emptie bellie be fill'd with that, which my almost full guts need not▪ then let me adde prayers to both, and I beleeve, the Lord will regard them, and be gracious to me. Increase my faith, O God, and receive this my sacrifice of abstinence, almes and prayer.

div.head: His Gaines.
div.p: 1 WE are all by nature much desirous of Gaine, as a help against want. And could our hearts but rest content, when we have got enough, to give the flesh what she justly requires, our profits should seem great; whereas for new desires of increasing our goods, we cannot savour the sweetnes of what we have alreadie got. Blesse my labors, O Lord, that Gaine may attend them, and let my mind be satisfi'd with moderate profits.

2. My meanes increase, and I adde daily to my store, and which comforts me much, what
I have is well got. So I may call it mine, and enjoy it as a blessing of God, and the fruit of mine owne labors. As by thy help, most gracious Lord, I get whereby to live; so blesse my gaines, that both they content me, and passe from me to my posteritie.

3. Filthie lucres and ill gaines are forbid; for, they breed but sorrow, remorse and feares. Whosoever injustly gets, can build no assurance on his riches, but still looks when they shall away. That which rapine gathers, revelling doth disperse, theeves rob, fire burnes, winds tumble downe, flouds sweep away. Then, God forbid, I should grow rich by wicked meanes. O Lord! let never my heart desire base profits, my tongue beg injust things, my hands take what's not mine.

4. I am wealthie, but is all this wealth mine? Am I quite out of debt? Have my workmen their hire, my servants their whole wages, the poore my charitie; or is here anie thing brought in by plunder or theft, deceit or extortion? If it be so, I'le cast it out: yea even now without further delay▪ its owner shall have it, with full satisfaction of the losses, he hath receiv'd by my injust detention of his goods. Behold, Lord, my resolution: help me in the execution of it, and forgive me the wrong, I have done unto my brethren.

5. Our day is the antipodes their night; for whilst the Sunne shines in our horizon, theirs remaines in darknes. So my gaines are other mens losses; for, what comes unto me, goes away from others. Is not, O God, the world big enough for all men? Doubtles it is, if its division were well made: but whilst some have too much, others must want: yet he, who hath lest, hath enough, if he can rule desire. Lord, give poore men contented hearts, and rich persons bountifull hands.

6. Who makes hast to be rich, shall neither be innocent, nor content: for, he must meet with manie great tentations and difficulties; tentations, to transgresse the rules of justice or of charitie; difficulties, to get and preserve his riches. O that God would give me a wise moderation, to seek and enjoy his earthlie blessings, without guile or too much molestation! Thou maist give this, my Lord; and this I beg of thee.

7. I thinke, that as raine is then best, when it falls by drops, not by streames; so gaine, coming by little and little, is like to doe more good, then if it should come all at once. An inheritance may be gotten hastily, but the end thereof shall not be blest; either because 'tis got unlawfully, or with such ease, that we regard it not, and so spend it with the same hast, 'tis come. Lord, give me thy worldlie blessings, as they may doe me the more good, and let me not labor
to grow rich too soone; least the love of money (that bitter root of all evill) pierce my heart with manie sorrowes.

8. The blessing of the Lord makes rich, and he addes no sorrow with it. O blest riches without sorrow! O then desirable blessing, which gives riches without sorrow! Let me have this blessing, O God; let me expect riches of thee. I am a stranger before thee, yea in this Land, a poore man without friends or anie human help: yet I feare not much want, although I feel some alreadie; because I know, riches and honor come of thee, and thou reign'st over all. The earth is thine, heaven is thine. O how then can I feare? If men forsake me, cannot Crowes help me? If I can have no part in the fruits of the earth, cannot heaven raine a little Manna, or a wind bring me quailes? This may be done, and if it be not done, let thy blessing make me rich in patience.

9. Gold and silver are but earthlie, knowledge surpasses both, and wisdome is before riches. I have this day read a good book, heard a daintie Sermon, receiv'd a godlie instruction. And as this is greater gaine then fine gold and rubies; so I more earnestly thank thee, O God, the giver of good things, for this thy favor to my soule, then if thou hast increas'd my worldlie store. Let me; O Lord, never lose that, which I have got this day; but keep it still in my memorie, and grant, I make good use of it.

10. My brother hath this day trespassed against me, or in my presence against God, and I with a meek sp'rit have shew'd him his fault; so that he hath heard me, and will (as I beleeve) be warie to commit either it, or the like. Is not this a great gaine? Lord, take the greatest share in it; for, it was by thy grace, that my admonition hath been by him received in good part. Grant, I continue this good course, to correct gently my brethren; and grant likewise, others deale so with me, when I forget mine owne dutie.

11. I have this day won a soule unto God. He was (poore man) in the wrong way, bred in error, taught strange doctrine, suckled with an ill milke; but I, with strong reasons and gentle persuasions, have made him see the dangers of his opinion, and withall renounce it. Is not this a great gaine? Doubtles it is. O then, good Lord, receive now the glorie of it: for, 'tis thy hand, which hath delivered his soule out of the Devils snare, and it is by thy grace, that he hath acknowledg'd thy truth.

12. Ill gaines are worse then losses. I might have had friends, wealth and honors, had I been willing to forsake Christ, or at least give him some fellowes; but what things were gaine unto me, those I esteemed losse for Christ. Christ, the Son of the living God! let me
ever adhere to thee, and count all things but dung; that I may win thee, my Lord and my God.

div.head: His Losses.
div.p: 1 AS we love gaine, so we feare losse, yea this is more sensible: yet if we consider, that all things are here under change, we will patiently beare our losses. There is no man, who alwaies gains. Why then should I look to get still, and not let go sometimes? O Lord! let me never refuse what's common to all men. Make me as patient in my losses, as I am joyfull in my gaines.

2. The Sea receives and casts waters, the Moone gets and loses her light, and so doe I my goods. I had more this morning, then I have now: yet let that passe, it may returne againe. My comfort is, that I am not lost with my meanes. Skin for skin, yea all, I have, will I freely give for my life. Blesse it, O Lord, with vertue, length and health; and doe what thou wilt with my wealth: yea if it be thy blessed will, to touch my bones and flesh, I resigne my life unto thee: onely save my soule.

3. Although my goods be stolne by theeves, or burnt by fire; my houses be blowne by the wind, and my children and friends wrapt in their ruine; yet by Gods grace, I will with
Job fall on the ground, and worshipping that Lord, who hath given and taken away, blesse his name in my losses, with a heart as patient as he himselfe shall give. Give it, O God, give it so good, that it please thee, an honest and religious heart.

4. Plunderers have been here; either little or nothing is left me, for a long subsistence, unles God assist me. Him therefore I implore, before whom I humbly confesse, my sins deserve these and greater losses: yet from whom I hope some speedie reliefe. Regard, O Lord, my confession, and let me not be frustrat in my hope.

5. My estate is like to be sequestred, because I adhere not to this partie: and I cleave not to it, for anie privat ends of honor or profit, which I have or expect from the other; but because myI suppose, that on wise and pio •• man, whether Royalist or Parliamenties, shall except against this, but rather appro •• it, as convenient for both, in their severall lights, and for anie person in other civill commotions. conscience tells me, right stands not with this side, and this side stands not for Gods truth. If it be so as I conceive, O Lord, convert or withstand these, who violate our rights, infringe our libertie, suppresse thy truth; and suffer them not to plunder my goods, incroach on my estate, afflict, captivate my person: or if they have done these, or some of these, incline, compell their hearts to a speedie satisfaction. But if this partie be indeed for thy truth and our good, and thou approv'st their warre, let me (I pray thee) know
their ground, that my heart be with them; and so let them assist, not ruine me.

6. I have lost all, and now must work hard, beg or starve. But what work can I doe, having learnt no trade in my youth, or being weak by age? And must I beg, who have reliev'd beggers? Or must I starve, while oppressors are fully fed with my good meat and drinke; with my poultrie, sheep and oxen; with the corne of my fields? All these are just with thee, O God. Thou maist, in equitie, call me to hard labor, for my long idlenes; lead me from doore to doore, to humble my proud heart; and starve me, for my past exces. If thou dost so, thy name be prais'd: yet I pray thee, not to doe so; but in compassion to spare me, and give me meanes againe, to live sweetly and holily.

7. My losse is great, therefore my cares shall be the lesse. My trust was perhaps in my goods, and my riches made me too proud: least therefore my meanes should lose me, God hath made me lose them: for although they be snatcht from me by violence and injust meanes, or lost through mine owne negligence; yet God had a hand in the losse, to order it to his glorie, and my greater profit, unles by foolish impatience, I goe about to withstand it. Let me, O Lord, never doe so: but grant, that in all things I conforme my will unto thine.

8. It is ingratitude, to forget that, which is given, and remember what is taken away. In that I lose, I see, that God deales far better with me, then with manie thousands, who have nothing to lose; whereas my losse shewes, that I had something. Therefore in stead of murmuring at my damage, I will thanke God for the fruition of those things, which I have lost this day. Good Lord, receive my thankes, and give me another blessing, for that, thou hast taken from me.

9. What I have lost may doe good unto another. I was (belike) hard-hearted to the poore, an injust steward of my meanes; and therefore God hath taken that from me, which I kept from his poore members. If it be so, my heart followes my losse, to wish the finder of my purse or goods, a much good doe them him; beseeching thee, my God, to give that person grace, to make that use of them, which I had made, had I been wise: yet first, to make inquisition of the owner, as he's oblig'd to doe.

10. I was yesterday in good health, but now either by ill orders in diet or exercice, or by Gods owne visitation I am not as I was; for, I feele my selfe sick: and so my health (the sweetest sauce of life) is lost. But thou, my God, in whose hands are health and sicknes, vouchsafe now to remove my paine; then give me grace to be
thankfull to thee, for the recoverie of my health, and hereafter avoid all such causes of distemper.

11. I have this day lost a friend by wrangling. Is not that a great losse? Yes, and so great, that ere the Sun be set, I'le trie, whether I can win him againe. He is not worthie to have friends, who can suffer no injurie, nor beare a frowne, or a hard word from them. Whether he be lost by my fault, or his owne, I weigh not much: but by my gentlenes I will blow up that fire, which is halfe extinguisht. Help me, good Lord, and as thou lov'st union; so let thy spirit make up this.

12. I was this day in the companie of a man, whose modest eares would heare no foolish and lewd talkes, whose tongue could neither sweare nor slander, and whose carriage was both sober and religious. But I, like a Devill incarnat, have made him blush at his godlie disposition, persuaded him to quaffe, sweare and swagger, and taught him to howle when others yell, and imitate my rude fashions: and so by my conversation he hath lost his vertue, and with vertue the glorious life of his immortall soule. Is not this a great losse? Shall not my soule answer for his? Then, O good God, forgive me this great wickednes, and give me grace to reclaime him speedily, by a contrarie behaviour; and by weightie reasons shew him the great
danger, both he and I are in, unles we forsake such ill courses.

13. Goods, health and friends may be recov'red being lost; time is not so: for, its losse is irreparable. What therefore shall I doe, since I have lost this day, which God had given me to beg mercie for my time past, grace for the present, glorie for the future? I cannot recall it; yet I will (as St. Paul counsels) redeem it: that is, the lesse I have done to day, the more will I doe to morrow. I have loitered to day, then to morrow I'le up sooner then my custome, and worke harder, and pray longer, then I am us'd to doe. Grant, good Lord, I doe so, and pardoning my idlenes, give grace to walke circumspectly, redeeming the season.

14. If the losse of time be irreparable, what is that of the soule? Not onely irreparable, but also incomparable. The gaine of the whole world is nothing to that losse. O then, my God, make me watch over this treasure, carefull to preserve this Jewell. Let me not lose it through ignorance or negligence; not give it for pleasure; not sell it for honor, riches, or anie other consideration.

div.head: His Spending and Saving.
div.p:
1 FRugalitie is a vertue between prodigalitie and avarice, which teaches man to
keep his owne, or to bestow it well: avoid profuse expence in his buildings, diet, attire; love and seek needfull things, and not regard superfluous. Let, Lord, this vertue tutour me, that discreetly I dispose of my meanes, to my present comfort and future occasions.

2. It is the gift of God to take our share in our riches, and rejoyce in our owne labor: yet our share must be moderat, and our joy such, as may last long. We must neither spend by riot, nor save by avarice: but (as our countrie Proverb saith) Let's cut our coat, according to our cloth. Lord, give me wisdome to doe so. Let me fill my bellie, and cover my back in such sort; that I want not meat for the first, nor clothes for the second.

3. Wealth without wisdome breeds sorrow; for, some spend it so lavishly, that it is quickly gone; then those must fast, whose daylie meales were feasts; and in their rags you may see the Proverb woven,
Choice food and costlie fare
Make the back parts goe bare. Others contrariwise save it with such covetousnes, that they receive no good of it, but by a frequent sight. Teach me, O Lord, frugalitie, and let me both hate prodigalitie, and loath covetousnes.

4. When Christ forbids the care of the morrow,
he doth not blame moderate provision of necessarie things; but busie and distrustfull thoughts: for, he himselfe commanded his Disciples to gather the fragments, which did remaine of his miraculous banquet, and also beg of his Father their daylie bread. We may then lawfully lay up in store for the next yeare what we save out of this. Onely let not the poore, our servants, friends, (much lesse our owne bodies) challenge for theirs our provision. Let me, O God, forbeare what thou forbid'st, and doe what thou command'st. Let neither carking care of the future trouble my braines by day, and hinder my night sleep; nor sloth keep me from providing in hot Summer, what I may need in cold Winter.

5. Should the Schoole-mistres of the sluggard stay till Winter, to make her provision, her death might make her see her fault: for, in vaine is that sought at last, which was not got, or spar'd at first. That little Ant gathers betimes her store, and though she bring but graine by graine: yet she brings enough for her need. So grant, my God, I doe begin to save in youth (the fittest time to get) what I shall want in my old age (a time to lose or spend) and gather by degrees, and from my present overplus, what may serve me, when the harvest is past.

6. If my living be worth but twentie
pounds, shall I live as one of fourtie? Then that's the way unto the hospitall, the gaole, and perhaps the g • llowes. But if God hath blest me with three hundred a yeare, shall I live as one of twentie, to keep the rest for my children, if yet I have anie? Then I'le be first assur'd, they shall likewise live at my rate; for, they are not better then I. Yet what folie should be both mine and theirs, to tye, and be ty'd to such condition? Doth God give me riches, and not the pow'r to eat of them? Then I am sick of an evill disease. No, no: if I am worth but twentie pounds, I will be so frugall, that they shall keep me well, without eating my corne in grasse, and being on my neighbours score. But if my meanes come to hundreds, I will not feed as my tenants, nor be clothed as a Yeoman. I'le save something for a deare yeare, and my childrens portions; and with the rest keep such a house, that my Hall shall not mock beggers. My neighbours shall tast of my meat, drink of my beere, and freely borrow my money. My wooll shall clothe naked persons, my fire warme them, my meat feed them, my barnes, or better roome lodge them. Lord, give me grace to doe as I purpose. If thou blesse me but with small meanes, give me wit to use them so well, that they may suffice me: and if thou give me wealth and store, teach me frugalitie, to
spend what is needfull to me, and helpfull to others; then save the rest.

div.head: His Giving and Taking.
div.p: 1 ALl things in the world give and take; give by inclination, take through necessitie. Heavens powre downe their influence, and the earth receives it. That's naturall to them, and necessarie unto this. From the hie God, to the lowest creature, there is continuall giving and taking. Onely some men would freely take alwayes, and never give; and in that they shew themselves bad citizens in this great common-wealth. Lord, let me not be one of them. As I love to receive, so let me be willing to give both unto thee and thy creatures.

2. There is one God, by whose gift all things are, and who, as he's alwayes giving, so he would still receive. He gives being, and what belongs to it; yet he desires but obedience and praise: and that he hath freely of all his creatures, except man. Of man chiefly God would have both, not because he needs them (for in that we may see and say, he is our God, that he hath no need of our goods) but for mans owne profit: for, as this being is but little considerable, unles we obtaine another, which be happie and perpetuall, and that we can never
obtaine, unles we praise and obey him, whose most free gift it is, he desires of us these two things, that he may give us his glorie. O God, grant, I willingly give thee these. Let me praise thy great Name, obey thy holie will, and in all things seeke to please thee: then let thy glorious Kingdome come.

3. The husbandman hath not so much right, to expect from his field what he hath sowne in it, as our God hath to look from us the service, we owe him: for, after the ploughman hath cast his seed into the ground and covered it, he does nothing more to make it grow: then he receives farre more then he hath sowne; whereas God sowes in us the seeds and fruits, which he expects from us, waters them with his former and later raine, gives them their growth, and brings them to maturitie. So then God is the first giver to me: yea such giver, that I can give him nothing, but what I have receiv'd of him. Yet if I give him that willingly, he doth thanke me, and confesse himselfe my debtor. O gracious God! who would not give thee what is thine, and so have thee ingaged by vertue of thy promises? Here is, my God, the best thing, I can give, even my whole person. Lord, make it such, that the gift may please thee.

4. After I have given to God what I have
received of him, my soule must have my second almes; for she's a giver too. By her I grow, feele, understand: therefore I'le bestow this on her: she shall be my darling and better part; shall rule this wanton flesh; take the best of my time for her noble functions of meditation and prayer. Mercifull God! let me never revoke this gift, but help my soule to enjoy it, without opposition.

5. My bodie shall have something too; for it gives both delight and knowledge to my soul with the use of its senses. If that be a faithfull servant, this must be a kind dame. Then it shall have good meat and drinke, warme and decent garments, good rest, and not too much labor. Lord, give me meanes and wit to afford my flesh kind usage; and grant, it abuse not my gentlenes, and by my goodnes receive harme.

6. I have from my parents this visible substance, and besides, I have had of them manie prayers, instructions, corrections and helps. So I am greatly in their debt, and thus I will indeavour to pay them. I will so live, that their griefe shall be turn'd to joy, their killing feares into comforting assurance; and their care into ease. O God, grant, I doe so. Let me honor, love, serve, obey, help them, as thou comman'dst, and they deserve; and blesse them, my good
Lord, with faithfull soules, healthie bodies, honorable names, and moderat riches.

7. My wise doth give me help, my child comfort, and my servant service: therefore as I take, I will give. The first shall have my love, the second good counsels and carefull instruction, and both my meanes, when I am dead; and whilst I live, shall enjoy them with sobrietie, as my selfe. As for the last, his wages shall be paid quarterly, and something more giv'n him. Certainly, he shall feel my heat before strangers, and quench his thirst at my fountaine, if I can spare of my water. Good Lord, so blesse us all, that we cheerfully give and take, according to our pow'r. So shall we live content, not as manie, but as one soule.

8. Kings give, and must receive. They give libertie, counsels, examples to serve God, praise to good workes, terror to the evill. They are the fathers of their countrie, the protectors of their subjects, supporters of the weak, exalters of lowlie persons, supplanters of the proud. They must then receive great honor, faithfull service, liberall, valiant helps. Thou King of kings, & Lord of lords, make all Kings and Governors such; and assist their subjects, in the voluntarie discharge of these and all other duties.

9. The Ministers of Christ are magnifique
givers; sith they give that, which is more precious then rubies, the saving knowledge of our God. How liberall then must we be to them, that they want not the lest commoditie? Let not the fees or honors of Physicians or Lawyers exceed theirs, otherwise we declare, that our bodies and goods are our principall care. Make me, O God, so judicious, so religious; that I greatly honor, liberally maintaine the stewards of thy mysteries, esteeming beautifull the feet of those blest men, who bring glad tidings of good things, preach the Gospel of peace.

10. Some persons may be esteem'd Ministers of Christ and his Church, although they want usuall ordination. Such are all those, who on all occasions instruct, exhort and reprove their brethren, in the spirit of Christ. And such again are those, whose loving hearts vent forth their zeale, in their pious writings, for the good of the Church. Such deserve our regard, and should find us alwayes willing, to manifest our gratitude to God and them, by the sweet fruits of faith and love, encouraging them in their commendable wayes, by all the helps, which we can afford, and they want. So, my Lord, grant, I doe, according to my pow'r. O let me not denie my worldlie goods to those, who spend themselves for me, for my eternall happines; and let all men be affected with the same mind, as they
and I: as they, to manifest thy truth; as I, to regard their holie labor.

11. My friend gives me counsels in busines, consolation in affliction, delight by his conversation, and help with his goods in my want. Let him, my God, receive the like of me, as occasion shall serve: make me as faithfull and helpfull to him, as I find him to me.

12. There are some men 'mongst us, whose penurie is great, and the greater, because their generositie permits them not mendicitie. Such are decay'd Gentlemen, Merchants and others once rich. Such must not be forgot, but remembred in our secret and Christian almes, chiefly if they be persons of honor, as well for vertue as for bloud, as well for present pietie, as for their past plentie. Help them, good God, and let me and all honest men prevent their pray'rs, by our voluntarie reliefe.

13. There are againe some men 'mongst us, who having had houses by the hundred, fathers, mothers, brothers and sisters by thousands, are (for Christs sake) depriv'd of all; honorable persons, where the Pope is ador'd; most religious, where religion is made superstition. Shall these have no regard 'mongst us, who have in deed, or in pretext so much Christianitie? Shall they be forc't to serve, starve, or flie back to their Monasteries, as mistrusting
upon their conversion, the sinceritie of our faith, for want of charitie? No, no: this must not be. They must be embrac'd and honor'd; and if they want, maintain'd; least Gods spirit be griev'd in them, and his light burden seem grievous to them. Yet we must wisely observe them, till their holie conversation and long perseverance have seal'd to us their conversion. Then they must be most deare to us, not as strangers, but members of the same bodie. Then they must be so welcome to us all, so gladly admitted into our houses, that they may not misse theirs. So shall we weaken the Popes Sect, and fortifie the Church of Christ. So let it be, O thou great Shepherd of the sheep. Call those to us, who like wolves will devoure thy flocke; and being come, grant, they find us loving to them, carefull of them, not being inferior in policie and charitie unto the children of this world, who have pensions, houses, honors for them, who forsake thy truth and our Church.

14. There is one, who shall take of me, though he give me nothing, unles it be injurious words, soure lookes, bitter curses, ill termes. He is my sworne enemie; yet I wil never use him so. I'le pray for him. I'le doe him good, and if he stumble before me, I will not tread on him; but be the first to help him up. Shall I lose my labor, give and not take,
doe good and receive none? O no. I may make him my friend by my gentle cariage, then he will thanke and requite me. Whether he doe it or no, I shall not lose my reward; for in judgement it shall be dealt with me, as I have dealt with him. Let me, O Lord, even doe as I say, beare for thy sake a kind mind towards all my foes, love and pitie mine enemies, and seek the good of them, who plot my destruction.

15. This begger gives me manie vowes: he wishes me long life, prayes God to blesse me and my store, keep my houses from fire and flouds, my goods from theeves, my whole person from harme. Shall he receive nothing of me; or shall I curse him, because he doth blesse me? Yes, he's a rogue,Let not these expressions se •• strange: for, sith in my Meditations, my designe is to shew and reforme vice, as well as to commend vertue: I suppose, my tongue may write what my eares have heard. a vagabond, a lazie and lowsie rake-hell, a dissembling villaine, whose heart doth curse, whilst his tongue blesses me. Our law condemnes all such unto the house of correction; and were I a Justice of Peace, I would teach him another tune, and make him take a better course. But soft, thou wicked tongue, the bewrayer of an ungodlie heart! Dost thou not marke in this mans rags Christs owne liverie? Dost thou not know, that he, who hath made this man hath made thee; and therefore could have fram'd thee more crooked, lame
and poore then him, yea a base worme, or some venemous toad? Who hath discerned thee? shouldst thou not be as lowsie as he is? as scabbed as the worst, if God had not discerned thee from him or such? Wherefore then dost thou revile him? In mocking him, dost thou not reproach his Maker? And fear'st thou not, that for the oppression of this poore, for the sighing of this needie, God arise now, to set him in safetie from thee, who dost puffe at him, in grinding to dust thy hard heart and curst tongue? Then change thy tune, give him faire words to comfort him; then with money, meat, drink or clothes commend him unto his Maker. Thou Christ, who hast appear'd to men, in the shape of a servant, let me never chafe at those distrest soules, whom thou vouchsaf'st to call brethren; but grant, I doe honor and love them as thy friends, and help them as their qualitie and need require, and my meanes permit me.

16. Alas poore soule! I pitie much thy case. Depart in peace, and the Lord be with thee. This is a godlie pray'r; but yet too thin, to keep this naked man from cold, and too light to feed him. An old garment and a dish of pottage may make him feele, that God begins to be with him; for, his hungrie bellie cannot be fill'd with words, nor his cold back made warme with pray'rs. Then he shall have what
I can spare. My God, accept my will; for my reliefe is not worthie to be set upon thine account. Yet 'tis better then a cup of cold water, to the giver of which thou hast promised a reward. O then, let this my small, yet free, gift receive his.

17. This poore is now in great distresse, so that unles he be quickly reliev'd, he must either steale, or be starv'd. If then I can, and will not assist him, his theft or death shall be laid to my charge. This is, my soule, a faire occasion, to give thy God what he hath given thee. Now then let this person have a little of what thou enjoy'st now, but must leave afterward; and doubt not, but that God will render thee a hundred for one. Jesu, the Son of man! make me so tender to thy poore, and readie to help them for thy sake, that when thou shalt sit on the throne of thy glorie, I heare of thee those gracious and comfortable words, by which thou shalt welcome all those, who have given thee meat in thy hunger, drinke in thy thirst, lodging in thy travels, clothes in thy nuditie.

18. These beasts give me their attendance; these oxen plough my ground, these horses carrie me, these cowes afford me milke, and these sheep wooll: these dogs keep my house and goods safe, and these cats kill my mice: since therefore I am in their debt, I will studie a requitall. They shall have meat in my service,
and their worke shall be moderate. Their guts shall not crie against me, nor their grones shew, I am a hard master. Let me not, Lord, abuse thy creatures, and by cruell dealing shew, I am worse then they. They doe serve me, as thou hast appointed; let me use them, as they deserve; and grant, they give me this lesson, to serve thee willingly, since thou hast made me for that end.

19. A just man is mercifull to his beast, yet he knowes that a beast is but a beast, and so uses her as a beast; not as a man; or better then a man, as too manie do now, who in that are not just, but verie in just and foolish. A dog, horse, cat, monkey and such are more deare then manie servants, yea some nice persons shew them greater love then to their own children. It is not a light sin, but rather so grievous and common, that I beseech the Lord, to impute not to this Nation, that their dogs eat delicat bits in their laps and trenchers, while his poore members are hungrie at their dores: Rather, O God, pardon this transgression, and shew us cleerly the folie and inhumanitie of it; that we loath and shun it. O permit not, we preferre a beast to a man, feed dogs better then our brethren: allow a beast what we denie to a Christian.

20. We must give others what they like, such things, as best please them, yet not foment their vice, or be dangerous. We must not
then give weapons to mad men, strong drinke to the drunkard, riches to the avare, honors to th' ambitious, nor bribes to pervert justice. Make me, O God, discreet in all my gifts, that they please, not offend. Let not my gifts be baits to sin, nor bribes for injustice; and grant, I hate to receive such.

21. Whosoever hath anie right to give Church or State-offices, is in conscience oblig'd, to bestow them on those onely, who are qualified for them, yea upon them, who are the most skilfull, honest and diligent; bewaring to commit the sin of preference, in the election of Officers, regarding bloud, alliance, or friendship before capacitie. That our great men observe the first, and forbeare the second, vouchsafe them, O great God, knowledge, love, feare: knowledge of their dutie, and of the persons, they preferre; love to the publick good; and feare to offend thee, corrupt the Church, ruine the State, and damne their soules, by the promotion of evill persons; of ignorant, injust, negligent officers: and let these men feare to receive functions, least to themselves and to manie others they procure damnation.

22. We must not give what is not properly our owne, or that, in which others have right: neither must we receive that thing, which the owner ought not to give, or of which he is not right proprietarie. That I neither give nor
take thus, the Lord blesse me with a wise and just heart.

23. God and wise men love a cheerfull giver: one, who gives freely what he can, makes a Christian inquisition of other mens necessities, prevents their intreaties, and blushes at their thankes. O that all rich persons were such! how rich should their soules be! yea how sweetly should they enjoy these earthlie goods, and safely transmit them to their posteritie! But such none can make them, but the almightie God. Him then I pray, to worke upon their hearts, till he hath made them free, in the voluntarie distribution of their riches among their poore brethren, and for those uses, which are call'd pious, because they promote godlines. Doe so, my God, and so open our hearts, that none want, while others exceed, and none exceed, while pietie requires their help, in the Christian education of youth, liberall maintenance and encouragement of religious, learned persons, and publication of good bookes.

24. Gifts have their times, as well as all things else: and wise is he, who observes them, not only to pleasure others, but for his honest advantage, and personall preservation; sometimes making his way by gifts, and other times pacifying anger. So did Jacob to Esau, and so Abigail to David: for, divine religion
forbids not all humane prudence; but rather allowes it, where it is joyn'd with honestie. If then I have need of great men, or feare anie enemie, I will send my gifts before me; and that I lose them not, move, my good Lord, move their hearts so, that they favour my cause, or be willingly reconcil'd to me.

div.head: His Promising and Performing.
div.p: 1 PRomises are necessarie, not only betwixt man and man; but also betwixt God and man: for, as it is neither expedient nor possible, to doe or give all things at once; so promises are requisit, for assurance of graces or duties deferr'd. Yet notwithstanding the necessitie and great utilitie of Promises, we must well examine their legalitie and possibilitie: for, as he is wicked, who promises some injustice; so he's a foole, who binds himselfe to impossibilities. Lord, let me be neither of these; but give me both honestie and wisdome, in my contracts with thee and men. Let me not rashly vow thee that, which is not in my pow'r, and thou dost not require: nor promise that to men, which is not just, expedient, or possible.

2. If we must not ingage our selves to anie injust and impossible thing, we ought not to oblige others unto such promises: for, we must
in all equitie give others the same law, we take. If we doe otherwise, we shall be guiltie of their sins in that; and God and good men may then look on us, as upon gulls, who lay snares for sillie persons. Such base thoughts be far from my heart, which the just God vouchsafe to fill with upright affections.

3. The promises of the wise and godlie are like the law of the Medes and Persians: they must not be repeal'd; for, being made with prudent cautions, and all requisit conditions, they are perform'd with honestie and religion. Make me, O Lord, both wise and religious in the discharge of all duties, and performance of all my promises.

4. As all men are sinners, the wisest and holiest may erre, in their promises unto God and men: for they are sometimes made in ignorance, superstition, temeritie, love or anger: but then such must not be perform'd, whose injustice or impossibilitie appeares before the execution: but we must rather grieve for such blind, light or passionat vowes. I have made manie such, yea perhaps perform'd them; and therefore I beg thy pardon, O thou wise and great God, who knowst the folie and weaknes of man. And that I never more promise, performe the like, indue me with wisdome, blesse me with honestie.

5. God promises to us exceeding great and
precious things, riches, honors, peace, friends, health, strength, children, grace & glorie: and as God cannot lye, so we may well expect the performance of all his promises. Who doubts of them, is injurious to the most High; for, so he doth mistrust either his justice or his pow'r. Yet, as his promises are made with condition of beliefe and good life; who wants the condition, or wilfully and frequently breaks it, may well doubt of the performance; not as conceiving God injust or incapable; but looking on himselfe, as one perhaps, to whom the promise belongs not. That I be ra • of these doubting persons, seale, O my God, thy gracious promises to me, with the holie spirit of promise: and let this seale be knowne to me, by my strong beliefe of the word of truth, and sincere love to thee; and to others, by my Christian conversation.

6. Man promises God pleasant things, faith, love, feare, obedience; but who is wise must have a condition in his contracts with God; not of condigne retribution; for, he must not expect a recompence, by vertue of his best service; but of gracious contribution. He must vow with this condition, that God vouchsafe to assist him effectually, in the performance of his promises. Sith then, O God, I renew now my vowes to thee, extend thy graces unto me. I vow to keep thy Law, but give thou me understanding.
I resolve to begin or continue my course, in the way of thy commandements: yet upon condition, thou shalt teach me the way, enlarge my heart, and incline it to thy testimonies. So I expect from thee both the will and the deed, yea the knowledge to lead that will: and I know, thou wilt give them me, because thou hast promised them to those, who trust in thee, and call on thee, as by thy grace, I doe: beseeching thee by the merits of Christ, my wisdome, righteousnes and sanctification; to make me wise, righteous, holie.

div.head: His Buying.
div.p: 1 AS no man possesses all things; but the richest doth want manie commodities; so there is none, which be not forc'd to beg, borrow, or buy. And as few men give or lend so freely, as sell: So manie must buy what they want. I am in the number of these: I must buy manie things. But because there is often great deceit, both in the price and wares, I pray thee, my wise and just Lord, to blesse me with honestie and wisdome: that so I neither cheat, nor be cheated. Blesse likewise all men with the same honestie and wisdome: that none be willing, to defraud his brother; nor sillie, to be defrauded.

2. I must goe about my market, and there buy what I need. But can I find it there? No
certainly. Manie things are necessarie, which the Kingdome cannot afford. Truth, wisdome and understanding are not English commodities. They grow not here, but are high countrey-wares. They descend from heav'n, from the Father of lights, out of whose mouth come knowledge and understanding. From him then I must expect them: of him I will buy them, of whom waters, wine and milke may be bought without money and price. Liberall giver of good things, give me now wisdome and knowledge, that I understand righteousnes, judgement and equitie, yea ev'rie good path. Give me, I pray thee, thy spirit, thy holie spirit of truth, to guide my soule into all truth. So shall not error mislead me, nor ignorance and folie destroy me.

3. As goodnes, righteousnes and truth are the fruits of the spirit, and wisdome, knowledge and understanding, the gifts of the Father; they must be beg'd of him: yet we must doe, as well as pray; reade good books, heare the wise, imitate the godlie, and observe the course of the world: for, by these we gaine experience, and experience perfects knowledge. Lord, give me a wise heart, to seeke all opportunities of finding the truth, gaining knowledge, and exercising righteousnes.

4. Sith I am commanded to buy the truth, wisdome, instruction and understanding: I
must seek where, and by whom these are sold: and when I have found the place and persons, I must open my eares and purse to them: yea I will sell all worldlie goods, to buy the field, where Gods treasures are hid; those pious bookes and religious writings, which containe heavenlie riches, the right knowledge of God and man, and shew my duties towards both. My God, grant, I doe so. Grant, I frequent, honor, maintaine those blest persons; buy, reade, learn those sweet bookes, in whose companie and lecture, I gaine the riches of thy grace, purchase the pearle of thy Gospel.

5. What booke is this, with a frontispiece so glorious, a title so specious? I'le cast my eyes on it, reade it in manie places, to know whether it be as good as faire: for under this pleasant green grasse of curious invention, rich figures, and choice words, a serpent of error, a toad of uncleannes may lurke. Fie, fie: burne it to its Authors eternall shame: for, 'tis erroneous, or lascivious, or at the least, but a vaine and lying libell, a seditious pamphlet, a fomenter of division. My God, permit me not, to cast my money in such dangerous wares; buy the serpent, which might sting me to death: and let no more such men have the power to move a hand, in the composition of such infecting or injurious bookes: or if they
doe't, let none be so bewitcht, as to regard their damnable writings.

6. I must buy things necessarie or convenient, but not superfluous, unles it be some little and cheap toyes, to quiet my children.
