My poore brethren, those sick, naked, or hungrie members of Christ, shall crie loud against me, if my superfluities hinder me, to relieve them in their necessities. What I enjoy is not so absolutely mine, that I may doe with it, whatsoever I list. 'Twas given upon condition, to use it soberly for me; and di • creetly, for the good of others, and the glorie of my Master. My God, grant, I doe so. Let me be a faithfull steward of thy spirituall graces, corporall gifts, and earthlie goods, to the best advantage of me and my brethren, and to the cleerest manifestation of the glorie of thy mercies to me.

7. I must not buy that of anie, which he hath no good right to sell; such as his life, wife, truth, honestie and stolne goods: for, all these things cannot be sold and bought without manifest injustice. I must not likewise buy a thing, whose proprietie is controverted, its right question'd: for there may be likewise injustice to him, who knowes not the right: and certainly there is folie in the buyer, in adventuring his money for that, which the law
may adjudge to another, either by right or wrong. I will then forgoe this bargaine, for the evident or suspected injustice, or danger of it. My God, let me alwayes doe so, and let thy Name be blest in that, I doe now so; for the present justice and wisdome, thou giv'st me.

8. It is naught, it is naught, saith the buyer, but when he's gone, then he boasteth. Indeed, Sellers sin in exces of commendation of their goods, and Buyers in dispraise: but who is honest, will never doe so. If I am innocent of this exces, my thankes are due and giv'n to thee, my God and preserver. But if ever I have bought anie thing too cheap, of some young, sillie or drunken sellers; I beg both thy pardon and help. Remit my sin, and assist me to make satisfaction.

9. To say, I'le give no more, or I will not sell it under, is a frequent speech amongst us, a lie in manie mouths; yea, O horror! a lie confirm'd by a false oath, and often by manie, waited on by imprecations: for amongst us may be hourely observ'd that doubly sworne resolution, in the one, not to raise; in the other, not to abate the price: yet the buyer gives more, and the Seller takes lesse, then they have said and sworne. And is not this a great iniquitie? an intolerable folie? Iniquitie, against the God of truth: folie, against our soules, who thus are sold to Satan for a toy, to save or
gaine a small piece of money. 'Tis again folie against our reputation, which we lose by such proceedings: for, who will beleeve us, since we lie so familiarly, sweare so lightly, forsweare so wickedly? Forgive, O God, forgive and correct these sins in our Land. Give us wisdome, to preferre our reputation, soules and thy feare, to the gaine of the world. Let our bargaines be withou Oathes, yea without lies and idle words: that in all things we shew the truth and holines of our religion profession.

div.head: His Selling.
div.p: 1 HE must be verie rich or poore, who buyes alwayes, and never sels; a King, or a Beggar. Being (by Gods favor) neither of these, I must both buy and sell. And that I doe both these aright, direct me, gracious God, making me warie in Buying, and honest in selling.

2. Some things may be lawfully bought, whose sale is unlawfull. Such are truth, honestie, which being once obtain'd freely of God, and dearly bought of men, in their speeches, bookes and actions, must not be sold againe: sith no earthlie treasure, worldlie honors, or carnall voluptie may be a price for them. O then what fooles are they, who sell their honestie, yea the truth for a toy, for a vain
profit or credit! How mad those Ministers, who for a Church-living, or for one better then the first, or to please some great men, or to be popular, and have the love of an ignorant multitude, betray the truth unto error, and make it serve their wicked ends, for the oppression of the just, and exaltation of wicked persons! Thou God of truth, suffer me not to goe with them in the way of Kain, run greedily after the error of Balaam, for reward, and perish in the contradiction of Core. If yet I have been one of them, O pardon and convert; pardon my sin, convert my heart, and fill it with the love of truth, and with griefe to have betray'd it. Convert likewise all those, who for their advantage have mens persons in admiration. And if they be past conversion, purge our feasts, from all those black spots; our aire, from those thick clouds; our heaven, from such wandring-stars; our field, from those dead trees. Let truth and honestie revive; then let peace and plentie succeed.

3. I must not sell what is not mine, and so I must not sell my selfe: for, I am Gods by creation, and Christs by redemption. Then God forbid, that I sell his creature to sin, and Christs purchace unto Satan. My God, keep thy proprietie in me. Sweet Jesu, preserve thy free man. O let me live as it becomes a creature so excellent, a man so highly priz'd; that the bloud of Gods Son must be my onely fit ransome.

4. Stolne goods being not mine, I must not sell, but restore them, with full satisfaction, for the dammage, I have caus'd their owner; griefe, for the sin committed against God; resolution, to forbeare all thefts and deceits. Give me this griefe, O Lord; help me to make satisfaction; breed, fortifie, continue the resolution, to walke uprightly before thee and men. So shall I walke surely from outward feares, inward remorse.

5. Who sells, perverts justice, for gaine, hope, favor, or hatred, sells all the right, he hath in his goods, life, and soule: for certainly, injust Judges forfeit all these. O then let me not, gracious God, be one of them, who justifie the wicked for reward, and condemne the poore innocent! If I undertake to decide anie difference between friends; let me, O God, doe it with such integritie; that my sentence please thee and them. Let all our Magistrates doe so. Let them all judge with just judgement, without respect of persons and their gifts; of love unto their friends; of feare of the wicked; of favor of the great; of the cries and prayers of their wives and children. Let them die rather then pervert the judgement of the stranger, fatherles, widow, poore: yet let not their pitie to these countenance them in a wrong cause. Give them the knowledge of thy Law, and of that of the Land; that they keep themselves farre from false matters, and least
through ignorance they rob or slay the innocent; assist, maintaine, justifie the wicked.

6. To sell ill wares for good, and commend them above their worth, are common, yet great sins, I will not then follow a multitude to do these evil things. I'le cheat no man in the qualitie of my wares. I will not say, that they are the best in England, or that the world hath none so good: for, this commendation shewes too great levitie and vanitie in manie men. Besides, either it is not true; or if true, 'tis not so to me, who know not the goodnes of the wares, I postpose to mine. To save then my credit, and not staine my conscience, keep me, O Lord, from all foolish and false commendations of anie thing, I sell or make: and permit me not to make or sell that, which be unfit and unlawfull.

7. False or divers weights and measures are abominable to God; & so are all unreasonable rates. If then I have anie just interest in him, and will be inwardly what I would appeare outwardly; I must be verie just in my weights, measures, rates. Yet just I cannot be, being the injust issue of thee • ish Adam, who stole the fruit prohibited, unles the just God make me just. To him therefore I call, for an honest and upright heart. O God, be not deafe at my call, but heare it speedily, and make me such, as thou command'st, I be.

8. Who is oblig'd to give bountifully, and lend freely unto the poore, may well afford him good bargaines. This then shall have my wares as cheap, as I can let them goe. The rich God pitie him and me, give us his all-sufficient grace, a frequent sense of his eternall love, thankfull, contented hearts in his divers visitations, pure affections in his service, religious words, holie conversation.

div.head: His Lending and Borrowing.
div.p: 1 WHat we call almes is by God term'd lending, because he renders it, if given for his sake, yea with great usurie: but with us lending is to let other men have the use of some things for a time, which after it, they must render in the same kind, if they be money, graines, liquors, or the like: or the same as they were, if they be vessels, clothes, horses, weapons, &c. Whatsoever my neighbour needs, make me, O God, as willing to lend him, if I can, as be is to borrow of me.

2. Mutuall love is much commanded, therefore, O Lord, let me sincerely love all men, and let them beare me the like love: then if they need those goods, which I can spare, let them command them as their owne, then returne them to me: and let them be likewise readie to doe me the like turnes, when occasion shall serve.

3. I must neither give, nor lend that, which brings harme unto my neighbour. I must not give strong drinkes to the drunkard, nor lend weapons to the furious, nor money unto the wrangler: for, the first will drowne his reason; the second beat, or kill his foes, perhaps his friends; and the third find so manie suits, that he'le undoe both himselfe and others. Teach me, O God, to give and lend what may profit the borrower, and cause dammage unto no man.

4. The wicked borrowes and payes not againe, unles it be with cursings, railings and disgrace: then I'le lend him nothing, but what I may well give: for, when Christ commands me, to turne not away from him, who will borrow of me, I thinke, he meanes to commend pitie to the poore, and forbids not to beware of cheaters. Whatsoever it be, I will both lend and give, and help my neighbour in that sort, that I my selfe fall not into such povertie, as compell me either to beg, or use deceit, to find reliefe in want. Give me, O Lord, a kind heart to all men, yet withall so prudent, that my kindnes deceive me not, and hinder me to provide both for me and mine, before to look unto others.

5. If I may lend unto my friend, I may be suretie for him, and so prove my selfe an honest man. I will freely give that, which I would gladly take, lend what I would borrow,
and passe my word for him, from whom I would expect that kindnes, were I in anie want. Yet if I have a wife or child, I will hardly be bound for anie man, unles I know by probable reasons, he will not forget my friendship, and leave me to discharge his debt, and repent for my good office. Lord, let no man be of so unthankful mind towards me, as to leave me in the danger, when I shall be suretie for him; but give him will and meanes to pay well what he owes, love me for my friendship, and thanke thee for thy help, in providing him such a friend.

6. A sinner will overthrow the good estate of his suretie; then I will not be taken with the words of my mouth for one. I will never be bound for him, who reckons the thing lent as found, puts them to trouble, who help him, and studies to defraud his friend. I had rather lend him, then be oblig'd for him: for in lending I may have some hope of my goods; but being bound, I shall daily feare to pay that, which he will or cannot discharge: and is not hope of good preferable to fear of ill? Although, O Lord, I be a sinfull man, yet let not sinners (I pray thee) draw me into such suretiship, as may make me wise by my losse; and churlish, because I was kind.

7. I must borrow money, but can I render it againe? If I cannot, I'le never borrow it, for, that were meere deceit. I will rather work
hard, then commit such base thing; or I will tell my friends how the case stands with me, and pray them to venture the summe I need, if so be I can n'ere pay them, in doing faithfully what industrie can teach a man. But if my state is good, and I may easily pay what I meane to borrow, then I'le doe it boldly, and discharge the whole debt, at the appointed time. So, Lord, grant me to doe, and blesse still thy servant with upright intentions, and good meanes to shew them, in paying all my debts.

div.head: His Consulting.
div.p: 1 AS all men are not wise, nor the wisest knowes all: so they must consult each other, and 'tis a mark of a profound folie, not of a hie wisdome, to scorne the counsell of others. Let not, O God, thy servant be thus markt, but make me so discreetly wise; that I trust not in my wisdome, but admit willingly the prudent counsels of the wise.

2. We must consult with those, who have the greatest skill in the things, we doubt and propound: for, best is alwayes the cheapest: and in consultations we must preferre the most necessarie affaires. Sith then the soule is before the bodie in dignitie, the bodie before earthlie goods, we must consult about them in order,
and with those men, who excell in the profession of that, concerning which we seek information. Let me, O God, esteem things, as they are, and studie their preservation and perfection; and for this end, let me seek and follow the counsell of the most skilfull, in spirituall matters, corporall state, worldlie affaires.

3. The greatest Clerkes are not alwaies the most honest: we must therefore in our consultations seek them, who have learning and honestie; yea we should doe wisely, to consider their experience: for, one may be both learned and honest, who yet for want of due and long practice may erre, and so deceive. Lord, direct me to such, in my great occasions: and so be thou with them, that they erre not in their counsels.

4. Who is not wise, must have wise counsellers: yet who chuses such, must be wise; and wiser, who followes their prudent directions. If thou hast not, O Lord, blest me with strong reason, to order my affaires, give me judgement enough, to be rul'd by the wise.

5. The way of a foole is right in his owne eyes: but who hearkneth unto counsell is wise. That I be not foolish, but wise, permit me not, O Lord, to despise wisdome and instruction, but to heare willingly those men, whose knowledge excells mine.

6. Without counsell purposes are disappointed: for, who resolves to doe, must advise
on the meanes to effect his resolution: and as he must be slow in the resolution, so celeritie is requir'd in the execution: for, manie things are at first dasht, because they want judicious determination; and stopt, in their progres, because they are carried on but slowly. Lord, make me wise, in the discussion of affaires: and diligent, in the execution.

7. He is not wise, who consults with his enemie: then what are they, who aske counsell of prognosticators, fortune-tellers, conjurers, Devils? Desperat fooles: men, who run head-long into hell. Purge, O God, purge thy Church from rebellious children, who take counsell, but not of thee: from all idolatrous persons, who frequently goe to inquire of Baal-zebub, as if there were no God in Israel: and if ever Satan hath so much prevail'd against me, as to persuade me to consult with him or his servants; or to beg or expect anie good thing from him or them: pardon me, I pray thee, this grievous transgression, and idolatrous rebellion: and let me never more fall into this great sin of witchcraft.

8. God is wonderfull in counsell, excellent in working. Of him then I will take advise, who doth informe the mind, enflame the will, and move the hands and outward lims. I'le seek, what rule his Law gives me, in this present and urgent occasion, and will pray him,
to let me conceive it aright, and fully follow it. My God, denie me not this help. My chiefe co •
fidence is in thy counsell, for guide; and in thy strength for performance. O then let thy testimonies be m • delight and counsellers.

9. Is Christ the Counseller? Then Christians should consult with him, at least in matters of Christianitie. Thus they should not destroy one another, by their barbarou • wars: for, he's likewise the Prince of Peace, Prince, who delights in holie union. O Christ how art thou despis'd amongst us! how dishonour'd by us, persons full of iniquitie, who yet call, or seem • call on thy name! O open now our ears to thy counsels and our hearts to thy feare: that deciding by thee, by the rules of justice and love, which thou left us, e •
present contentions, thou maist againe reigne among •• us.

div.head: His Counselling.
div.p:
1 EV'rie man would be a counseller, yet few are fit for the office, sith it requires greater wisdome and honestie, then manie imagine: for, who gives his advice without knowledge, is a presumptuous foole: and who gives it against or without honestie, is but a wicked counseller, a right Achitophel, whom counsell shall destroy. If then I undertake to counsell others, I must see, whether my wisdome
and honestie are sufficient. If they be not, Lord, make them such, and if they be, continue, augment them.

2. As in materiall gifts, so in counsels discretion is requir'd: for, we must consider the nature of the thing and counsell, and qualities of the giver and receiver: otherwise both gift and counsell should often lose their grace, and the giver and counseller their thankes. Make me, O God, discreet in all affaires, that I be not onely a good Christian, and so belov'd of thee; but also a most compleat man, and so in good reputation 'mongst men.

3. To counsell Kings or great men before intreatie, is reputed temeritie: and to advise our betters in wisdome, is imputed to vanitie: and it is likewise vanitie to bestow our counsels on the foole and scorner, to whom they doe no good: yet in urgent affaires, it is pietie and humanitie to admonish great men. So when counsell is perished from the prudent, the simple may whisper a word: and who sees anie hope in a foole, or scorner, may then take opportunitie, to give them instruction. O that no man be discourag'd to advise me, nor I remisse or negligent, to bestow my counsels, when there is need of them. Make, O God, all men such, as I desire to be. Let no greatnes, wisdome, folie hinder the communion of Saints, nor
worldlie respects extinguish that divine love, which should make us all help one another, as members of the same bodie.

4. I know, Prudence is the life of Statesmen, and Policie their chiefe studie: yet when Prudence is without religion, Subtilitie without simplicitie, Policie without honestie; there but mischiefe is intended, and swift ruine drawne on That Christian Kingdomes avoid it, give them, O Lord, religious Counsellers, Christian Rulers, and pious Magistrates.
5. Here is one, who askes my counsell, and because I must not, nor will deceive him, inspire me, gracious God, what directions I shall give him, and let him have thy grace, to follow them.

6. Is not this man come to tempt me, with his subtile questions? Doth he aske my advice, for direction, or propound this, for the di • coverie of my capacitie, that he publish my ignorance, or bring me into some danger. If he hath such base ends, assist me, O Christ, the wisdome of God, who wast often thus tempted for my sake. Make me capable to satisfie him; and if he comes deceitfully, shew him his sin, that he repent: if in simplicitie, speake thou by me what may instruct, or comfort him.

div.head: His Praising.
div.p: 1 GRace and Vertue, God and good men doe challenge praise. As then there is no man, who be not indebted to God for all, he is, and for all, he enjoyes: so he must receive praise of all Adams issue. As I am one of them, I acknowledge, O God, my noble being from thy grace. By thy onelie will and pleasure I am a man, whose nature excells all other visible creatures, a man, for whose service, they all seem to be made. I owe thee my education, health, strength, friends, case, honors, comforts, long life. Thou maist then command all, as thy tenants at will; and Lord, make me willing to spend them all in thy service.

2. Praise is comelie for the upright, and the righteous must praise the Lord. I am not upright, but crooked; not righteous, but injust: Yet I will praise thee, O my God, with all my heart, and glorifie thy Name for evermore. My mouth shall be fill'd with thy praise, and with thy honor all day long: for, great is thy mercie to me, excellent thy goodnes, and eternall thy love. Let then mine to thee be endles, and my gratitude perpetuall.

3. After God hath receiv'd his praise, vertuous persons must have their due, and praise is due unto vertue, as a reward unto merit, and as a help to greater perfection. I will then praise
vertue, where I see it, thus to encourage the partie, to proceed and excell in generous, pious actions. Yea I will glorifie the Lord, for the prudence, temperance, fortitude, justice, truth, religion, I shall observe in anie man. That I may have frequent and ample subjects to praise thee, in thy free gifts to men, increase them, liberall Giver, where they are alreadie bestow'd; and poure them, where they are not yet. Let now all men be truly men; wise, just, courteous: and let all Christians be Christians; meeke, humble, loving, faithfull and religious.

4. As we may and must praise well deserving persons, so we ought to beware to commend the other, vicious and evill men: yea we must be discreet, in commending the first; least our commendations exceed their dignitie, and so doe degenerat into adulation. Let me not, I pray thee, O Lord, accept anie mans person, neither let me give flattering titles unto men; least thou shouldst soone take me away. Let not my lips flatter; least thou shouldst cut them off.

5. Who praises the wicked is a forsaker of the Law; for, the Law condemnes him: is guiltie of his sins, which his false praise foments: and therefore shall share in his plagues. Lord, let me not justifie him, whom I ought rather to condemne: and let no man approve in me anie sinfull designes, vicious actions, or evill words: thus to
nurse me in sin, feed me with corrupt meat. Let none spread a net before his neighbours feet, with a flattering mouth, which workes ruine.

6. Who loves the praise of men, more then the praise of God, may be askt, how he can beleeve? For so Christ askt the Jewes, which receiv'd honor, one of another, and sought not the honor, which comes from God onely. And indeed, how can he beleeve, he loves God, when he seeks not Gods glorie, but mans praise? How can he beleeve, that honor comes onely from God, when he chiefly expects it from some men? O how manie are deceiv'd by mistakes! How manie forgoe an eternall honor, for a temporall praise! Lord, permit me not to be one of them: but be, be thou my praise. Be thou the object of my good actions, and let not my heart be so vaine, as to delight in mens commendations.

7. As the fining pot for silver, and the surnace for gold; so is man to his praise: for, as those metals are try'd in the pot and furnace; so is man knowne by praise; or so should a man trie and refine his praise: for, first, when we are prais'd, it appeares what we are, vaine or serious; emptie, or full; vertuous in truth, or shew: and secondly, as the furnace doth refine gold; so should a man his praise. He must trie, whether it be right, and if such, refine it, make i • finer, by his free acknowledgement,
that the good praise in him is a meere gift of God, to whom therefore he returnes all the praise, retaining none unto himselfe. Make me ever doe so, O God, from whom all good things flow. Let me reject false praise, and present thee all true commendations of thy graces in me, and give thee the glorie of them.

8. This person commends me highly. He calls me faire, wittie, wise, vertuous, or gracious: but doth he speak truly? If he doth not, I will fairely tell him, he mistakes me: but if he doth, I will and doe speak thus to God. My God, these epithets are thine: for, my beautie is given me by thee: thou art the maker of my wit, my wisdome comes from thee, my vertues are thy gifts, by thee I am gracious. Thou art then my beautie, wit, wisdome, vertue, grace; and so the faire, wise, vertuous, gracious God; and as such I will proclaime thee, before this person and all men. Let him and them acknowledge thee for such, and as such love and adore thee.

9. Mans selfe praise is a great dispraise; because it shewes such vanitie in the heart of that man, who speakes of his owne worth, that children and fooles laugh at him. The wisdome of heaven gives us no such lesson. Let another man praise thee, and not thine owne mouth; a stranger, and not thine owne lips. Let our part be to act nobly, wisely, religiously;
and if any man undertakes, to publish our vertues, that's well: if not, let us be silent of our perfections: for not he, who commends himselfe, or is commended by others, is approv'd; but whom the Lord commends Lord, make me so perfect, that thou maist approve me; so pure and religious, that thou maist commend me; so humble in mine owne conceit, that thou maist exalt me.

div.head: His Reproving.
div.p: 1 AS Praise is due unto vertue; so vice and sin challenge Reproofe: and as vice is naturall, and sin a generall contagion; so must correction be. There is no man here so vertuous, no person so gracious, which may not be reprov'd: and the more one is such, the more vertue and grace he hath, the more welcome is correction to him: for, the prudent regards reproofe. Lord, make me thus prudent. Let me not refuse instruction, least povertie and shame be my portion; but grant, that I regard reproofe, that so I be honour'd, and the fitter to honor thee.

2. Correction is a friends dutie, and reproofe, the honest mans right: for, 'tis then an excellent oile, when it proceeds from righteous lips. Thou shalt, saith God, rebuke thy neighbour, and not suffer sin upon him;
and by Christs rules, we ought to rebuke our brother. My God, give me honest neighbours, loving brethren to rebuke me, and make me such to them: and let our eares heare the reproofe of life, that our soules get understanding.

3. As God is mans best friend: so is reproofe the best of all, which comes immediatly from him. Wise then is he, who heares it willingly: happie is he, who turnes at Gods reproofe. All men erre, and must be recall'd, and 'tis a great honor, to be recall'd, redrest by God. I take it thus, O Lord, and therefore thanke thee now, for all thy past reproofes, and beseech thee to continue, both thy outward and inward calls: but, gracious God, rebuke me not in thy anger, chasten me not in thy hot displeasure. O let love dictat thy reproofes, and correct me in gentlenes, yet with efficacie.

4. Who is willing to give, not to receive reproofe, shewes ignorance or pride: ignorance of th' excellence of reproofe; pride, in too high conceit of his unblamable vertues. He's a prosperous lover, if yet he truly loves others, who thus hates his owne soule; and he hates her, who refuses reproofe: for, he erres from the way of life. Lord, keep me in this way. Make me willing to give, but more to receive correction, and to this end, deliver me from pride and ignorance.

5. As an ornament of fine gold, so is a wise reprover to an obedient eare. Indeed to make eares obedient, the reproofe must be wise: wise in the consideration of the qualities, humors and interests of persons, who give and receive correction: in the observation of the nature, circumstances, motives of the offence: in th' election of time, place and words fit for that pious office; and so in the demonstration of a zealous and loving heart moving to it. O that all men should consider these things! so their rebukes should not be offensive; reproofe should not be call'd reproach; correction should confirme, not break their amitie; instruction should convert, not obdurat the erring hearts. That all men be so, assist them, O Lord; blesse Rebukers with discretion and gentlenes; and the Reprov'd with humble hearts, obedient eares. Let not the first use reproach for rebuke: nor the second harden their necks against frequent reproofes, least suddenly they be destroy'd, yea without remedie.

6. This person hath now done or spoken what deserves reproofe, and as I love my God and him, I ought to rebuke him: But that I doe it not in vaine, inspire my mind, O God, direct my tongue, open his eares, prepare his heart; that my discreet and loving reproofe be receiv'd with profit.

7. Listen, my soule: here is one, who begins
the office of a friend, he reproves thee. Consider not therefore, whether he be truly thy friend or foe; or whether love, anger or vanitie make him speak thus: but see, whether he speakes the truth, and so receive his words, and in this esteem him a friend. If his rebuke be false, and spoken in reproach, and so to thy disgrace; let thy patience declare it such, rather then thy clamors. My God, I desire to doe so, and if thou wilt help me, I shall finely doe so. O then denie me not thy grace: least I lose this faire occasion, either for correction of some vice or error; or for triall of fortitude.

div.head: His Praying and being Pray'd.
div.p:
1 THere is no man so great and rich, which may be long without the help of the little and poore: and as all things are not bought with money, nor done for it: pray'rs are necessarie, not onely in Religion, but in Conversation. 'Tis then a generall dutie, to pray both God and men, and so to be highly esteem'd: for, as all men have their whole dependence on God, and a certaine, one upon the other; so he is impious and foolish, who refuses to pray his Maker and brother. I'le not then refuse it, but in all things will call on thee, my God, and sometimes on my like. Heare then me,
when I call, and let not men be deafe to my just petitions.

2. Pray'rs of man to God are holie, excellent and pow'rfull, if truly good. But to be good, they must have good Conditions or Qualities, and be made by a soule well dispos'd. This must beSee my Catechisme, Q • esti •• 966. to 10 • 7. Wise, Meek, Faithfull, Constant, Inquisitive, Humble, Penitent, Loving, Devout, Attentive, Thankfull, Carefull: and the Prayer it selfe must beSee the Question 1027. to 1052. Intelligible, Grave, True, Just, Religious, Frequent, Short and Charitable. As all these are most difficult, yet verie requisit, who intends to pray God, shall doe wisely, to beg them first of him. My intention then being such, I pray thee, Lord, so to dispose my mind, so to order my Pray'rs: that nothing be amisse in either of these two. Let them be both such, as thou lov'st: or if not altogether such, let thy love supplie all their wants, and cover all their faults.

3. How excellent is man? how glorious his nature? sith God himselfe vouchsafes to pray and court him. Nay rather, how loving is that all-sufficient God, to wooe that sinfull wretch, for his owne advantage? Dost thou, my Lord, dost thou indeed pray me daily by thy selfe and servants, to be reconcil'd unto thee, give thee my heart, cease to doe ill, learne to doe well, walke in thy wayes, beleeve in thee, embrace and kisse thy Son? Then I
will grant thy petition, yea heartily thanke thee, for requiring such things of me. I grieve to have kept thy request so long without answer; and that I never use thee so, grant me the will and strength, to doe what thou command'st, forbeare what thou forbid'st.

4. Who will have good succes in his requests to men, must observe manie things; himselfe, the partie whom he prayes, the subject of his petition in relation to both, the times and places fit for it: so hard is man to man, that nature is become too short in some, to teach them th' art of persuasion. If I have anie thing to require of others, and it be just in it selfe, convenient to me, and easie to them; move their hearts, O God, to grant it: and if they want my honest and possible help, let me willingly afford it, at the first intreatie.

5. This man hath some request to me of a thing, I know, and may doe. I will therefore prevent his pray'r, and grant before he askes; thus to comfort his heart, and make it thankfull to thee, gracious God, for thy mercios to him by me. O make all men thus willing to doe good; thus readie to prevent a blush in the face of a suppliant, who would often more gladly buy, then beg favors.

6. I cannot grant this petition, for want of meanes, and must not this other, because it is not just. Yet I will doe something for the petitioners, give good words to the first, honest
counsell to the second. Help them both, gracious God: the first with other friends, more able to help him then I; and the second with repentance, that he grieve for his injustice, and willingly desist from it.

7. Manie things are lawfull, which are not expedient. So is this mans request. It is just, but not convenient: 'tis honest, but not safe. I must then reject it, for its inconvenience or danger: and that my deniall offend him not, I pray thee, my good Lord, so to dispose his heart; that he intertaine no ill thoughts of me.

8. There is an evident danger, in granting or countenancing this petition: yet it is so just and necessarie, that I am resolv'd to doe it. It is to save an honest man, to help my friend or bloud opprest by injustice, to defend my countrie, to maintaine the glorie of God, and the right of his Church: and who will not adventure much for such, yea goods and life, if need requires? I'le trie, what I can doe in this, and that my labor be not vaine, assist me, Lord, in this designe. Give me wisdome and fortitude in the carriage of this affaire, which I commend unto thy speciall providence.

div.head: His Conversation, Solitude, and Meditation.
div.p: 1 MAn is a sociable creature, delighting much in companies, and seeking acquaintance. His wise Maker knew his disposition, and saw, it was not good, that man should be alone. I can therefore but dislike those, who flie from companies to live amongst wild beasts; or (though they dwell in great cities) have no familiaritie with men; but passe their lives with images, bookes and skuls, unles it be once or twice everie week. Indeed they follow their nature, in frequenting their like: for, as those men are dead to generous actions; so they doe wittily (if not well) to sort themselves with dead mens workes and bones. Let me not, O good God, burie my selfe alive, spending my time in idlenes, and feeding my melancholick humors; but grant me wit to chuse my time, both to converse, and be alone.

2. Some say, Wise men can never be alone: for, if they want men, they have bookes; and if these faile, their minds are free to walke with the angels, and talke with God himselfe. This may be true for a short time, but it cannot last long. Our soules are here ty'd by a
string, which quickly puls them downe. The cares of the bodie, and the thoughts of the world make us often in a moment fall downe againe from the highest heaven. Then we may and must give attendance to the flesh, visit our friends, and deale with men; th • n flie up againe, if we can. O Lord, grant I doe so, dealing by turnes with thee and men, now pleasing the mind with sweet meditations, and then feeding the flesh with what she justly doth require.

3. We must live in our solitude, as if we were in companie, and never thinke, we may then sin, because no man sees us: for, who made man, and can save or damne him, hath alwayes his eyes upon us, yea within us, beholding our actions, and weighing our imaginations. Let me, O God, set thee alwayes before me, and be thou still at my right hand, to guide me aright in this world.

4. It is harder to live with men, then manie thinke. In our chambers we may live as we list, if so be't, we doe well: but abroad we must conforme our selves to the divers humors of men: with those who weep, we must mourne, and with them who laugh, be merrie. In all lawfull actions, we must doe as the rest; yet we may trie, to doe better, then they. So by imitation, we doe please them; and by doing better, we reforme in them what's amisse.
Good Lord, teach me so to behave my selfe with men, that better then I teach me good, and I may convert those, who are worse then my selfe.

5. In our conversation we must shew respect unto our betters, gentlenes to our inferiors, and courteous freedome to our like: reward our friends with mutuall love, and so deale with our enemies, that we avoid their snares, and reconcile their minds. Friends may be lost, and enemies won; we must therefore be neither too free with the first, nor too severe with the second. Let those, who in our presence doe well, receive our praise and encouragements, and the others our discreet reproofe and gentle dissuasion. Grant, my good Lord, that I observe all these in my conversation. Suffer me not to make other mens sins mine owne, in winking at them, approving them, or not reproving them. Let me seeke thy glorie in all things, and teach all men thy feare.

6. The Wisdome of God commends us the prudence of Serpents, and the simplicitie of Doves: as these being most requisit in our conversation. Give me these, O Christ my Wisdome: give me a prudent wit, to looke well to my wayes, fore-see the evill, and hide my selfe: and harmles, least I injure others.

7. The world is like the sea, full of storms, rocks and sands; and so ought to be shun'd:
yet as the sea hath some calme 'twixt the stormes, and manie places free to the navigation; so the world is not alwayes, and everie where perillous. We may then deale with it as we doe with the sea; saile in the calme, and land when we see the weather boisterous; converse with men, when they are quiet and sober: then retire to our owne dwellings, when their passions rage against their reason. There in our meditations, we shall by the windowes of quick apprehension see worldlings tossed to and fro, as a small boat in a tempestuous sea. O Lord, teach me to walke upon the waters of this world, when time doth serve; and take me thy selfe by the hand, when the wind is too strong, and I begin to sinke.

8. The world is either the whole universe of heav'n and earth with their creatures, or the whole mankind. Being taken in the first sence we cannot flie from it, and in the second we must not: unles we (Timon-like) hate our semblable, as being all naught, whereas often none's worse then we. Were all men led with the same sp'rit as manie black minds are, then farewell all societie. Let me not, Lord, hate those whom thou hast made; forsake my like, shun men as snakes, yet lurke in holes like a serpent.

9. The world is againe either that, which God being in Christ, hath reconciled to himselfe;
or that which cannot receive the spirit of truth. The first is the Church of God, and the second the assemblie of the wicked, infidels and reprobate. We must strive to live in the first, least we be starv'd; for 'tis our Bethlehem (the house of bread) where Christ is born to us; the pasture, where God feeds his sheep; and the fortres, where he keeps them. The other we must depart from, if we are in; and come not neere, if we are out: for, they sit in darknes and the shadow of death. Keep me, O God, within the bosome of thy Church, and let me never walke in the counsell of the ungodlie, stand in the way of sinners, nor sit in the seat of the scornfull.

10. Who walkes with wise men, shall be wise: for, good is communicative. The Sun cannot keep his light to himself, nor wise men their wisdome. They will impart me some; yea enough to see mine owne wayes. Good men will teach me goodnes; the mercifull, pitie; the upright, true dealing; the harmles, innocence; the modest, chastitie; the humble, lowlines; the courteous, affabilitie; the sober, temperance; the prudent, discretion; the patient, fortitude; the constant, stabilitie; the thankfull, gratitude; the sad, gravitie; the merrie, cheerfulnes. Let me, O God, converse with such, as can make me good by counsels, and better by their owne examples: and when I am with
them, make my mind docible, to learne easily their precepts; open mine eyes, to marke their behaviour; and strengthen me, to imitate their lives.

11. A companion of fooles shall be destroy'd: who toucheth pitch shall be defil'd therewith; and who hath fellowship with a proud man, shall be like unto him: for, ill manners are as the contagion, infecting their neighbours. The proud man doth poison our minds with loftines, the glutton with greedines, the covetous with avarice, the voluptuous with wantonnes, the prodigall with lavishnes, the cheater with deceits, the theefe with pilfering, the wrangler with debate, the cholerick with anger, the cruell with violence, the oppressor with extortion, the drunkard with quaffing, the impudent with boldnes, the obstinat with wilfulnes, and the sluggard with idlenes. Let me not, Lord, converse with such, as can make me worse then I am, by ill examples and counsels; or if I need to be with them, let not their instructions enter into my heart, nor their behaviour please my eyes; but grant, that loving their persons, I hate their ill manners.

12. A little leaven leaveneth the whole lump. St. Paul thought, an incestuous person and a fornicator call'd a brother might infect the Church of Corinth. Indeed one scabbed sheep spoiles the whole flock. So then it were
better for us to shut our selves in a caverne, then to be familiars with such, as the Apostle wishes us to forbeare, fornicators, covetous, idolaters, railers, drunkards, extortioners. Keep me, good Lord, from such mens companies, who drinke sin like water, devise mischiefe upon their beds, and whose bowes are bent, and their arrowes readie upon the string, to shoot privily at the upright in heart. Let them not wind themselves in my good opinion, and by their words, smoother then butter and softer then oyle, persuade me to like their doings.

13. Ill companies are worse then pestilence: for, they infect the mind, when contagion doth poison but the bloud. Yet as we may with a cordiall come often neere the plague, without receiving infection; yea drink poison it selfe without harme, after we have taken an antidote: so when our minds are well resolv'd on a religious course, armed with pray'r, and led with good meaning, we may safely converse with ungodly persons; for, we must not beleeve, that Paul forbids it so strictly as some doe imagine: for, he would not the Corinthians should think, that he gave them precepts, to forbeare the companie of the fornicators of this world; for then he knew, there were so manie fornicators, covetous, &c. that they must goe out of the world; but he forbad their acquaintance with them of the Church,
who were such. Now if his reason was good then, why not now? since all men live with so little regard of their Christian calling, that he must goe out of the world, who is afraid to keep companie with those, of whom holie Paul speaks. For, which of us can say now; Who can accuse me of fornication, or covetousnes, or idolatrie, or railing, or drunkennes, or extortion? Therefore we must in this time imitate the charitable Samaritan, when we find in our way anie man wounded in the soule; not passe by him, as the Priest did, but goe to him, and bind his wounds, stay his ill course by good examples and counsels; poure in oyle and wine of sweet and comfortable words; put him on our owne beast, shew him the ground of our owne hope concerning the remission of our sins, and the salvation of our soules; and bring him to the Inne, the holie Church of God. O gracious Redeemer, who cam'st to seeke out the lost sheep, and call sinners to repentance; give me a heart sensible of my brethrens offences against thy majestie; a willing mind, to withdraw them from sin; a holie behaviour and gracefull utterance, to persuade them with deeds and words to lead a better life: and while I shall be thus imploy'd, preserve me from their infection; and grant, my remedies have more vertue, then their disease.

14. Should healthie men flie from the sick,
what help could they find to heale them? And should good men shun ill persons, how could they become good? Was not Christ conversant and eating with sinners? and hath he not and his Apostles exhorted us in manie places, so to let our lights shine before men, and be so holie in all manner of conversation, in the midst of a crooked nation, that God be glorifi'd, and sinners converted to him? Then St. Pauls prohibition, to eat with fornicators, &c. must be understood either in the Sacrament, or with strangers to us, but not of our kindred, masters, neighbours and friends: for, with these we may keep acquaintance, and must strive by faire meanes, to bring them into the right way, when they are gone astray. Lord Jesus, the great Shepherd of the sheep! make me (I beseech thee) so perfect in all good workes, that men be turn'd by my example from their manifold sins, to serve thee in holines and righteousnes all the dayes of their life.

15. Tares grow with the wheat till harvest, ill and good men live together till death: but then the wheat is gathered into the barne, the faithfull soules carried into Abrahams bosome; whilst tares are burnt, and the wicked buried in hell. From the dayes of Cain to the end of the world, the Church of God hath sheep and goats; but then they shall be separated.
In the meane time, let the sheep keep their innocent nature, and the wheat retaine its goodnes, waiting patiently for the time, the Lord hath appointed for their separation. I hope, O Lord, that I am a sheep of thy flocke, and an eare of corne in thy field; then let not tares hinder my growth, nor goats alter my condition.

16. To be good with good men is no true token of goodnes; but to be such with the wicked is a witnes of sound vertue; and to convert them from their lewd wayes to godlines, is an act so glorious in Gods eyes, that he will make such persons shine like the lights of the firmament, and be call'd great in his Kingdome. Good Lord, make me good at all times and in all companies; but double my goodnes, and blow my zeale, when I converse with evill men; that thou speaking by me, and working both in me and them, their soules be brought from a sinfull to a gracious estate.

17. Amongst all the wicked, whose conversation we must shun, hereticks are the first, because their false doctrine may quickly poison us, unles our faith be well grounded, and our hope strong. We may yet converse with them, when we doe see anie likenes, to draw them from their heresie. But if their subtilitie be greater then our learning, we must beware to deale with them. As for those, who have been
warn'd by lawfull superiors, yet persist in error, and those arch-hereticks, who broach, or by profession teach heresies, we must never receive them in our houses nor so much as give them the salutation of the day; least we be partak • rs of their ill deeds. We have in this Gods owne prohibition, and two great mens examples, Christs beloved Disciple, and Polycarpus his Martyr. The first would not wash himselfe in the bath, wherein Cerinthus was, nor the second salute Marcion. O thou the God of truth! let me never frequent such men; but if by chance I meet them in my way, let me looke upon them, as on the Devils eldest sons, and thy greatest enemies: and if they be not past amendment, convert them, Lord, I beseech thee; that thy Church be without error in faith, and her members holie in all conversation.

18. As we must gladly frequent those, whose words and actions teach us those vertues, we want: so we must be carefull to avoid those, who are stain'd with those vices, and guiltie of those sins, to which we are chiefly inclin'd: least so we be confirm'd in them. I am sicke, O God, I am sicke, but sicke spiritually; then teach me those outward Physicians, which may give me good remedies by their Christian instructions and conversation; and worke thou powerfully with them, opening my mind, moving my heart, to
conceive, beleeve and practise those precious things, I shall heare of them, see in them: and let me never frequent those, who by their contagion should augment my disease.

19. Tale-bearers and Flatterers ought to be shun'd, as the enemies of all men: the first of the absent, the last of the present. They are both base, injurious, deceit • ull. Permit me not, O God, to countenance such vile persons, much lesse, to become one of them. Let me hate false or idle reports, and beware of adulation.

20. He is dead in the world, who lives but to himselfe. Solitude is for certaine times commendable, and meditation praise-worthie, when just action challenges not our time. But to be alone, when we should be in companie, and meditate in private, when we should act in publick, is much fitter for a heathen Timon, or a Roman Frier, then for a true servant of Christ. We should imitate our Master, pray and preach by turnes, meditate by night, teach by day. O Christ! let me follow thee in those things, thou didst here as a holie man. Let me by pray'r strengthen my soule, and by meditation feed her oft: then grant, I teach thy statutes to the unlearned, thy judgements unto the wicked, thy mercies to the penitent.

21. 'Tis needfull for a man to converse with himselfe; for, so he sees his owne estate,
and may mend it, if it be bad; or better it, if it be good: and likewise as he, who stands on a hie rock neere the sea, sees that element better, then he, who sailes upon the waves: so the solitarie hath a fuller sight of the world, then if he were tossed in it. In his meditation he cals in his conversation, & this shewes him all mens dispositions, and where both theirs and his are good, where they are naught, and how he must behave himselfe, in his next sallies out. Lord, let me love to looke into my selfe, and there learne how to become good, or grow better. Let me know mine owne heart, and teach me how to deale with men.

22. Manie by deep meditation correct the vices of nature. I will then even now, and from this time till death, daily and often consider, to what vices I am inclin'd, and what vertues I want, and withall how to root out the first, and plant the second in my heart. Lord, blesse me with good thoughts, and let me see my diseases and their remedies. Teach me to know thee my Maker; consider whereof and wherefore I was made; view the place of this my abode; thinke what love it deserves, and in what dangers I live here; meditate whither I must goe, and take betimes the right, though strait, way unto happines.

23. These should be in my opinion the chiefe subjects of our Meditations: Gods
Workes, Law, Love, Rewards. His Workes, to admire him in them. His Law, to observe it. His Love, to answer it in some sort by another love. His Rewards, to invite and incite us in his service. In these, my soule, in these must be thy chiefe delight. That they be so, assist me, gracious God, that nothing be so pleasant to my heart, as these meditations of thy marvellous Works, holie Law, excessive Love, and excellent, yet free Rewards. Let me consider them severally, or all involv'd in Love: for indeed Love comprehends all. Love made the world for my fruition, gave me the Law for direction, and prepar'd the Rewards for my incitation. Yea Love hath done much more: for, it brought Christ from the Throne to the Crosse; from the highest glorie of heav'n, to the greatest ignominie of earth. O then let me intirely love that Love, that love of God, that God of love, or rather that God Love.

24. Fooles say, I had not thought on it, when the events of their actions crosse their expectation. Wise men differ from them: for, although the issue prove often contrarie to their expectation, since there is nothing so certain, which may not be hind'red by some sudden accident, yet it is not for want of due meditation; sith their counsels goe before their resolutions; and before they begin they consider the possibilitie, lawfulnes and utilitie of
the thing, not forgetting the meanes, by which it be well e • fected. Good Lord, make me wise in this sort. Let my meditation prevent all my actions; and let that be so wise, that these prove most happie.

div.head: His Meeting with a Friend.
div.p: 1 IF friendship is in human life what the Sun is in the world; who hath no friends, wants light and heat: but who hath some, doth enjoy these. I may then say at the sight of this man, that light appeares to me, and heat begins to comfort me. He is my friend, and as such I will embrace him, and withall call on thee, the God of love, to blesse us with perseverance in our mutuall friendship.

2. There's one, whom I esteem and call my fri • nd: for, I find him verie friendlie and officious, being made such to me and I to him, by a sweet sympathie or agreement of our humors, by a perfect conformitie of opinions, and joint indeavours to serve God, assist and delight each other in all just occasions. He loves me at all times, in summer and winter; stickes close to me in prosperitie and adversitie, honor and infamie; gives me prudent counsels, to order my affaires; and religious, in the service of God. I will then love him as my soule, and what I have shall be at his disposition,
so that he never want, as long as I enjoy anie commoditie. O God, take care of this loving person, yea of what belongs unto him: and that our friendship may please thee, be thou the chiefe object of it: and that it continue, let thy grace never forsake us, but let truth and fidelitie take their habitation in us.

3. There is a friend, yet (as I may suspect) not of my person, but greatnes My wealth makes him my friend, my gifts draw him to me. I will not then trust him: for if I fall, he'le not raise me: and if my riches flie away he'le flie with them, or after them, to grow rich by my povertie. Shall I then regard him? Yes, though not as a friend. Give me, O God, the spirit of discretion, in the election of my friends: least I take dissimulation for sincere affection: and give honestie to all dissemblers, that they love the persons, more then the wealth and honors of all these, whose profest friends they are.

4. This man will be my friend, but I will not be his. He is an angrie man, with whom I will make no friendship: a drunkard or prater, who cannot conceale my counsels: a lover of ill companies, a derider of godlines, a vicious and irreligious person. I must not then shake hands with him, nor goe with him; least I should learne his wayes, and get a snare unto my soule. Let me not, Lord, contract friendship
with those, who by their wicked behaviour declare themselves thy sworne enemies. Either convert them unto thee, and so unto a holie life; or let me shun their companie, unles it be to instruct them.

5. There goes a man with whom I have none or but little acquaintance, yet one most fit to be my friend; for, I conceive him to be deare to God. See, how modest all his apparell is, how grave his lookes without severitie. I heare commendations of his sobrietie, justice and pietie, without hypocrisie. His conversation drawes others to the love of vertue, his tongue declares them the wonders of God, unfolds his mysteries, invites them to his love. I will now go to him, or shortly seek means to begin a strait friendship with him. Let those, O Lord, let those be my friends, who love thee, and by whose help I know thee more and more, love thee with more sinceritie, serve thee with more fidelitie.

6. My friend is coming towards me with a countenance so cheerfull, that I perceive, all things are well with him. I blesse thy Name, O gracious God, for the happines of my friend, which I pray thee to continue.

7. How sad doth my friend look! how dejected is he! I will know what the matter is, and afford him my help, in comforts, service, loanes or gifts. He shall want nothing, I enjoy; yea besides it, I will and doe pray thee, my God,
to disperse his sad thoughts, cherish his heavie soule, and help me and other his friends to relieve him in his distres, that he may praise thy Name for our fidelitie.

8. Yonder goes one, who seems not to know me, or whom I would not see: yet he hath been my friend, but now is lost to me, or I to him. So nothing is constant on earth, and so I learne, that we must not be too bold with our friends, least we lose them; nor too lavish of our secrets to them; least they prove false, and basely betray us. O my God, let me die, rather then be so base; and let me live circumspectly, that I feare not the treacherie of other men.

9. There is something between this friend and me, which cooles our affections: and so I see, we are not wise, nor worthie to have friends, sith we cannot cover, excuse, forgive their faults. Who will have a friend without vice, must seek him in heaven. Shew us this, O wise God, and reconcile our minds, that our amitie end not thus, but it be permanent.

div.head: His Meeting with an Enemie.
div.p:
1 SIth all men are made of one bloud, Enmitie is 'gainst their nature; yet it is now so generall, that it may be thought naturall. And so is it, as nature is wholly corrupt: for so 'tis prone to everie vice, and Enmitie is a great
vice, yea the cause of manie. Give strength, O God, give strength against this corruption; correct this furious vice in me; fill my heart with love to al men, and all men with wisdome, to consider they are brethren, all engendred by one primarilie father: and so let this knowledge breed mutuall affection.

2. It I must love all men, I must be enemie to none, but a friend unto all, and so shew them th' effects of true friendship. That I be such, and doe this, assist me, good God; and not onely me, but all men.

3. That man is my Enemie, but who hath made him such? I, by some ill office, or he, by suspition; or another, by a false relation? If anie of these be the cause of his anger, I will make him satisfaction for th' injurie, and let him know the truth of the thing, he suspects or heares. Give me, O Lord, grace to doe so, and let him cheerfully both accept and beleeve what I shal doe and say.

4. This man hates me, because my good life cond • mnes his; and reputes me his chiefe enemie, because I tell him the truth. I then pitie his case, and much rejoyce in mine. Yet my joy is in thee, O Lord, the author of my holines; and my pitie moves me, to beg thy compassion upon this sinfull man, to convert him to godlines, and to the love of saving truths.

5. There is my sworne enemie, who whets
his tongue to slander me, and daily plots my destruction in goods, friends, life. Then he's the man, whom Christ doth command me to love, blesse him, doe him good, pray for him. I will, O Christ, doe as thou command'st me; but help thou me, to doe it well, I will love him heartily; speake as well of him, as truth shall permit; doe him as much good, as I can; wish him all happines, which proceeding from thee, I pray thee to give him. Blesse his house with plentie, his familie with tranquillitie, his bodie with health, his heart with love, his soule with pietie.

6. That man comes against me, with looks presaging some mischiefe. He will either quarrell or fight; by his tongue wound my reputation, or with his sword indeavour to cut off the weak thread of my life. I must then stand upon my guard, that his foule words provoke me not to impatience, nor his weapons hurt or kill me. Rebuke him, O my God, rebuke or weaken him. As the hungrie Lions could not devoure Daniel, then in thy gracious protection: so let not this mans strength or skill prevaile against me thy servant, but make me victorious of him, yet not insolent against him. If I am forc'd to fight in my defence, let me unarme him without harme, overcome his strength by valor; and his furie, by generositie. Forgive his malice against me, and let love succeed it.

div.head: His Good Name.
div.p: 1 AS a good Name is better then great riches; so the wise preferres it to them: and who is truly such mistakes not, wherein it consists. He knowes, vertuous actions, are the right foundation to an honest Reputation, and that wisdome and pietie make him gloriously famous. Let me, O God, truly know this, and so let vertue and religion be my principall studie, that my name be most sweet both to thee and all men.

2. I perceive, I have a good name, and that whosoever knowes me, speakes honorably of me; because they see my religious conversation, and by it guesse, that I am inwardly what I appeare in the outside. But are they not deceiv'd? No, thankes to thee, my God. Both sides agree: my holie affections produce my good actions, my intentions are right for thy glorie, my religion is n • t onely superficiall, but most cordiall. Therefore againe my cordiall thankes to thee, O Lord, from whom my thankfull heart hath its sinceritie, and which I beseech thee to deliver from vanitie proceeding from th' applause of men.

3. See, how sweetly these look on me, how courteously they salute me, how humbly they give me the way. Is it for my riches, greatnes; vertue or religion? Alas! the two first are not
mine, though like Swallowes they have now made their nests under my roofe. And for the last, they are greater strangers to me. I have no vertue, but in shew; no religion, but on the lips. I am but a meere Formalist, a verie hypocrit: so that like the Church in Sardis, I have a name, that I live, yet am dead. Then, my Soule, regard not the honors, all these render thee, but crie to God for help, call upon Christ for life. Thou, Christ, who art the Resurrection of the dead; of the dead in the flesh, of the dead in the soule: regard, I beseech thee, my wretched condition; regard and vivifie the deadnes of my heart. See, how fairely I carrie all things outwardly, yet how corrupt I am within. O permit me no more, to be a Saint without, and a Devill within, but sanctifie me now throughly. Sanctifie me by thy truth▪ that like thy selfe I love truth in the inward parts. Give me, O give me a strong love of the hearts puritie, and pardon my hypocrisie.

4. I heare, manie speake well of me: and so I have a good name amongst them. But what are they? Birds of the same feather, the companions in my riot, the fomenters of my faction, the complices of my wicked actions. And is a name good in such mouths? Nay rather their breath taints a name. God forbids such to use his name, and so should good men doe: and certainly, if I were sober and quiet, honest
and truly religious, those would blame me, who now praise me. O then, my God, make me speedily such, that these men may not avow me; or rather make me and them such, that we be asham'd of our wickednes, and so approv'd of thee.

5. The memorie of the just is blessed; but the name of the wicked shall rot. Am I then desirous, to leave a good name after me, an ornament to my issue? Let me be just: for, justice shall preserve my name; but if I am injust, wicked, irreligious; my name shall rot, as soon as my carkas; or if it continue, it shall be like a stinking snuffe, to offend the nostrils of my posteritie. O then let the just God make me upright and religious, to his glorie, and the honor and example of my children.

6. There's a Name good by excellence, and so most worthie to be prais'd: an admirable, holie, reverend, great, glorious, sweet, terrible Name. 'Tis the name of the Lord, of my Maker, Saviour and Comforter.See my Beliefe, Article 31. and 34. A Name, which I desire to have alwayes in my heart, and often in my mouth; yea a Name into which, as into a strong tow'r, I will run, to be safe. Thy Name, O God, is as ointment poured forth; therefore I will love thee. O let me know thy holie Name; that I sanctifie it, and not profane or blaspheme it; thy terrible Name, that I feare it; thy glorious Name, that I glorifie it; thy sweet Name,
that my soule love it. Let thy Name be named on me, or I call'd by thy name, acknowledged as thy servant; that all good men love me, and the wicked be afraid of me.

div.head: His Ill Name.
div.p: 1 THat man hath but little of man, who is careles of his good Name: for, man generally hath by nature a strong inclination, to be in good Reputation: so that where one degenerates from this naturall propension to glorie; thousands exceed in its prosecution, and manie lose themselves in it. Lord, make me moderat, neither too eagerly seeking to be well esteem'd by others; nor foolishly careles of their good opinion.

2. I have here an ill Name, and truly not without desert. I am a blasphemer of the holie and glorious Name of God; a derider of godlines; a drunkard and wanton; an oppressor, or selfe-seeker; an unprofitable citizen in the common-wealth; a rotten member in Gods Church. Can then others speak well of me? No certainly, otherwise they speake without truth. If then I will recover my good name, and fill mens mouths with my commendations, I must change my conversation, and make it as holie, as 'tis impure. Make it holie? Alas!
this is beyond my pow'r. I can rather, I will, I must, I shall adde daily to my impurities, unles the pure God of heaven stop the swift course of sins violent streame. Thy grace then, O my God, thy help, to turne those black waters. O renew me now within, with divine lights, pure affections; that my words and actions be likewise sanctifi'd, and so my neighbours may speake well of me, for my Christian conversation; and better of thee, for thy love and mercie in my conversion.

3. Manie speak ill of me, and no wonder; for, I speak ill of them. I, like a busie foole, prie into their secret affaires, discover their counsels, publish their faults: and so they doe the like of me: and so againe, I and they are all naught. Let then the onelie good God reforme us, make us see, loath, forbeare these evill practices, and live as good neighbours should doe.

4. I heare some light speeches of me, and therefore I will examine, what foundation they have, and if in me or in others. If the cause be in me, and not honest; I'le indeavour to remove it: if in others, proceeding from anger, malice, or false report; I will trie to informe or pacifie their minds. Lord, shew me the meanes to doe this, least their slanders of me upon anger, malice, credulitie, provoke thee to permit, their owne names be defam'd; yea to plague them in their goods, friends, bodies and soules.

5. I have an ill name amongst my neighbours, because (poore soules) I am not their pot-companion. They call me Covetous, because I am not a glutton or prodigall; Sillie, because I swager not; Coward, because no brawler nor fighter; Eunuch, because no whore-master. Shall I then regard what they say, and to avoid these names, become furious, lascivious, or drunkard? The Lord forbid. No, no; my God: they must not draw me thus away from my sober and quiet life. Rather, call them to my imitation, asham'd of their lewd life, and of their detractions of thy graces in me.

6. Heark, this man saith, I am a Puritan, because I will not sweare, or I reprove him for swearing: this other jeares at my professions of Christianitie, at my frequent exercices of pietie, which he esteemes hypocrisie, and calls me superstitious foole. And am I such indeed? Doe I serve my God but in shew and in superstition? Is my pietie but outward, and my professions but verball? Then the Lord pitie me with speed: but if all these things are reall in me; then his goodnes be prais'd, and knowne to this reviler of his gifts. Till then, and as long as such as he live, make me, O God, joyfull in these trialls of pietie, constant in thy service, by honor and dishonor, by ill and good reports, as a deceiver, and yet true. Blessed Saviour, who for my sake, didst make thy selfe of no reputation,
give me so much wisdome, as to esteem reproach for thee greater riches, then all worldlie treasures. O let me thinke my selfe happie, when I am reproach'd for thy name; and blest, when men shall revile me, and say falsly all manner of evill against me, for thy sake. Put thy Law in my heart; then let me not feare the reproach of men. Let not thy word be to me a reproach, but a delight; nor sin a delight, but reproach: yet that it neither be this last, cover it with thy holines, and let me know, love, practise righteousnes. So let these doe, and if ever I have committed this great sin, this sin of derision against godlie persons, pardon it, I pray thee, and preserve me from it.

div.head: His Prosperitie.
div.p: 1 PRosperitie is the common wish of all men, yet as it consists in honors, riches, friends, health, pleasures; 'tis the portion of few; and then no certaine token of Gods speciall love, sith the wicked enjoy these as well as the good, yea often in greater measure. When then thou O Lord, wilt blesse me with prosperitie, extend it farther, I pray thee. Let my soule feele thy saving grace, my heart be fill'd with all Christian vertues.

2. There's no trust in prosperitie, because 'tis built upon a sandie foundation. Though then plentie be now in my dwelling, and
greatnes wait on me: although all men professe great friendship towards me, my veines be full of the best bloud, and my bones moistened with marrow: yet I will not say to my soule; Thou hast much goods laid up for manie yeares: take then thy ease, eate, drink and be merrie: For, thou, O God, mightst say to me; Thou, Foole, this night thy soule shall be requir'd of thee: then whose shall those things be, which thou hast provided? O then let me not lay up treasure for my selfe, but be carefull to be rich towards thee.

3. The ease of the simple shall slay them, and the prosperitie of fooles shall destroy them: because their ease breeds idlenes, this foments wantonnes; and in prosperitie they establish securitie. The wise doe otherwise, looking upon prosperitie as upon a Swallow, which sings for a short time about his house, then flies away, leaving behind but a litle nest of drie dirt. Let me, O God, have a wise heart, to consider rightly all things, not placing my felicitie in things essentially earthlie, in things subject to instabilitie; but seeking my riches in thee, and setling my greatnes, delights and life in thy favor.

4. The Wicked live, become old, and are mightie in pow'r; their seed is establisht, their houses safe from feare, they spend their dayes in mirth. Is not therefore their condition happie, and so their life desirable and imitable?
No, no: They are but (like hogs or oxen) fatned for the slaughter; reserved to the day of destruction and wrath; their lamp is soon put out; in a moment they goe down to the grave. And is this right prosperitie? Not in my opinion. It is rather adversitie, to be thus prosperous, to be here rich, great, voluptuous; sith fooles are thus destroy'd, wicked cut off and damn'd. O then, my God, let me not be envious against the workers of iniquitie, nor fret by reason of the man, who prospers in his way, and brings wicked devices to passe. Let me rather pitie his condition, and pray thee for his conversion, then be tempted to his imitation.

5. Now I am in prosperitie, I live in plentie and at ease, all my desires are succesfull. Then I must be thankfull, carefull and wise: My God, grant me these three, gratitude, care, wisdome; gratitude to thee for thy worldlie gifts; care, to avoid exces in their fruition; wisdome, to love them in such sort; that if thou wilt take them, my heart follow them not.

6. I must in libertie remember those, who are in bonds; and in prosperitie, those, which suffer adversitie, as being in the same bodie. But what must my remembrance be? The same I would that theirs should be, if I were in their case. They shall be remembred in my prayers to God, for his infinit compassion on them:
in my good words to them, for their consolation: in my liberall gifts, frequent visits and courteous offices, for their speedie reliefe. My God, affect all men with these human, holie desires. Let dead charitie be reviv'd in these uncharitable times; and let, in these dayes of hatred, brotherlie love continue, or rather be renew'd. Be thou gracious to prosperous persons, in inlarging their hearts to Christian compassions, and liberall contributions: and to th' afflicted, in sweetning their adversities, by spirituall consolations, full persuasions of thy eternall love, in their correction or triall; speedie and happie change of their sad condition, sad at least outwardly in worldlie appearance.

div.head: His Adversitie.
div.p:
1 SIth Man is born unto trouble, and subject unto miserie, he must, if he be wise, make good provision of patience against the evill day: and the more he's honest, the more vertuous and religious; his provision must be greater, and sooner made, because his portion of pleasures is not on earth, but troubles, want, and bitternes of soule are here reserv'd for him. I cannot, O my God, I cannot say, I am vertuous and religious, unles I be such in some cold desires of vertue, weak indeavours in pietie: yet knowing, my life is expos'd to great and daylie afflictions,
I beg of thee the strong armour against calamitie, fortitude and patience: fortitude, to scorne volupti • , sleight fraile beautie, and neglect vaine honors, an • boldly undertake the conquest of the World, the Devill and my selfe, to bring them as slaves to thy feet; and patience, to endure meekly all the difficulties, dangers, sorrows, I shall find in that enterprise.

2. He is not fit to reigne with Christ, who will endure nothing for Christ, and so will not imitate Christ, who certainly did not live here in plentie, pleasures and honor, but in great povertie, feares, griefes and humilitie. As I am a Christian by name, so, my God, let me be in deed, in conforming my life to that of thy deare Son, as much as 'tis possible, in meeknes and humilitie, fortitude and patience; delighting more to beare my crosse after him, and drinke gall with him, thee to sit in chaires of honor, and enjoy the sweetest pleasures, the world and flesh can afford me.

3. Adversitie hath in it great utilitie: for, it shewes us, all things are vanitie, and so no fit objects of the love of mans soule. Let then not be of mine, O thou the soverain and permanent Good. Have all, my heart can give, yet still I shal owe more.

4. Adversitie is a mirrour truly representing our selves and our neighbours, their affections to us, and our strength in vertue: for, if they assist us in our calamitie, they are true
friends; if they leave us, they are but counterfeit. So if we faint in adversitie, our strength is but small; but if we resist it, retaine in miserie our vertue and integritie; our freedome to good in captivitie, our fortitude in the greatest torments, Gods truth in the dayes of apostasie: then with joy we may say, we are approv'd to God, we are right in his sight. That I may know and say so much, I will, O God, I will eat willingly the bread of adversitie, drinke the waters of affliction, whensoever it shall please thee, to present them to me; but I pray thee to make those bits and drops easie, by the consideration, that my affliction is but a triall of vertue, or a recalling from my sins. If then I be bound in fetters, and held in cords of affliction, shew me my workes, open my eares to discipline, and effectually command me to returne from iniquitie. O chuse and refine me in the furnace of affliction.

5. How weak, poore and abject am I! All things crosse my desires. My friends stand afar off, my neighbours revile me, manie oppresse, but none relieves my soule wearie of life. Then I will turn my eyes from this deceitful world, from these false friends, slandering neighbors, inhuman oppressors, and fix them on those glorious globes, which rowle over my head, and beyond them set my heart upon their Maker, whom I consider afflicted with me. Why
then, my soule, art thou cast downe? why thus disquieted? And thou, my God, why dost thou oppresse me? Thou art my onelie hope: and wilt thou faile me too? Thou canst not; for, thou art gracious. Then comfort now my heavie soule, by the apprehension of thy love towards me. So shall my affliction be light, and I happie in my adversitie.

div.head: His Mirth and Sadnes.
div.p: 1 MIrth and Sadnes follow our conversation and meditation; for, such as these are, those must be. We do rejoyce at our friends happines, grieve at their miseries, and at our enemies unkindnes: so thoughts of heaven breed our mirth, and the consideration of hell brings sadnes; and so mans heart is between these passions, not knowing which to chuse, yea often unable to make his choice: for, they are both so violent, in following their owne objects, and these objects so manie and frequent; that reason can seldome rule them. Strengthen mine, gracious God, that it ever sway affection.

2. As action and meditation agree well; so mirth and sadnes make a good match. Action is vanitie without meditation, and meditation without action, is but dull idlenes: mirth is foolish without sadnes, and sadnes hurtfull
without mirth. Pound them both together, and they shall make a good compound. But if one put downe the other, they shall doe to the soule what a predominant humor does unto the bodie, destruction must follow: mirth makes her light and insolent, by sadnes she growes desperate. O God, let neither of these two be alone, nor one too strong for the other: but grant, that as in my feares I may hope, and likewise feare in hopes; so in my mirth I may feele some sadnes, and in sadnes some mirth. Lord, let likewise my face and behaviour be such, as my friends see in them both a sad mirth, and a merrie sad • es: no spightfull frownes at unpleasant actions, nor immoderate laughing, or foolish grinning at delightfull objects.

3. How light am I? But what is the cause of my mirth? A good bargaine, a new honor, a commendation of a friend, or perhaps of a flatterer, a suit at law obtain'd, a love granted of a faire maid to be my wedded wife, an heire borne unto my estate, new possessions added unto the old, or plentie succeeding my penurie? Then downe, my heart, leap not so hie; for, some of these things may away with greater speed, then they are come. Vouchsafe, my Lord, to blesse me long with the fruition of this thing, which doth procure my present joy, and grant,
I set no more love upon it, then such fraile thing deserves, that so its losse vexe me the lesse.

4. How light am I? But what is the cause of my mirth? A holie motion in my heart? A constant purpose to doe well? A true desire of godlines? A sense of Gods favor? A persuasion of his eternall love? Then, my heart, be merrie, and let my soule be joyfull in my God; for, he hath clothed me with the garments of salvation, and covered me with the robe of righteousnes. Lord, let the cause of my joy last, and let me not sleight these motions; but grant, I doe till death, as well as I doe purpose now.

5. Is a reward prepar'd for me in heav'n? and is my name writ in the Book of life? Why then am I heavie for this light affliction? Away with the worldlie and death-working-sorrow. Must I grieve for a toy, for the losse of a pin, for a child or friend dead, for a man, now angrie with me, although I have given him no cause, whilst God loves me, and keeps for me an incorruptible crowne of glorie? Let me not, O good Lord, sleight thee and thy heavens so much, as to regard a small losse, or disgrace.

6. Had I no sin, I could live merrily; for, I should neither feele paine, nor feare ill: but since my case doth not stand so, joy must give place unto sorrow; till I have bewailed my
sin; for then my sorrow must be gone, and I will rejoyce in the Lord, who shall break off my bonds. O God! grant, my sorrow worke repentance to salvation; and, Lord, forgive me my offences, that godlie joy may fill my heart.

7. Now my sins are brought before me. Now they all appeare like monsters, to terrifie my soule; and like lions, to devoure my darling. Well, well, let them so terrifie, that they make me run to Christ, for refuge. Let these lions of hell so pursue me, that I seek and bring against them the Lion of Judah, to force them back into their dark dungeon. Are not, O Christ, are not my sins washt in thy bloud? How then can they appeare so foule? Is not my injustice cov'red with the robe of thy originall innocence and actuall righteousnes? How then can she fright me by her uglie visage, infernall countenance?
