O Christ, comfort now my sad heart, with a full persuasion, that my sins are pardon'd, my transgressions cov'red, and my spots washt. Sweet Jesus, speake peace to my heavie soule; least the remembrance of my grievous sins make her become so desperat, that she forget thy infinit merits. Let no more sin enter my thoughts, but to make me thankfull to thee, for its free remission; and carefull of my wayes, that they be not as they have been, leading to perdition, but tending unto perfection.

8. Why am I now become so sad? Because
(belike) my joy was not in God, without whom mirth is but sorrow, pleasure but pain, sweetnes but bitternes. I sought mirth in the flesh, sport in the world, and content in riches; but now I see, the end of that is heavines and affliction. Had I grounded my joy in the graces of the Spirit, and the mercies of God, I should possesse it still. But since 'twas otherwise, and is now gone from me, I will not run after; but rather strive to get a mirth, which no man take from me. O Lord, help me in this purchace; give me that peace, which the world cannot give, that blessed joy, which wicked hearts cannot savour.

9. I am heavie, yet doe not know the cause of my present sadnes. And so alas! man is so wretched a creature, and of such fraile nature, that a small thing can afflict him: a litle flie torment his flesh, a sleight griefe vexe his sp'rit. Yet as he's reasonable, judgement must guide his actions, and prudence order his motions. I will therefore rowse up my spirits; that I lowre not, when I may as well laugh as weep. If my dangers are great, what are my helps? If I may feare, can I not likewise hope? If God is but with me, who shall be against me? Let thy face, gracious God, shine on my distrest heart; and lift up now thy countenance upon my heavie soule; then these mists shall vanish, and my sad soule rejoyce in thee.

div.head: His Love.
div.p: 1 THere's no heart without Love: yet there are few wise hearts, which set their loves on right objects, and in a right measure, and due order: for, some love that, which they should hate; others love with exces, or with coldnes; and there are millions amongst us, whose affections are most preposterous. That I be not one of all these, let the wise God direct my love.

2. If Beautie charmes our eyes, if Vertue moves our minds, if Riches and Honors (like that fruit of Eden) are pleasant, if Wisdome is desirable, and Love amiable: we must, and I doe fix my eyes, heart and mind upon thee, my God, the first beautie, transcendent perfection, durable riches, incomparable greatnes, infinit wisdome, excessive love. I will love thee How he's lov'd thus, see the T • ble of my Catechisme in the word Love.
first and above all things, because thou hast loved me first. I will be ordered by thee, as being my Wisdome: aspire to thee, my chiefe Honor: seek thee, my permanent Riches: See my Catechisme, Qu • stion 914. &c. imitate thee in Christ, my rare Vertue: run after thee, my heavenlie Beautie. Let me ever so Love, Submit, Apire, Seeke, Imitate and Run; that at last I find thee, in whose blest fruition is my onelie felicitie.

3. God having my first love, the next is due to me, and to that part of me, which excells
the other. But how much I must love my selfe,See that Table, & the word Love. and in what sort, are things subject to great mistake. Least then I mistake them, direct me, gracious God, in my love to my selfe; that it be both orderlie and holie.

4. My Neighbour must have my third Love, and I must esteem all men such; yet there are degrees amongst them, and so must be in my love to them. Bloud, alliance, friendship, vertue and grace challenge that which is theirs. I will, O God, give everie man his due, a cordiall love to all, See againe that word Love.
even to my enemies; yet I will in it preferre those, whose right is first and best. Take thou the first, and distribute the rest.

5. Riches are attractive: for, as Christ saith, Where our treasure is, there also our hearts are: and for that cause he advises his followers, to lay up theirs in heaven: in which words I conceive, he gives them a double lesson: First, to give him in his poore members a part of their treasure, which he may keep in heav'n for them. Secondly, that they excessively love not those riches, which are not permanent, but set their thoughts and affections on him, who shall never faile them. These lessons I would gladly learne, although I be not rich, and the Lord grant, that all wealthie men goe with me unto Christs and Pauls school. Call us, O Christ, call and teach us, not to be high-minded, n ••
trust in uncertaine riches, but in thee the living God, who giv'st us richly all things to enjoy. Teach us, O teach us, to doe good, to be rich in good workes, readie to distribute, and willing to communicate.

6. All creatures are lovelie, but those obtain the precedence in human affections, which have a greater portion of beautie: and these affections may be set on beautifull objects; if it be done in order and without exces; that is, if the Creator be first lov'd, and the creature, as a creature. So honors may be sought, and so pleasures enjoy'd, if in our search and fruition, we forget not to honor him, delight in him, who must be our chiefe honor and pleasure. I love Beautie, Honors, Pleasures: but that I never sin in the prosecution, fruition, privation of them, be thou, O God, my most lovelie Beautie, highest Honor, sweetest Delight.

p.hi: See my Discourse of Love, when it shall be printed.

div.head: His Hatred.
div.p:
1 ALl men are subject to anger, and anger breeds Hatred: yet as we may be angrie without sin; so we may faile in the conception of Hatred, and faile most happily; sith this viper kills her mother. O Lord, moderate my anger; keep it within the limits of reason; least it conceive
Hatred, and Hatred kill my heart and soule; deprive my heart of all honest pleasures, and my soule of thy grace.

2. God forbids us to hate our brother in our hearts: yet Jehu the Prophet reprov'd Jehoshaphat, for loving them, who hated the Lord. Whence I gather, that we must love and hate; love man, as he is our brother, as he is created by God: but hate him, as he is wicked and Gods enemie. Our love must be to his person, our hate to his ill qualities. O God, grant me this love and hate: Grant, I love cordially that noble creature, which was made after thy likenes: and I hate with perfect hatred those who wickedly speake against thee, bloudie and deceitfull persons, blasphemers of thy Name, revilers of goodnes, persecutors of godlie men.

3. As the lover of God must affect what he loves, so he must hate what he abhorres Since then God hates evill, the man after his heart must (as David) hate everie false way; not one kind of evill, not one vice or few sins, but all generally, because all opposit to God. O most perfect and holie spirit, direct mine in all things; so that all my passions be orderlie, my affections holie. Let my heart abhorre sin in me and in others. Let me hate evill, and love good.

4. I am forbid to love the World, and commanded to hate my Father and Mother;
yet I must and will love both these, the World and my Parents. The World as made good, and for me; and my parents as the authors of my carnall substance. How then shall I hate them? I must not hate them, but something in them: not the world, but worldlings; yet not worldlings, but worldlines; that exces of delight, they take in the creature, their irregular affection to it, and immoderate use of it. Not my Parents, but their vices, or rather mine. I must not love them so, that their dotage on me, or my fondnes of them, hopes on them, feare of them, withdraw or hinder me from the service of God, who is my chiefe Father. Then, holie Father, heare and grant: heare my resolution, and graciously grant my request. I will love thee more then all worldlie things, and above my Parents. I will hate worldlings, and forsake father and mother, brothers, sisters, bloud, alliance and friendship, in their oppositions to thee. I will doe this, yet I cannot, shall not doe it, unles thou assist me. Help me then, my gracious Father; help me, my loving God, without whom I can doe nothing, and by whom all things are easie. Blesse my resolution with faithfull performance, speedie, constant execution, on all just occasions.

div.p: See the fourth Pray'r for the Morning, page 26. and that for Friday-Evening in the Monthlie Devotion.

div.head: His Feare.
div.p: See the second Prayer for the Morning, page 21. and Night-Feares.

div.head: His Conformitie.
div.p: 1 THere's a vertuous and a vicious Conformitie; vertuous unto and in good things, and vicious in the contrarie. We must then search the nature of all things, which require our Conformitie; that so we give or denie it according to merit. Help me, wise God, in my inquisition; least I be conformable, where I ought to be singular.

2. The most vertuous Conformitie is that which is the most divine, and such I esteem our Conformitie with Christ, to whose Image we are pr • destinat to be conforme. We must then indeavour to be like him, at least as much as we canSee my Catechisme, Question 954. & 955. imitate him. Thou gracious God, who hast elected me to that Conformitie, renew me in knowledge, holines, righteousnes; and let thy
Christ be all these things to me, that in him I be before thee perfectly wise, holie, righteous.

3. As the Elect are all members of one bodie, they must studie a greatSee the Table of my Catechisme, in the words Conformitie and Communion. Conformitie, which intertaine theirSee the Table of my Catechisme, in the words Conformitie and Communion. Communion. Who then proudly neglects this strait conformitie, and so breakes the holie union, may well doubt of his Election. Let me never doe so, O thou the lover of union, not dissent from thy Saints, not affect or practise contrarie to thy Church; but let my judgement and heart be one with her, so that there be but one spirit and one heart amongst us.

4. Holie Paul forbids me Conformitie unto this World, by which, I thinke, he understands not this visible and insensible frame, whose regular motions, constant seasons give me a faire lesson of the excellence of Order, to make it as well the life of my actions, as it seems to be the soule of the world. So Paul commands it to the Church of Corinth, and rejoyces to see it in spirit amongst the faithfull Colossians. Whence I conclude, that if I sleight Order in Church or State, and observe it not in all things, I am not worthie to be esteem'd truly faithfull, and to passe for a rationall man. O thou, who art the Author of Order, not of confusion, teach me order in my privat affaires,
and make me love, not oppose it, in publick Governments, Ecclesiasticall and Civill.

5. I must not be Conform unto this world, not to the vaine and proud fashions of our worldlings; to their idle, drunken, wanton conversation; to their swaggering, swearing, profane and impious behaviour: but rather I must be, (and so, my good God, grant, I be) transform'd by the renewing of my mind, that I may prove what is thy good, acceptable and perfect will. O let all those be thus transform'd, whom vanitie, folie and wickednes deforme.

div.head: His Singularitie.
div.p: 1 WHere Conformitie is commendable, there Singularitie is avoidable. Discretion is then requisit in our daylie Conversation, that we offend in neither of these. As it is requisit, so I beg it of thee, O thou the wise maker of mans understanding. Make mine (I pray thee) Judicious, to discerne good or ill.

2. As it is levitie, to be Conforme in vanitie; so to be Singular in things indifferent savours a foolish pride. In these then the Church shall have my Conformitie, the State my Subjection, and persons of my qualitie shall find me in their modest mode. Let me, O God, indeavour
to please men, where they displease thee not, and goe with them as far, as their way is not foule.

3. Singularitie in vertue is not against the rules of Conformitie to the good; sith in vertue and pietie we must not onely aspire at imitation, but at excellencie. He is then wisely Singular, who indevours to be more perfect then the rest. If he followes the way, observes the rules, he's not ty'd to other mens pace. O that I were thus Singular! O that my God would make my feet so swift, my affections so light and active in his wayes, that I should not loiter behind his Saints, but run nimbly before them all! Thou mayst doe this, good Lord; thou mayst draw me faster with stronger cords of love, by cleerer lights of the felicitie of those, who forsake all to follow thee. Doe then now what thou mayst. Draw me swiftly, attract me pow'rfully, till I be at the end of my celestiall race.

div.head: His Silence and Talk.
div.p:
1 AS by meditation we are taught, how to behave our selves in our conversation; so in Silence we learne to speake: and these must goe by turnes, as well as the others. Either of them must have its place and time: silence becomes our solitude, and companies desire our talkes. As for the time, we must speak,
when we see, our words may doe good, or procure innocent delight; and be silent, when the matter's too hie for us, or our speeches are not welcome. Lord, teach me both the place and time to speake and be silent; and grant, that when my tongue is held within my teeth, my mind discourse and walke with thee; and when I speake, season my words; that they be in the eares of my auditors, as morning dew to a drie ground.

2. To be silent, when we must speaks and speak, when we should be silent, is alike censurable. Then to speak so, that our hearers may not understand our meaning, is a thing to be avoided: likewise too curious and trim speeches, or harsh and low discourses must either be forborne, or discreetly made before them, whose minds love such. And to speak against our practice is a hie self condemnation. If our words be against our deeds, men will sooner judge us, then mend themselves. Lord, let me make my actions good, that they give weight unto my words; and let me so order my speeches, that by them thou receive glorie, and my auditors and I gaine.

3. I love silence, when it is not abus'd; that is, when it waits on meditation, gives heed to instruction, and heares other men speake; but Monkes and Friers silence I dislike, as foolish and superstitious: for, it is ty'd to constant
times and places, out of which they may talk, till they be hoarse and drie. To speak too fast is a signe of folie, and too long and frequent discourses are seldome without vanitie, and never without sin. But to be long silent denotes a surlie mind and spightfull heart: yet as their silence is constrain'd, by the rigor of superstitious lawes, I may free some of them from the imputation of those vices, which for their sakes I wish, were the greatest, they have. Lord, shew those poore soules their errors; give them another light, then that they have by their fore-fathers traditions; quench their thirst with other waters then those, they draw out of the Well of their merits. Teach them to pray, sing, fast, goe bare-foot, whip themselves, and keep their long silence, to mortifie their flesh without thoughts of merit; with good intention to please thee, and not with presumption, to make thee their debtor, by reason of their workes.

4. Fooles must heare wise men speak, and young men give eare to the old: so both may learne wisdome; whereas the first bewray their folie by their tongue, and the second their ignorance. Let them propound their doubts, and mark well their resolution from the wise braines of the learned and grave. So fooles may be esteemed wise, and children thought hopefull young trees. When I am in their companie, Lord, let me instruct them: but when I converse
with the wise, let me heark to their instruction, give eare to their counsels, and follow their good directions.

5. Silence is a great vertue in women, and so much the greater, because their sexe is given to pratling. She's therefore wise, who hath reform'd that common vice. Wives should follow the rule of the Apostle, not speake at Church, nor teach in companie; but learne at home of their husbands. Since mine doth so, Lord, I thanke thee; and that all women doe so, I earnestly pray thee. Teach them, O Lord, humilitie towards all men, submission unto their husbands, and to witnesse their submission, indue them with silence.

6. Servants and inferiors must either keep silence, or speak with great heed and respect before their masters and betters: for, with a sober tongue and modest speeches they will better shew their respect, then with bare heads and long legs, or low courtesies. Lord, when I keep servants, let them so deale with me; and grant, I honour my betters, as I will be regarded by my inferiors.

7. As in number mans eares exceed his tongue; so it is sit, he heare more then he speak, and use the eares more then the tongue. And 'tis wisdome, to tell our tales unto our selves, before others heare them; for, then we learne, how to expresse our thoughts, and conceale
that, which we will keep secret. Let the onelie wise God teach me this, and help my soule to looke unto her wayes; that I offend not with my tongue by idle words, foolish talkes, and unsavourie tales.

8. Pratlers are sick of an evill disease; for, they will neither heare, nor can be heard; and so they make themselves both odious and ridiculous in all good companies. They have an itch, to say all, and heare nothing, and out of their throats (although drie) comes a river of words, which drowne their hearers attention. Lord, cure in me this itch, and heale me of that ill disease. Make me readie to heare, and slow to speake; and as unwilling to interrupt others, as I am to be stopt, before my tale be told.

9. Evill communication corrupts good manners, and lewd talkes taint chast minds. Lust creepes into the heart, as well by the eare, as by the eye: lascivious words are as pow'rfull, to blow the fire, as wanton lookes. Then God forbid, my tongue should be the bellowes to kindle lust, since it is made to be a trumpet or an organ, to sing her glorious makers praise.

10. Detraction is forbid; and 'tis ill done, not onely to lay upon anie man a false crime, but also to report the true, if it be done, to disgrace the person: yet this sin is common in our dailie conversation. We praise our selves,
commend our friends, flatter great men, and taint the names of those, who cannot answer us by reason of their absence, or dare not gainesay us, for our greatnes, and their meane condition. Let not O Lord, my tongue doe so, being so vaine, as to set out my worth; so base, as is fawne on rich men; so wicked, as to slander vertue, and blast the fame of innocent persons; or so uncharitable, as to shame anie for his fault, when I may wi • him otherwise.

11. If we ought not to speake ill of a man, without prudent caution or great necessitie; is it lawfull to speake slightly of the creator of all men? to blaspheme the God of heaven and earth? Or if anie does it in our presence, shall love or feare to or of the partie command us then silence? No, no: neither of these is good, but both are verie ill. O let not the maker of my tongue be offended by it in speeches or silence? Let it O Lord, let it rather cleave to my roofe, or rot in my mouth, then utter a slight word of thee: but let it be nimble to reprove those, who shall offend thee, the preserver of men. O let it be a sword to them, who blaspheme that worthie name, by whicb I am call'd, and that most holie Spirit, which sanctifies and comforts me; those lims and children of Satan, who, O horror! doe with boldnes denie the Deitie of thy eternall Son and Spirit.

12. Mans speech is the interpretor of his
mind; and in this he excels all earthlie creatures, because he may shew his semblable, what by nature is hid in him. Yet the lyer and dissembler doe abuse this prerogative, for, they shew men, by a false tongue, quite contrarie images to those, which are drawne in their hearts. Let me O Lord, never imitate them, but let my words answer my knowledge, and manifest my thoughts, when it is fit they should be knowne; if not, let me conceale them by silence, and not disguise them by falshood.

13. Who uses lies will sweare; the swearer will in time forsweare, and perjurie shall teach him blasphemie. But O God, let my tongue be as drie in my mouth as the dust in summer, before I take thy holie name in vain, how much lesse sweare, forsweare, blaspheme? And if I heare others offend in anie of these things, O my God, loose my tongue, and so open my mouth, that I shew them their sin, in such ouglie colors, that they both loath and forsweare it. Must I accuse that man, who doth blaspheme my King; and be dumbe before him, who doth revile my God? No, no; I neither must nor may. Thy zeale O Lord, shall make my words as hot as fire, to melt the hearts of such offenders; and like darts, to wound them, for their grievous offence.

div.head: His Tentations in Sin, and their Remedies.
div.p: 1 OUr life is a warfare, the world our field, Satan our chiefe enemie: therefore we must still be well arm'd, and have a stout courage, to withstand his furious assaults. Let me O Lord, be alwayes found in thy whole armour; but above all, give me the shield of faith, the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the spirit.

2. We looke all for a crowne; but who will give it us, unles we be victors? and how can we be such, unles we fight? and who can fight without enemies? Enemies I have enough; all the devils of hell, the wicked men on earth, and my sensualitie are daily fighting against me. Too too many for one: yet if I do look with such eyes, as Elisha's man had, when he saw the mountaine full of horses and charets of fire round about Elisha, then I shall see, that they who are with me are more then all they, who are against me. The blessed spirits of heaven are with me, and God himselfe is at my right hand, least I be mov'd. Then my soule, feare nothing, trust in thy God, fight under his banners; and thou my Lord, make hast to helpe me: my God, make hast to save me, and be not far from me.

3. Tentations must make us warie; yet they should make us merrie too; for, they are
signes, we are not yet in Satans snares. They are call'd the salt of the soule, which season • her vertues; the furnace, in which faith is tri'd; a sure remedie against pride, and the fore-runners of sweet rest, if they be well put off. Let them, O Lord, shake no more my soules constancie, then the waves doe those rocks, against which they break all their strength.

4. The Devill is a subtile foe, who assaults us under the liverie of nature; a cunning waterman, who doth follow both wind and tide. He fits his tentations to our disposition, so that his fight is lesse, and his victorie more certaine. To the wanton he presents faire objects; to the drunkard, sweet and strong drinkes; to the rich man, pride and pleasure; to the needie, desire of meanes, or occasions of theft; He feeds the covetous with feares of future want, the merrie man with worldlie joyes, and the sad with thoughts of despaire. Lord, let me know tentation from inclination; yet so beware of both; that I resist the first, and reforme the second.

5. The Basiliske or Cockatrice must be kill'd in the shell; diseases looked to, as soone as felt; enemies withstood, as soon as known. I feele motions of pride, wantonnes, or envie, which in a little space may cause my overthrow, unlesse I choake them in their birth.
Strengthen my hands O Lord, that I destroy all these vipers, before they grow too strong.

6. What sweet and lovelie face is that? How faire this womans bosome is? It seemes to me as smooth as glasse. I'le draw neere her, to feele the softnes of her skin, and tast the sweetnes of her breath: for, 'tis told me, that her lips drop honie. But my soule, stay a while; let her goe before thee, least thou be seene with her: and if thou feare to lose her, marke well which way she goes. Alas poore wretch! her feet goe downe to death, her steps take hold on hell. Then let her goe for me, I will not follow her. Stop me that way, good Lord, and let me not for a minutes pleasure, lose as eternitie of joy. O turne away mine eyes from beholding such vanities, and let never my sillie bean be intangled by fraile beautie.

7. Here is a cup of wine of a curious color, sweet smell, and delightfull tast. I'le drowne in it all my cares and sorrowes. I'le send it downe, and after it manie others. Wilt thou doe so? Then heare a word before the second or third glasse, for afterward thou'le not heart me. Whilst it is here, thou maist spill it; but when 'tis drunke too much, it shall rule thee, take away thine owne heart, be bitter to thy guts, bite thee like a serpent, sting thee like an adder, and make thee like a beast. Looke
well into that wine, for although it be pleasant at the top, yet in the bottome of the cup, are woes, sorrowes, quarrels, wounds, death, hell. Then drinke no more, then thou canst beare; yea drinke no more then may quench thirst, or cheere up thy sad heart. O Lord, let not wine bewitch me, so that my soule erre through strong drinke; but grant, I take it for comfort more then for its sweetnes.

8. I'le be reveng'd: that man hath abus'd me, therefore I sweare, I'le die, or be reveng'd. So my soule, thou maist die, yea without revenge too. Thy sole desire is able to kill thee; and thou shalt find my saying true, unles thou change thy malicious purpose. What hath this man done unto thee, which thou hast not done to others, or to the Maker of all men? And hadst thou been willing, they had paid thee in the same coine? Thou wilt say no, and I dare beleeve thee. Then deale with this, as thou wilt be dealt with. Let passe his wrongs to thee, forget his unkindnes, and forgive him with all thy heart. So maist thou both obtaine mercie of God, and by meeknes make a friend of a foe. Mercifull God, take rank • r from my heart, purge it from all malice, fill it with love and gentlenes towards my sworne and deadlie enemies; then forgive me my trespasses, as I f • rgive all them, who trespasse against me.

9. How shall I heap riches, that I may get honors, and buy some preferment; for, (it seems) no man regards me: but were I rich and great, then I would make those stoop, whom I must salute afar off? Alas poore man! art thou wearie to live at ease, lie in the safe haven, and sleep in thy whole skin? Be, be content with what thou hast. Large possessions require great eares, riches breed feare, gold racks the mind Wilt thou be rich? Use well thy meanes, and think, thou hast enough. Wilt thou be great? Then be not ambitious, for, ambition is never satisfi'd. Besides, if thou wilt climb, think thou maist fall, then thy case shall be worse then now, Now thou art free in thy low condition; but if ambition seize on thee, thou must be servant to others, by whose help thou maist get honors. O God, give me wisdome enough, to consider my present happines, enjoy my meanes in peace, and smother these troublesome thoughts of greater riches and honor.

10. This mans happines troubles me; my heart rises at his prosperitie, my eyes cannot see his glorie, my eares glow at his praise. His content procures my torment, his joy my griefe, his life my death. I feele this verie true; and so I see, I am a verie foole. This man is the object of my envie, yet he's never the worse: for, this serpent gnawes but my heart,
and can doe him no harme, unles I deale with him as Cain with Abel, or the Devill with Job. But God forbid, my madnes should be such, as to offer him the lest harme. Nay rather, in spight of envie, I'le strive to doe him good, in praising his vertue, and rejoycing at his prosperitie. O Lord, let me doe so, and never suffer me to envie the good of anie, as a member of that cursed Angell, through whose envie death came into the world; but rather grant, I wish well to all men, as the follower of thy self, who mak'st thy Sun shine upon all.

11. Yonder goes a gallant: how rich and neat all his apparell is! He drawes upon him all mens eyes. Why should I not be so attir'd? Because my meanes are not so great as his, nor my condition so gentile; or if they be, yet I will not feed vanitie, and spend on my carkas what I must keep for my children, and give my hungrie and naked brethren. Let me, O God, thus withstand Satans tentations concerning proud attire.

12. I am now tempted to doe ill, yea and by so manie, that I know not how to resist. The Devill, the World and the Flesh are all busie to draw me to their wils. Their persuasions are strong, their allurements sweet, and their promises great. Shall I then yeeld? No, no; for, I perceive, the sweetnes of sin shall be
short, but its bitternes long: the pleasure lasts but some moments, and the paine may be perpetuall. Besides, their promises are false; and were they true, yet I would not forsake my God. He hath made me by his power, redeemed me with his owne bloud, and daily keeps me by his providence, and feeds me with his word and bread. Hath Satan done the like for me? Will the World die for me? And can the Flesh look so to me? No doubtles, no. Then none of them shall have my love, yea I scorn to lend them an eare. They are my foes, aiming all at my destruction, and devising, how they may put him downe, whom God will exalt. O then, my God, stand thou my friend, deliver me from my enemies, and let my mouth be filled with thy praise.

div.head: His Victories over Sin, and Thankes for them.
div.p: 1 AFter a long and bloudie fight, how pleasant is the victorie? I was assail'd on everie side: my senses had objects of sin, my heart felt motions of lewdnes, envie, hatred, &c. yet I did so bestirre my selfe, that my enemies are fled. O then, my God, receive my praise; for, thou alone hast taught my hands to war, and my fingers to fight.

2. Let Cesars trophies be pull'd downe, let
not Roman triumphs be regarded, before my glorious victorie. I have not skal'd hie walls, surpris'd strong townes, kill'd valiant men; yet I have done farre more: for, I have overcome my selfe, subdu'd my affections, tam'd my rebellious flesh. Then blessed be thou Lord, my strength, my hope and my fortres, who subduest my people, which by right should be under me, yet strives to master me.

3. If those are strong, who overcome strong men; and those stronger, who conquer flesh and bloud; what strength is mine, since I have wrestled against principalities, against powers, against rulers of the darkenes of this world, against spirituall wickednes in high places; yea so wrestled against them all, that they have had the fall? But who hath given me such strength, who hath girt my weak loines with truth, and armed my naked bodie with the brest-plate of righteousnes? None but thy selfe O Lord, my defender. Then none but thou shall have the praise of the victorie. I will not share in the triumph, I dare not challenge the trophie; but I doe render thee all honor and glorie.

4. God hath tempted me this day, by a losse in my goods, a disease in my flesh, a wound in my bodie; and I have with patience felt the smart of his rod, and without murmuring drunke in the cup of affliction. The
flesh like Jobs curst wife would persuade me to curse my God; but I did rebuke her. Is not this a great victorie? Then my soule magnifies thee, Lord; and my spirit rejoices in thee, God my Saviour; because thou dost in me great things.

5. In walking now abroad, I saw the world making a glorious shew, to draw me to his love: yet I past by, without regarding all his pomps, coveting his riches, desiring his honors; for, I saw they were not lasting, but deceitfull, and often withdrawing from God. So I have overcome the world with a generous mind, which will love but perpetuall things. Is not my victorie famous? Then my soule gives thee thankes, O thou the maker of the world, because 'tis by thy grace, that I have escaped the corruption, which is in the world through lust.

6. The flesh hath this day tempted me by wantonnes, voluptie, sloth or gluttonie; and the devill by evill thoughts, ambition, malice, heresie; and I was almost woone, had not God by godlie notions shew'd me, the flesh will lead me unto death, and the devill drag me to hell. And so with that knowledge, I have overcome both. O then let both my heart and flesh rejoice in thee my God; because thou hast kept me from sulfilling the lust of the flesh, and from the fierie darts of the wicked.

7. Men have tempted me by foule words, ill
deeds and unkindnes: yet I have done so well, that by faire meanes and kind usage I have appeased them, whereas I might by Satans suggestion have given them as good, or rather as ill as they have brought me. So I have not been overcome of evill, but have overcome evill with good. And is not this a glorious victorie? No doubt it is. Therefore I must return thee glorious thankes, O God of love and peace, because thou hast indu'd me with meeknes, when wrath could have made my heart swell, and rage kindle the fire of immortall hatred.

8. In the victorie of sin, vain-glorie is the last enemie, which resists: for, it takes strength from its fellowes defeat: therefore it must be kill'd by a sincere acknowledgement, that Gods hand, not our strength, hath overcome all our enemies. Then we must not be secure for the first victorie; since our enemies (Anteus-like) seeme to get new forces by their fall, and daily assaile us againe, and will doe so till death. Then if we persevere in our spirituall warre, and valiantly overthrow sin, we shall receive the crowne laid up for those who overcome. O God, who seest the weaknes of nature, strengthen me by thy grace, that I fight a good fight, finish my course, and keep the faith.

div.head: His Overthrow in Sin, and Repentance for it.
div.p: 1 AS it is glorious for a man, to overcome himselfe; so it is infamous, to be overcome by himselfe: for, in that we vanquish sometimes, we see, we may doe it alwaies, were our hearts still the same, and our faith alike at all times. Then how disgracefull must it now be to me, since I am foyled by my selfe, whom before now I have often subdu'd? O God, I am asham'd; and could I find a place to hide my nakednes from thine all-seeing eye, I would runne into it. But there is none, unles it be the bleeding wounds of thy deare Son Jesus. There I will be, beseeching thee, my sweet Saviour, to hide me well from the most dreadfull lookes of thy angrie Father, till thou hast made my peace.

2. Who made man, knows what is in man; yet he tries us often, not to know us better; but that others see what we are, and we our selves know our owne strength. He hath tempted me this morning, and brought my patience to her triall by a loss, pain, or fall: and I not remembring how long I have sweetly enjoy'd that thing, and what little right I had in it, more then those, who want it, have taken the losse of it, as a wrong done to me, repined
at Gods providence, yea curs'd his name: a far greater losse then the first; yet in mercie he doth give me these good motions, to make me see my fault. Lord, I thanke thee for thy goodnes, beg pardon for my sin, and grace against such occasions.

3. This day I saw the world in his Peacocks feathers, and I was so ravisht with that pompous shew, that I stood still to behold it, untill I was taken with both admiration and love. Then I perceiv'd, mine eyes were dim and weak to look heaven-ward, though cleere and strong to behold vanitie: yea I wonder how these thoughts come into my head, since my braines are so full of the things of this world. Doubtles they come from God, to call me back to him, and make me break my league with his and my sworne enemies. Lord, since thou call'st me, give me feet, my feet motion, my motion swiftnes, and my swiftnes acces to thee. Turn thy face from my present sin, and put out this misdeed, and let not such another shew make me commit the like offence.

4. O God, give me the comfort of thy help again, and stablish me with thy free spirit: for lo, Satan hath put me downe, the Serpent hath beguiled me, and I have eat of the forbidden fruit. I have broken thy lawes by _____ and done wickedly in thy sight. But now I doe repent, and with a
broken heart, weeping eyes, bashfull face earnestly crave, thou wilt vouchsafe to purge me with bysop, and wash me throughly from my wickednes, with the bloud of thy Lamb.

5. As the strength of our enemie commends our victorie; so his weaknes makes our overthrow disgracefull. How infamous therefore is my present defeat; since by my flesh my sp'rit is overcome, a giant by a pygmie, and an elephant by a flea? This base flesh in her fight with the spirit hath drawne it to fulfill her lust, in uncleannes, fornication, drunkennes, wrath, sloth or hatred, as easily as a great load-stone drawes a little needle. O Lord, forgive me my faintnes, in yeelding to a foe so weake, and restore me what she hath ravished from me, that I may fight againe, and with thy help give her the foile.

6. I have receiv'd a frowne, an angrie word, a little wrong, or a light blow from my brother, which in meeknes I might have borne; yet in my rage I have made a quarrell, at which God hath (no doubt) been much displeas'd with me. Therefore I humble now my soule, and beg mercie of thee, O God, the Father of mercie. O save me for thy mercies sake, from my sins past, and prevent the future.

7. O that mine eyes could see the ouglie shape of sin, that so I should loath it! O that I could well consider, that sin hath made hellfire,
and thither drawne Angels and men! Is it not the sole murderer of the immo • tall soule? Is it not the sole cause of Gods hate towards his creatures? Why then have I done this? Why have I ly'd, sworne, cheated, stolne, or fought; since by such things I lose Gods grace, and draw his curse upon my head? Most glorious God, I have in that done as a man shapen in wickednes, and conceived in sin: but doe thou as a God, rich in mercie, abundant in goodnes and truth, and forgiving iniquitie and transgression and sin. Have mercie upon me O God after thy great goodnes; and according to the multitude of thy mercie wash away my grievous offence.

8. Repentance is a salve for the wounds of the soule, a remedie for her diseases, and the very key of heaven: a Jewell too precious to be in mans keeping. It is a gift of God, as all other good things: therefore we should not so sleight it, as to deferre it untill death; for then we may misse it. This very houre is my best time for repentance: the next may be not mine, or if it be, yet my repentance may be gone. It is a sorrow for sins past, and a purpose of amendment. Can I have the first when I will; and use the second, when I die? No, no, my soule. To grieve heartily for thy sins, not onely because thou fear'st punishment; but rather out of love towards thy gracious God,
is a thing harder then men think: then to delay amend • ent untill death, yea but till to morrow, is an argument of folie: for so it seemes, thou art not now readie to die, when yet in an instant thou maist die. O graciou • Lord, let me never be so foolish, as to delay my conversion: but grant, this day I heare thy voice, this minute I repent, and even now begin to lead a vertuous life. So shall I not feare, when death comes, but be cheerfull at her approach. Grant this, O th •• holie, blessed and glorious God.

div.head: His Evening Pray'r.
div.p:
1 THis is the time, in which I will present my selfe and my reasonable service, a living sacrifice, holie, acceptable to God. I owe him my being, actions and possessions, and if they be but such, as may please my Lord and Master, I shall think my selfe a happie Tenant and Servant. But how can I be such, sith I am a sinner? And how can my actions please him, being vicious? I know how to present him both with his approbation. I will wash my foule thoughts, affections, words, actions in the bloud of his Son, beleeving, it was shed for me. Then covering my whole person with this Sons holines, I will thus speak to him. Behold, most holie Spirit, behold, I appeare before thee,
all bathed in Christs bloud, all clothed with his robes. See not my filth thus wash'd, my injustice thus well cov'red: but for him and in him accept graciously my person and indeavours in pietie, and pardon my imperfections, yea wilfull prevarications, and give me strength to serve thee henceforth as I ought, or as I can. Let me no more be divided, or halt between foure opinions: but as I know, that thou art my Lord and my God; so let me follow thee. Away then, malicious Satan, away vaine World, away lewd Flesh: away, away, depart whatsoever may hinder me from adhering unto my God; from serving him, who hath made me; from loving him, who died for my redemption; and from obeying him, who thus sanctifies me, by these and the like good notions, holie motions, vertuous and religious, although weake indeavours; but above all, by a gracious application of Christs originall and actuall holines. Assist me, my good Lord, assist me pow'rfully in my resistance to those things, which withdraw me from thee, and in my search and practice of those meanes, which unite me to thee, who shouldst be my first and chiefe love. O be thou now what thou shouldst be: be thou the desire of my eyes, the delight of my heart, the subject of my thoughts and talkes, the object of my good actions: and let me be thy care. So shall I feare nothing; so shall I wake and sleep secure.

2. Wisdome is good with an Inheritance, but it must be a right wisdome, and a lawfull
inheritance. Not the Wisdome of the World: for, it is folie before God. Not the Wisdome of the Flesh: for, it is enmitie to God. Not the Wisdome of the Wise: for, God shall destroy it, and 'tis a perverting wisdome. Not an Inheritance gotten hastily, because its end shall not be blest, but who swallowes riches, shall vomit them againe. Not an Inheritance acquired by injustice: for, treasures of wickednes profit nothing, and such riches make themselves wings; or are kept for the owners hurt. But it must be the Wisdome of God and an honest Inheritance, descended to us, or purchast by us, by the blessing of God on a diligent hand. This Wisdome then and this Inheritance I beg of thee, O thou Wise and Liberall God! whose power can grant both; whose goodnes can refuse neither. I desire not onely understanding, to handle a matter wisely, all my designes and affaires prudently, and so find good: but also that I may be fill'd with the knowledge of thy will, in all wisdome and spirituall understanding: but first of all, and above all, I beg him, who is thy Wisdome, and in whom are hid all the treasures of wisdome and knowledge; thy Christ and my Jesus. O my God, give him me, without whom I can doe nothing, but ill; I am nothing, but corruption; I have nothing but miserie. Give him wholly to me, that he be my Wisdome, against Folie; my Knowledge, against Ignorance; my
Pow'r, against Weaknes; my Righteousnes, against Injustice; my Holines, against Impuritie; my Redemption from Sin and Hell. Then for him and with him my Wisdome, give me or keep for me a just Inheritance, or instead of inheritance give me sufficient meanes to live sweetly, contentedly, honorably: or if thou deni'st this, give me patience in want, contentment in adversitie, and fortitude in dishonor and paines. And if all these things be not sufficient, give me those graces and blessings he hath commanded me to beg of thee, in this succinct, wise and pious Prayer, which in his name or mediation, I devoutly recite to thee, both for me and all thy Elect. Our Father, &c.

3. It is good for me to draw neere to God, in whose absence is perdition, in whose presence is salvation: yet it is good to be warie in my approach, for there is often danger in boldnes: and an angrie repulse may cause griefe and disgrace. I must then consider, how to make my approach, and where I may find God. But this last question is easily resolv'd: for, God is everie-where. I must then seek him in all things, and will by his owne help doe so. Most high, yet most loving and gracious God, assist me in my search of thee. Teach me to seeke and find thee in all things. Let all visible creatures be to me as faire glasses, to behold thy invisible Essence, eternall Pow'r, infinit Wisdome and rare Excellencie; yet let them be but steps to my soule, to ascend higher, even
beyond all sight, and above Creation, there to contemplate thee in thy selfe before the Creation, and after the Consummation of this visible masse: There let my thoughts be drown'd, my intellect ravisht, and my love eternally fixt. Yet againe let me behold and search thee in him, in whom is the fulnes of thy Divinitie, and in whom thou art sooner found: in Christ, the brightnes of thy glorie, and the expres image of thy person: in Christ, in whom thou art well pleas'd, and in whom onely I am accepted. There, there, let me seeke and find thee, both by him and in him: by him, my way to thee; in him, my propitiation before thee; propitiation for sin, and way of holines. O then in him let me be found, not having mine owne righteousnes, and by him let me approach thee, by that way, he hath shew'd, by those paths, he hath trod. Give me grace to follow after righteousnes, godlines, faith, love, patience, meeknes; knowing, these end in thee. Thus let me approach thee, thus ever be with thee, my blessed God and loving preserver, to whom be glorie for ever.

4. If (as 'tis verie true) all men are members one of another; and all the faithfull one Bodie in and of Christ: how great must their mutuall love be! and how strait their union! Their love should be invincible, their union indissoluble, if they should wisely consider their naturall and Christian relation. But men perish for want of right understanding. The
wise, who, like the Eyes, should look to all the rest of the bodie, lose themselves in fruitles speculations, not descending to the actions necessarie for the members. So are the rich and strong regardles of the poore and weak: and so is our union dissolv'd. May we then be call'd men? Must we be accounted Christians? No, no. Beasts may teach us humanitie, and of Heathen we may learne pietie. O Christ, what disgrace is this to thy glorious Name! Shall it be said, that Turkes are more loving then we? that Papists exceed us in charitable deeds? 'Tis said so, to our shame: yea we know it, and seeme to grieve and blush at it; yet take no care, to prove the contrarie, by a course opposit to that, we have run untill now. O then looke upon us in compassion, for our speedie conversion from dead or cold workes; least our continuation in them, draw suddenly thy angrie lookes, for our swift destruction. Grant, we consider now, but consider heartily and effectually; that sith we are members of one bodie, yea of the best bodie of all, we must diligently performe our severall functions. Let then the wise begin plentifully to communicate their knowledge unto the sillie; the rich, their goods unto the poore; the strong, their help; the great, their protection to the weake and opprest: and let these oppressed, weake, poore, sillie be readie to doe what service they can to their higher members. Thus shall we shew humanitie, and set forth our Christianitie, in doing
these things for thy sake, and according to thy orders: and thus then shall thy Name be known holie and reverend, by our godlie conversation.

5. Sith this Life is full of sorrow, troubles, diseases, cares and sins, how can wise men love it? Beccause their wisdome is not right. Sith 'tis a dangerous peregrination, why doe we wish it long? Because (belike) we have no house or countrie of our owne: for, should we look for that Citie, whose builder and maker is God; desire that Countrie, which is heavenlie, we would make hast thither. That I, yea all Christians doe so, open our eyes, most gracious God, to see the vanitie and miseries of this present life, that our hearts may desire the soliditie and felicitie of the future. Let's consider this world, as a sea full of stormes, our life as a weak ship in it, our soules imbarkt in it, running manie hazards, expos'd to great perils. Then let us indeavour to put in the haven, desire the end of our navigation, and (as holie Paul) wish for our dissolution, that so we be wholy with Christ. Let us boldly look upon Death; for seeing, she hath lost her sting, and the Grave is conquer'd by Christ, why should Christians feare it? Sith mans dayes are numbred, is not our care ridiculous, to put off the last houre? Sith death is but a bed of rest for the bodie, a passage for the faithfull soule unto a happie life, that man seems to denie his faith, who tries to avoid that passage. Rather, O God, let me manifest
mine, by my sincere aversion of this sinfull life, and diligent preparation to the future. If I desire to live, let it be to serve thee, to sanctifie thy Name, and promote thy glorie: which because I cannot doe well: (for, alas! sin abounds, and my transgressions multiplie) let me desire to dye, that I see thy beautie, and enjoy thy glorie, in thy Son the brightnes of it, in whose name I beg it and all things fit for me, calling on thee, as he my Doctor hath taught me. Our Father, &c.

6. Prudent souldiers furnish themselves with all those things, which are necessarie for militarie life. And so must all wise Christians doe. They are souldiers to fight under Christs white colors, and so must have good armes, and (as Paul saith) the whole armour of God: for indeed, no other weapons can serve them in their spirituall war, then those, they have from God their Generall. Seeing then, I am Christs souldier, I must have that armour, and to have it, I must beg it. Thou God of strength, and Lord of hosts, mightie and terrible Spirit, my goodnes and fortres, my high tow'r and deliverer, my shield, and he, on whom I trust; vouchsafe some gracious lookes on me thy weake souldier. I am but a novice; O teach thou then my hands to war, and my fingers to fight. Give me the armour of righteousnes on the right and left hand: on the right, against proud conceits of mine owne righteousnes (a strong
and naturall enemie:) and on the left against all injustice, both active & passive, chiefly against the first: O let me thinke, affect, speak, do no injust thing; and if either Devil or man wil offer me any, gird me with truth, that their strength bow me not unto error, and give me the breast-plate of righteousnes, to blunt the edge of all their darts, resist their tentations, withstand all their assaults. And because these assaults are both frequent and strong, let thy help be like them, least I be overcome. Let me know Satans subtilties, see how he workes 'gainst me, by me; against my present peace and future salvation, by the corruption of nature, lewd inclinations of my heart. Give me then a full sight of my naturall propensions to sin, chiefly of those, which hitherto have drawne me more swiftly from thee. Let me know my weak parts, that I arme and guard them better; watching alwayes, that what brings more delight, profit, honors, make no entrie in me by the help of sensualitie, avarice, ambition; but be repulst by a prudent moderation, a mind admitting no exces of pleasures, riches, dignities. And as Custome is another nature, arme me, my God, arme me (I pray thee) with thy feare against sins of custome: stay me with thy strong hand, least they (like so manie violent streames) carrie me downe into a sea of ills, and at last into hell. Grant, I diligently avoid all occasions of usuall transgressions, and studie day and night all vertues opposit to those vices and sins, to which I am most addicted, by nature or custome.
My soule shall love thee for thy help, and my heart and mouth shall give thee the honor of my deliv'rance, and the whole glorie of my victories.

div.head: His Undressing.
div.p: 1 I Must undresse my selfe, and put off these garments, which vaile my nakednes. Night makes me bold, and I dare doe that in the dark and in privat, which in companie I forbeare. A true picture of hypocrites, who in publick live like Angels, and in secret behave themselves like Devils. Lord, let me not imitate them: but grant, that I studie to be what I would seem. Let vertue, not glorie, be the scope of all my actions.

2. Garments deck the bodie, and load it too: vertue doth not so to the soule; for, 'tis a grace to her, but never a burden. Blessed are they, who never put off such attire. Lord, let me share in their felicitie.

3. Have these my clothes given occasion of offence, either to my selfe, or others? Then forgive it me, gracious God, and grant, that never my garments breed proud▪ thoughts in my heart, nor rash judgements in my neighbours.

4. How light am I now without clothes? Cursed be sin, which forces us to goe so much loaden: and thrice cursed be pride, which hath devis'd so manie sorts of apparell, yea hath
taught us, to exceed means and modestie. How manie men owe for those rich garments, by which they make a vaine shew of riches? I'le goe naked, or clothed with fig-leaves, rather then Shop-keepers should have my name in pawne, for my glorious attire. Here is my suit: who can challenge the lest button of it? Then, good God, I praise thee, because thou hast given me both better meanes, then to manie others; and greater discretion, to clothe my selfe according to my meanes.

5. As I am now, I can run faster, then clothed; and if anie man would wrastle with me, he should find the lesse hold. Indeed a mind free from covetous desires, is more nimble in her course heaven-ward; and who hath nothing here, no gold, houses, lands, goods, yet is content, hath a great advantage over the rich men of this world, who possesse, and yet are possest: possesse riches, and are possest by avarice. If I am rich, Lord, make me wise and free: wise, to rule affection; and free, to doe good with my meanes. If I am penurious; make me laborious and patient: that by labor, I get bread and good things for food; and by patience, overcome hunger, thirst, cold, heat, disgrace and other such, which daily happen to poore men.

6. My present nakednes represents me my past and future state, both in the wombe and
grave: for thence I came naked, and thither shall goe as I am, clothed onely with shirt or sheet. Who carries more, marres the face of the earth, to adorne her intrals; or robs his friends or poore, in the behalfe of wormes, if yet they can feed on such things. As we have no pride in the wombe, we should carrie no markes of it under the tombe. O God, free my s •• le from that odious vice. Let me seriously consider, what this visible part of me was and shall be, a weake thing in the womb, a stinking corps, noisome corruption in the grave. O then let not the soule, that immortall substance, be subject to the sinfull lust of this corruptible flesh, proud of her strength, acti
• itie, beautie; carefull of her wanton ple • sures; but give me a wise heart, to keep her in order; and my whole man in subjection unto thy holy lawes.

7. What have I here? A flea-bit, or a pimple, both markes of corruption. But how dares a flea affront a man, whom God hath made the master of this world, and whose presence should fright the generous Lion, furious Tiger, royall Eagle, and mightie Whale? And how can a pimple rise in that smooth bodie, which had immortalitie in possibilitie? Sin, thou hast made this flea, and bred this spot or heat, to torment me: therefore I abhorre thee, and from this houre will forsake thee. Looke, gracious God, on my resolution, and make it effectuall.

div.head: In Extinguishing his Light.
div.p: 1 THe Light is for the Eye: when then this must be shut, th' other is not necessarie. I'le therefore extinguish this light, because I am readie to sleep, beseeching thee, my God, to pardon my frequent abuse of thy inward and outward light; of thy Inspirations, Word, Sun, Moon, Stars and Fire. Deprive not my soule of the first; not my bodie of eyes, to behold the five last, and in them see and admire thy Wisdome, Power and Love.

2. Pious mens soules are like the fire in a taper of waxe, or in sweet wood. They leave behind them no ill smell, but rather a pleasant odor, a sweet name after them, good examples to their posteritie. Can I say, I am such? Thee, my God, have my thankes, and continue my pietie, to thy glorie, to the good of thy Church, and the honor of my Issue.
3. Wicked mens soules are like the fire in a candle made of tallow. They leave a stink behind, an ill name after them. If I am such, Lord, convert me: if not, let me never be such.

4. Some lights are put out by meere force; and so are men, depriv'd of life by a violent death; and so againe hindred by force to manifest their light. In these, O Lord, give strength against all oppression; give strength in death and in
persecution. Assist the weake against the violent, and give boldnes to thy servants to speake and preach thy truth, to the face and shame of Tyrants.

5. Some lights must vanish for want of matter; and so men dye by age, when their humors are all consum'd; and so againe their gifts are drown'd, and their talents buried, for want of help to keep them up, or dig them out. Is not this want a great defect in our Christian Kingdome? Let, O Lord, our great men and rich persons wisely consider this, and zealously • end it. Let no more children be stifled in the place of birth, for want of strength; no curious and religi
• us wits be still-borne amongst us, because their mother the Countrie and Church wants a politick and religious will and strength, to put forth such blest fruits.

div.head: His Lying downe.
div.p: I Will both lay me downe in peace, and sleep; beleeving, that my God will make me dwell in safetie. Let, Lord, no plague come now nigh my dwelling; but command thy holie Angels, to pitch their tent about this place, to keep off all those things, which may bring harme, and suggest sin. Thou hast made my soule and bodie; O then for thy sake preserve them.

2. As I have left my toilesome workes, and
doe betake my selfe to rest; so let me, gracio •• God, cease from all sin. And, as I trust, that my bodie shall be this night refresht by sleep; so let my soule get strength by sweet meditations.

3. Lord, how manie poore soules lie this night in a ditch and open fields, whilst I in this soft bed an like to enjoy a sweet rest? Let thine eyes beh • ld their distres, and thy hands protect them and me. Give them strength in their paines, and make me thankfull for my ease.

4. Manie worke hard all day, and when night comes, their paines increase, for want of food or rest; whereas I have well supt, and find my selfe dispos'd to sleep, though my labor hath not this day been great. Whence comes this difference 'mongst men, but from their Makers providence, who gives to some th' undeserved blessings of plentie, peace, health, rest; and to others the deserved curses of want, vexation and disease? Yet as these things happen often alike unto good and bad men, who enjoyes the first, cannot account himselfe secure, and the other must not despaire. When thou, O Lord, giv'st me sufficiencie, blesse me also with godlines and temperance; and when thou visit'st me with penurie and affliction, let me have strength and patience: then I'le beleeve, thou lov'st me in either estate, and so I'le praise thy Name, as I doe now, for the ease, thou giv'st me.

5. Some compare sleep to death, and the bed to the grave, and so use persuasions to draw men unto repentance, and to prepare themselves to die, before they goe to bed. I am not of their mind: for, we doe sleep often, and die but once; and in the grave our bodies are corrupt, whereas in beds they are refresht. And were their comparison good, they should admonish us, to make our selves ready in the morning; for, a good life is a good deaths preparation: and he is but like to die ill, who thinkes not on death, till it comes. Yet, as it is better late then never; so these men cannot receive blame, to call on us, when we are neere to die, either in truth, or in figure. Mercifull God, let alwayes my soule be readie; and let death be so farre in my thoughts; that I never offend thee wilfully, and so feare not, when it shall come, whether by day, or night, in young age, or old yeares.

6. In this I thinke, sleep is like death; that as in sleepe good mens minds rest, or are taken by some pleasant and quiet dreames; whereas the covetous, malicious, voluptuous and glutton see what doth defile their bodies, and fright their soules: so after death the first enjoy a blessed rest and infinite pleasures, and the second suffer eternall horrors and torments.
Lord, give me grace, to passe my dayes so well, that my nights be quiet; and live so holily, that after death my soule enter into her Masters joy, thy celestiall Kingdom.

q.l: Though thy Curtaines be drawne close about thee,
Yet forbear sin, beleeving, God doth see
All thy actions, heare thy words, know thy thoughts.
O then scare him, and for thy dailie faults,

div.head: In Shutting his Eyes.
div.p: 1 HAving no light, I may well shut my eyes; and so might I have done before: for, they have been open in vaine; onely to see and delight in much vanitie, stare upon fraile beautie, observe worldlie fashions, reade some idle, wanton, or impious bookes. Thus, thus my God, hath my light been darknes, and my eyes treacherous guides. Let them be no more so, but faithfull servants to the soule; and pardon me their lust and vanitie, and so likewise the sins of all my other senses, whose preservation I doe crave.

2. As I must shut these fleshlie eyes, before I sleep corporally: so I observe, that my intellect must be shut, before Satan lull me asleep in sin. Should that be open to the light, the
light of Gods holie inspirations, the light of his pure word, the light of his promis'd glorie, and above all, the light of his excessive love to me; of which th' other are but effects; I should nere sleep in sin. But it hath not alwaies bin so, & therefore I beg his pardon, who is the Father of mercies. Gracious Father, forgive my transgressions of ignorance and negligence; of a dark intellect, or a negligent mind, to see the light, and walke by it.

3. Have my Eyes done well their dutie both to the flesh and spirit, watchfull over the whole bodie, and diligent to convey to the soule good instructions from the creatures, better from the holie Scripture and other pious bookes? Then I may shut them with comfort, blessing thee, loving God, for the good service of my Eyes: for, it is by thy grace, they have been thus faithfull. Grant, they be daily such, and take thou care of them.

div.head: His Examination.
div.p:
1 HOw have I spent this day? Am I better then I was yesterday? Have I overcome
anie vice? And hath Gods grace been effectuall in me? Then let my soule rejoyce exceedingly, and ascribe to her Lord the glorie of her good actions. 'Tis wholly due to thee, my God: 'tis freely rendred thee l • y me. I acknowledge my progres in vertue, my growth in grace to be effects of thy mercie, fruits of thy love; and beseech thee to continue thy speciall assistance, till thou hast perfected in me thy worke of Sanctification, and begun that of Glorification.

2. In what estate am I? Am I not worse, then I was yesterday? More proud, covetous, envious, injust, cruell, wanton? Have I not resisted Gods grace, derided religion, despis'd goodnes, pietie, truth? Have I not sought occasions of quarrels, gluttonie, drunkennes and all vicious exces? O then what shall I doe, to sleep secure from the provokt wrath of my God? My God? I must not call him so: for, he is not my God. No, no; my bellie is my god: yea, I have now as manie gods as perverse affections unto divers objects. Hono • s, riches, women, are the gods, I have till now serv'd. And must I continue, to acknowledge, adore such gods? I must, unles the true God, he who hath made me pitie me, and break the strong and naturall chaines of folie and wickednes, which tye me to those things. My hope is still on him, and therefore I beleeve, he is not far
from me: for, hope is one of his graces. I will then crie to him: I will incessantly call upon him. My God, heare now my voice: my Lord, regard the desires of my heart. O forsake me not in distres; but assist me against my oppressors. I am sold under sin, the Flesh rules over me, the World • tr ••• es me whither he lists, Satan possesses me: and no meanes of freedome, but by thy Son: for, who hath him not, hath not life; and who hath him, hath life. Then, gracious God, give me thy Son, that my soule live through him. Give me the merits of his life and death, and thus I shall be free from sin and hell. Let him now challenge me, as the price of his bloud; then my tyrannicall masters shall give me libertie. Then my vices shall be succeeded by vertues; drunkennes by sobrietie, avarice by liberalitie, lasciviousnes by chastitie, pride by humilitie; and sin shall give place to thy grace, and so my old man shall be renew it. Let this renovation or change begin now in me; that all men, who know me, may say to the glorie of thy mercie: The right hand of the High hath wrought this mutation. O touch now my hard heart with thy effectuall grace; melt it in griefe to have offended thee; and comfort it with assurance of reconciliation with thee. So shall my sleep be now as sweet, as I may feare it otherwise: and so shall then my soule and flesh rejoyce in thee; loving, praising thee day and night, for their present freedome, and future salvation.

3. I think, this day, I have not done much good, nor ill; but have been at a stand, neither worse, nor better, then I was yesterday. Then I may say, that I have lost the day: and then againe, I am worse then I was: for certainly, who daily, yea hourely, doth make no step forward in his celestiall course, must make one or manie backward; sith there's no stay in that slipperie and steep way. Besides, if we march not cheerfully towards God inviting, yea drawing us upward, the Devill doth pull us downward, seconded in his work by our corrupt nature, which makes his labor more easie. Sith then I find, I have not ascended this day, I must with shame and griefe confesse, I have much descended. And least I descend still, I must and doe now call on thee, my God, to condescend to me, and draw me up againe. O shew thy strength in the weaknes of my nature, and thy goodnes against Satans malice. Draw me, O draw me pow'rfully against all difficulties of flesh and bloud, infernall suggestions, and worldlie baits; by the serious consideration of the future infinit joyes, thou hast prepar'd, to succeed my present sorrowes; and of that eternall reward, thou hast mercifully assign'd, for light labors and afflictions.

4. Good workes are faire tokens of faith; yet works may seem good without faith: such is mans morall honestie, which is of no account
before the searcher of all hearts, though much esteem'd by men. If then this day I have done anie good actions, through naturall inclination, or for ostentation; and forborne to doe ill, perhaps for want of tentation, or occasion: I must look on my selfe, as on a meere naturall man; and upon my actions, as upon specious sins: for, in the commission of good, and omission of ill, other things are requir'd: Knowledge, shewing the legalitie, utilitie and possibilitie of things: Faith, beleeving them pleasant to God. Then the heart must forme the right intention, to commit or omit what's knowne and beleev'd good or ill, for the glorie of his beloved God, in the manifestation of our love, gratitude and obedience to him, by which others be edify'd and invited to the like affection, thankfulnes and service. If in my commissions and omissions those things have been wanting, Lord, forgive me the fault. If they have been present, receive the whole glorie, and that I ne're want them, give them me, I pray thee.

5. Am I in Christ, or in Adam? It concernes me much to know it: for if in Christ, I am alive; if in Adam, as bad as dead. But how shall I find, if I be in Christ, but by searching, whether Christ be in me? And certainly, Christ may be knowne by these few Markes: Knowledge, Faith, Love, Feare, Service, Conformitie
and Submission. If then I Know my God aright, and him, whom he hath sent; Know him after divine revelation, not human imagination. If I truly Beleeve in him, Relie wholly on his mercie and the merits of Christ, for preservation, donation, salvation; preservation of sin and harme, donation of good things, salvation of my whole person, according as he hath promis'd, and not alwaies as I expect. If I Love him sincerely, not according to his infinit merit, but to my best capacitie, above my selfe and all things else. If I Feare him, trembling at the thought of my lest offences 'gainst him, not so much because he can punish me, as because I'le not be ingrat for his loving favors. If I yeeld him the best Service I can, as to my best Master, neglecting all things to please him; yet not serving after mens inventions, but according unto his prescriptions. If I am, as neere as I can, Conforme to the image of his Son, in righteousnes and holines. If I Submit my will to his, as well to drink the bitter cup of affliction, as to savour the sweetnes of consolations; cleaving closely to him in prosperitie and adversitie, I may say with exces of joy, I am in Christ, and Christ in me. If my corruption hinders me yet to say this, O God, pitie thy poore creature, and renew me with speed. But if thy grace hath alreadie been so effectuall
in me, as to blesse me with that Knowledge, Faith, Love, Feare, Service, Conformitie and Submission; O Lord, receive my thankes, and heare my pray'rs: thankes for thy past favors, and pray'rs for the continuation of them. Thou art a God excessive in love, excellent in mercie, abundant in goodnes. In these thou hast begun thy gracious workes in me. O then continue them, and daily perfect them: and let me now take a sweet rest, in the assurance of thy love, and protection of thy power.

div.head: His Night-feares.
div.p: 1 NIght is nothing, but th' absence of the Sun; and darknes, but the privation of light: yet when night comes, it brings with it a kind of feare; not to wild beasts, for then they walk to seek their prey; but unto man, whose conscience is guiltie of manie grievous sins, which come best to his mind, when he's alone and in the dark. Lord, forgive mine, and free my heart from present feares.

2. The night is more quiet, then the day: and yet we feare in it what we doe not regard by day. A Mouse running, a Board cracking, a dog howling, an Owle scritching put us often in a cold sweat. What is the cause of it? Sin committed by light. When the Sun shines, and we are with our friends, we drink
iniquitie like a sugred portion, delighted with the present sweetnes of sin; but not fearing its future bitternes. But when night hath drawn her black vaile, and we are about to take rest; then the potion begins to work, and puts us into distemper. O Lord, whilst mine eyes see the Sun, let my mind behold thee; and whilst I am with my fellowes, let my heart talk with thee, never thinking my selfe secure enough, to displease thee, in the lest thing. So shall not my soule be afraid for the terror by night, nor for the pestilence, which walketh in darknes.

3. Doe we feare more by night, then by day, because Satan is call'd the Ruler of darknes? Then we mistake St Pauls meaning: for he beleeved not, that Satan had power to rule over outward darknes, by bringing or removing light: but he calls him Ruler of the darknes of this world, to shew his pow'r over worldlings, whose understanding being darkned, they are alienated from the life of God, through the ignorance and blindnes of their hearts. Against such children of darknes Satan beares a great sway both night and day: but he can doe no harme to the children of light, either by day or night, unles God gives him leave. Let me, O Lord, never feare him, but make me strong to resist his assaults; and grant, I trust under thy wings, and abide under thy shadow.

4. As man is man, he may well feare; but as he's Christian, he should not: for, he must know, that nothing can happen to him, but what his God ordaines. Now if he hath a true feeling of Gods love to him-ward, he shall beleeve, the Lord will look to him, as a carefull mother to her beloved child. Lord, let me feare to offend thee, then live secure from all bodilie harmes.

5. Who keeps me, slumbers not, and who made me will suffer nothing to marre me, but for his glorie and my good: yet I grow sad at this conceit, start at this noise, and shiver at this sight: because (doubtles) I see not, how neere me the Lord is. Had I some light, and were my friends by me, I should but smile at this, which makes my whole bodie tremble. But O blind heart! is not God more pow'rfull then man, and faith brighter then anie outward light? O God, quicken my faith, that I trust in thee as I ought, and remove now from me the present cause of feare.

6. 'Tis said, Lions lose their courage, if some thing be cast on their eyes: and so manie men doe, when they are in darknes. A strong token of their spirituall blindnes: for, he's inwardly blind, who feares mor • by night, then by day; n •• he sees not, that God is at all times alike pow'rfull, to protect his servants.
Then this likewise figures, that when sin (the soules night) hath spread over her its darknes, she is seised with great terrors. Keep me, good Lord, from all blindnes of heart, and darknes of understanding; that though my outward eyes be shut, or deprived of light; yet I want neither faith in thy providence, nor knowledge of thy mysteries, and of mine owne dutie. Keep me also (I beseech thee) from Satans illusions, fearfull visions, assaults of men, nocturne feares and all harme.

div.head: His Dreames.
div.p: DReames, which proceed from repletion or emptines of the bellie, or follow manie cares, ought the lest to be regarded: onely they should instruct us to cut off the cause, that the effects may cease. Lord, teach me temperance both in diet and cares, that no vaine dreames trouble my rest.

2. Our nightlie dreames follow often our daylie affections and occupations. As these are, those shall be. The covetous tels in his sleep his coine, finds a treasure, increases his riches, or loses of his store. The voluptuous dreams of his cheere and whores; the angrie man, of quarrels and fightings; the cheater, of tricks and deceits; the ambitious, of new honors. But those, whose daylie thoughts are godlie and
harmles, find in their rest pleasant conceits. Let me, O God, so live by day, that I rejoyce by right; and so order my affections and thoughts, that my dreames fright me not.

3. I am often troubled by dreames of losse, danger and death, either of my selfe or my friends. And contrariwise I thinke sometimes in sleep of riches, honors and mariage; yea I doe often foresee things: but there is no trust in such dreames, unles they come to us by Gods revelation. Yet we may from them take warning, to looke better unto our selves, friends, goods, least that through negligence happen, of which we dream'd. Lord, give me • it to discern true dreames from the false: and when it shall please thee, to shew me by them anie thing, • each me their interpretation; and grant, that I ever •• eight those, which are vaine, and agree not with thy cord and human reason.

4. This was an illusion; for in my sleep I thought, I did enjoy the thing, I love: but now being awake, I find, 'twas but a dreame. Yet because I have done what argues wantonnes, covetousnes, revengefull mind, &c. I beseech thee, my God, to forgive me my daylie negligence, which is (doubtles) the cause of these nocturne pollutions, worldlie thoughts, or bloudie plots in sleep.

5. This was a pleasant dreame. I thought I was in heaven in a mo • t blessed state: but now
I find my selfe a bed, like enough to undergoe manie crosses, before I goe thither; yea i • danger to misse the way. Therefore let my Lord pitie me, and so still fill my heart with holie thoughts & dreams, that seeking those things, which are above, and mortifying my members, which are on earth, I may at my death be receiv'd into that glorious light and infinit pleasures, on which I did now dreame.

6. This was a fearfull dream. I was dying, and neer me stood Satan readie to snatch away my soule, for my grievous offences. I yeelded my selfe lost; for, I could neither plead not guiltie, nor intreat for mercie. Now that by Gods grace I live still, shall I take this for a meere dreame, or rather for a good warning, to mend my wicked life, and for my sins relie on Christs passion? Jesus, grant, I doe this. I know, I may die, whilst I sleep, and I confesse, I deserve hell: yet call me not at unawares, neither denie me thy mercie.

div.head: His Night-waking.
div.p: I Am awake, but 'tis not time to rise, neither have I yet slept enough. Therefore I beseech thee, my God, to blesse me againe with sweet sleep.

2. I am awake, yet not in paine, anguish or feare, as thousands are, and for that, gracious Lord, I offer thee my praises and prayers; praises
for me, and prayers for me and others. Continue thy favors to me, extend thy compassions on all persons in affliction.

3. I am awake by the barking of a dog, or crowing of a cock, a beast and fowle, which teach me vigilance. Lord, give me what they teach: make me vigilant in human affaires, but redouble my vigilance in religious duties.

4. While I doe wake, I must not lose my time: yet what can I doe in the dark? Speake to my God, meditate on his Law. Lord, grant, I now doe so. Fill my mind with good thoughts, and my heart with holie desires.
5. Manie go to bed in health, and there are found dead. I praise thee, my good God, for that it hath not been my case, and beseech thee, that it never be such.

6. Some wake to plot or act mischiefe. Such, O great God, convert by thy goodnes, or oppose by thy pow'r, chiefly those who devise the ruine of the fatherles, widow, stranger and poore; the destruction of their countrie, suppression of thy truth, confusion of thy Church.

7. Some wake for the good of others, either meditating upon their beds, how they can help the poore, comfort the afflicted, assist the oppressed, defend the State, promot truth, learning, pietie: or being alreadie in action about anie of these. The good God favour these good men,
the God of love be with these loving soules, and give their designes good succes.

8. Heark, Peter! the Cock crowes: nay heark, my soule! for, the case concernes thee. Thou art as bad, but not so good as he. He deny'd his Lord thrice: Canst thou say, thou hast done no more? No, my Christ, I cannot: yet I can say, thou art still mercifull, and canst convert me by a gracious look. Doe it, my good Lord, I pray thee, and with the remembrance of those indignities and pains, thou didst endure for me, in the last night of thy mortall life, make me weep bitterly, repent truly, and love thee sincerely; so that I denie thee no more.

9. How silent are all things? It was in such silence, that Christ was borne to us. God loves quietnes, and therefore comes to us, when we are still. O Lord, rebuke the winds, both of passions and tentations, which disquiet my heart; that thou be borne, and sleep in it.
This Daylie Devotion hath 500. Meditations and Pray'rs.
