div.head: HERBERTS QUADRIPARTIT DEVOTION. For the Day, Week, Month, Yeare. THE SECOND PART. FOR THE WEEK, In the Sanctification of the Lords Day.
His Morning Pray'r for the Lords Day.
div.p:
GOod being communicative, and thou, O God, the soverain good, it pleased thee, to manifest thy love, wisdome and pow'r, in the creation of all things. And because the light is a meane, to see and discerne corporall objects, this light was the first of thy distinct workes: that so man the last to be made might see what thou hadst created for him, and likewise learne, that light must precede his actions, yea guide him in all his cogitations and affections. So
when the worke of our Redemption was finisht, thou, O Father, didst raise thy Son, the Sun of righteousnes, that by the beames of his glorie, Christians should see and beleeve it. That Light and this Sun appear'd first this day, which for that cause is the first in nature, and in our religion. It is then a great day, it isSee my Catechisme to the 4. Commandement. a holie day, if not in it selfe, yet to me. I will make it holie, by making my selfe such. But, O my God, this speech is presumptuous: for, Holines is thine. It proceeds from thee, and returnes to thee. Thou, thou onelie establishest mans heart unblamable in holines. Thee then onely I beseech to make me holie. Sanctifie all my thoughts, affections, words, actions. Help me to withdraw the two first from my worldlie affaires, and fix them upon thee, the glorious Maker of the world, and gracious Redeemer of man: then let my words be of thee and to thee, and my workes holie before thee. O let my thoughts be drownd in thee, who art so mightie in wonders, yea wonders wrought for me. Let my affections be wholy on thee, for the exces of thy Christ in my Redemption. Great Creator, I praise thee in thy noble workes. Gracious Saviour, I will sing thy excessive love, thy tender compassions. Mightie Spirit, I submit my person to thee, by whom I have been made, and manie things for me. Here I vow thee a perpetuall service; and here, most loving God, I offer thee a pure, intire and constant love, or at lest, a desire of such. I desire to love thee purely, intirely,
constantly, and therefore beg of thee the sweet effect of my desire. As thou hast been my onelie Creator and Redeemer, be thou my onelie Love; Let me love none but thee, or none but for thee and in thee. Let my holie actions, religious words manifest the sinceritie of my love towards thee, walking this day, yea all my life, as a child of the day, a child of light, made by thee and for thee, the wise Maker of this visible light, and mightie Raiser of Christ from the dead: to whom with thee and the most holie Spirit, one omnipotent Creator and mercifull Saviour, be service and glorie, by me and all thy workes of Creation and Redemption. Amen.

div.head: At the hearing of Bels.
div.p: THese Bels call me to the Congregation. Indeed this is the day, in which we use to meet, in the place appointed, for Gods publick worship. I will therefore make me readie, to be one of the first, who shall tread the treshold of Gods house, and bow both heart and head before his majestie, to praise his Name for benefits receiv'd, call upon him for grace, and heare his word for instruction. Let me, gracious God, doe all this, to thy glorie and my comfort.

2. This day is the first of the week, and therefore fit to be dedicated to God and devotion:
for, who made man may justly challenge his first fruits. Besides, upon this day Christ did rise from the dead, in a glorious estate, after the painfull work of the redemption of mankind; and therefore we make it holie by prayer, reading and preaching. We forbeare likewise servile workes, unles they be necessarie; much more all sinfull words, actions and thoughts, unles they be pressed on us by the force of some tentation, or received by us through the weaknes of our nature. O good God, let my soule so celebrate this day, in a vertuous and holie rest, that all the week may prove happie, both for the flesh and spirit.

3. This is the last ringing: I will therefore make hast, least pray'rs be ended, ere I come. Sermons are good, and prayers are good too, chiefly such pray'rs, as are contain'd in grave and godlie words, and uttered with zeale by a religious man, and hearkned unto with devout attention, by the faithfull congregation. Lord, let me love to beare thy word both read and preacht, and speak to thee by praises and prayers, in the assemblie of thy Saints, and the presence of thy angels, as now I meane to doe, by the help of thy Spirit.

4. I doe amisse. 'Tis unlawfull to carrie burdens, both this day and unto this place: yet I perceive, I am loaden, yea with those
things, which God and mens lawes disallow. All the week past, I have made a great bundle of transgressions, both against God and men; and now shall I bring it before God and his Saints, to draw his heavie wrath upon my sinfull head? No, no. I'le cast downe my burden, and least I fall with it, I pray thee, graci
• us Lord, to lend thy helping hand, and with the sword of thy Spirit cut off the bonds, which tie me unto sin. O wash away my transgressions, in the bloud of thy Son, make me sorie for them, and cleanse me throughly from them all; that so with a new and pure heart, I enter now into thy house.

div.head: His Entrie into the Temple, and Going to his Seat.
div.p: I Must settle my countenance, and with respect behave my selfe both inwardly and outwardly, without wandering mind or eyes: for here I walke in the speciall presence of that great God, whose hands have made heaven and earth, and whose eyes search the hearts of men. O that he accept mine, and make it such, as may ever please him!

div.head: Without a Seat.
div.p: To prevent rash condemnation for this Meditation, I send my Reader to S. James; for, my justification is in his second Chapter.

HOw came these inclosures in our common pasture? Who hath made these close seats, these pewes with locks? Judges of evill thoughts, Respecters of persons. Partialitie hath adjudg'd them for the chiefe of the Church, for them, who weare a gay clothing, & have gold rings, or at lest a piece of money for the Sexton or other officers. Be they wise or foolish, pious or ungodlie; yet they are the chiefe of the Church, if they be rich and in fine cloths, or have more boldnes then the rest. Then these lockt pewes are not for me; and then againe, I must goe to another Church, or stand here in the crowd, hoping to sit shortly in Gods glorious Kingdome. Answer my hope, O Lord; that in the assurance of my future exaltation, I regard not the lowlines of my present estate, and despis'd condition.

div.head: In his Seat.
div.p:
HAve I here more room then I need? Then I will admit those, who stand there in the
throng, and have (for ought I know) as much right in this Seat as I. It is an odious pride to God, his Angels and good men, if I, under pretext of my riches or bloud, sit here alone, as a King amongst these, who yet in grace may excell me, and have greater naturall gifts then I. Great God, whose thoughts are not like ours, suffer me not to have the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ with respect of persons: but grant, I love and honor the poore of this world, chiefly those, I know rich in saith, and so heires apparent of thy glorious Kingdome.

div.head: His Adoration.
div.p: WIth my whole man I adore thee, O God most glorious and pow'rfull! I thanke thee for thy benefits, beg pardon for my sins, devotion for this time, attention to thy word, grace for my life, help at my death, and glorie after death.

div.head: Before Prayers.
div.p: O Lord, teach me to pray. Let thy holie Spirit kindle within my breast the flames of devotion. Keep my mind attentive to what shall be read and said here; give me a livelie faith, that I obtaine of thee whatsoever I shall now aske, and grant the same to all this people.

div.head: Before the Chapters.
div.p: O Earth, earth, earth, heare the word of the Lord. Thou man of earth, and dweller on the earth, heare the word of the Lord of heaven and earth, of that great Lord, who if thou wilt heare well, and keep his word on earth, shall shortly transplant thee from earth into heaven.

div.head: After the Chapters.
div.p: LEt me, O Lord, never forget these instructions; but grant, I put them in practice, as occasion shall serve.

div.head: Before the Commandements.
div.p: LIsten, my soule, listen; thy God begins to speak. Lose not one of his words; for, they are all precious. That I lose none, O Lord, open my eares, give me understanding, prepare my heart to obedience.

div.head: After the Commandements.
div.p:
THis is, O God, this is thy Law; a hard saying to corrupt man, a honey-comb to the regenerat.
Let it be such to me. Grant, I may truly say: O how love I thy Law! O let it be my meditation all the day, my delight all my life, and forgive graciously my transgressions of it.

div.head: After the Creed.
div.p: GRant, O God, I beleeve all this, and whatsoever else is fit, I should beleeve. O let never human reason, divellish cunning, worldlie ends, nor desire of life obscure true faith in me, or make me fall from it.

div.head: At the Singing of Psalmes.
div.p: LEt my voice praise thee, glorious God: yet let my melodie be without vanitie. Accept my song, and free my heart from pride.

div.head: Against Distractions or wandering Thoughts in time of Prayers and Reading.
div.p:
1 WHat things are these, which draw my attention from God? Away you idle thoughts, here is no roome for you. Shall my tongue pray, whilst my mind doth wander? Then the Lord will not regard me. And shall my bodie be at Church, whilst my heart is at home, or in the fields, or perhaps in worse
place? Then my God will judge me. Help th •• therefore good Lord, to call now my heart in, and so fix it on thee, that it wander no more.

2. How light are human minds, and how inconstant unto good? I cannot keep mine long upon what is here read, but it flies out to view the world, or order some affaires abroad. But in this I offend, and therefore crave pardon of thee, O thou wise God, who know'st what is in man; and helpe from thee, who art only pow'rfull to scatter these vaine thoughts, and fill my heart with godlie conceptions.

div.head: Against Distractions in Sermon-time.
div.p: 1 WHat was I thinking now? Perhaps the Devill knew, that what the Minister had to say was able to move me to some vertue, or divert me from some familiar vice: and therefore he hath put a toy in my braine, to make me lose wholesome counsels. He shall doe so no more. I'le watch my mind, that it stray not, and pray God to free me from all foolish and wandring thoughts. So doe thou, my good Lord, and grant, I learne in this Sermon what may better my faith and life.

2. My mind is gone againe, and being swifter then the Sun, hath viewed far countries, whilst it should have remained here, to
listen to this man. What meanes to keep it in, for, it is out in a moment? Unles God help, it is a thing beyond my pow'r. Then, O Lord, assist me, and blesse me with a settled mind and carefull attention unto the words of thy servant.

3. If all this peoples minds wander as much as mine, this man may well direct his speech unto these stones: for indeed in preaching unto us in our distractions, he speakes to none better then stones; since we receive his instructions no more then these pillars. So our hearts are stonie, in which the good seed of Gods word can take no root at all. Then, Lord, I beseech thee, to take away my stonie heart, and give me one of flesh, easie to be till'd by thy labourers, soft to receive the seed, and fat to yeeld increase.

div.head: Considerations upon the Minister and his Sermon.
div.p: If anie of Christs Ministers be such as those, I commend here, let him glorie and rejoyce in the Lord: but if he be guiltie of anie of those faults, which I censure, let him studie a correction of his imperfections, and love me for telling the truth. This truth I love, and doe gladly manifest it on all just occasions; and God forbid, his peculiar servants should hate me for my paines.

1 THis man speaks verie well. He hath a good and fluent tongue, and (which is commendable)
his hands are as good, as his tongue. He is a man who preaches as he lives. He's none of those who lay heavie burdens on mens shoulders, which they themselves will not move with one of their fingers: but like Jesus the Son of God, he does, and teaches what is needfull for himselfe and others. By his good works, he makes his calling and election sure; and by his godlie instructions, he shewes his flock the way to happines. Blest be the Lord, in the gifts of this his servant, and let his goodnes send manie such labourers into his great harvest.

2. This is an honest man: yet his knowledge is either small, or he wants expression. His life is holie and blameles, but his wit's somewhat slow, and his utterance unpleasant. Yet if he say more, then I practise daily; if his doctrine be sound, and his counsels wholesome, what have I to doe with the rest? He's not there, to tickle my eares, but to convert my soule. O God! let me not seeke in thy servants, the inticing speech of mans wisdome, but the plaine evidence of the Spirit and of pow'r.

3. This is a man, who with curious conceits, choice words and strong reasons could persuade anie thing, were not his deeds contrarie to his words: but who will beleeve him preaching sobrietie, when he's seldome sober; exhorting others to mildnes, being a severe
man; teaching frugalitie, whilst he's lavish; bountie, being a wretch; or plaine dealing, when he deceives others, and owes more then he can render? Who by his persuasions can live quietly with his neighbours, since he's alwaies at strife with his Parishioners, for things of no moment? Who? All may, and I will. As long as his doctrine is Christian, and his counsels morall, we have Christs owne warrant to obey him. I will doe what he bids, but forbeare what he does. Shall not then souldiers fight, because drummers fight not, but invite them to the combat: or shall I lie down in the road, or go back to my house; because he, who shewes me the way, goes not along with me? He goes perhaps another way, or he's not yet readie to begin his journie. Let, O good God, my soule shun the ill examples, and follow the godlie counsels of such men as I heare, this is: and if it be thy blessed will, Lord, make him see the errors of his life, and convert him to another; but let not his ill courses draw me from pietie.

4. The Minister is out, his memorie hath deceiv'd him, some wandering thought hath made him lose his place. Help him, O God, least hame put him out more and more, and anie man thinke him the worse, for what happens sometimes to verie learned men.

5. This man reads his Sermon; which thing
manie dislike, yet 'tis nothing to them. For my part I care not, whether his eyes be on his book, or on anie thing else. They are nothing to me. His tongue is the lim, I observe, and I weigh his words, not his lookes. Yet if his reading doth proceed from sloath, not from want of time, or weaknes of memorie, make him, O Lord, more painfull in divine studies, and more carefull to please his flocke.

6. Some think, this man preaches not his owne words, but that he steales other mens inventions. If he doth so, what's that to me, as long as he preaches good things? I am perhaps obliged to him, for his theft; since belike his conceits and sermons should not be so good, as those, he borrowes. Lord, let nothing hinder my profit under him, or such as he's: and if be take other mens workes for need, give him a copious wit; and if for sloath, give him that diligence, which his calling requires.

7. This speech is for that man: there the Minister hath him right. Doth he not blush at this? Nay rather, he might blush or laugh at my folie, if he should know my present thoughts: for, do I know the Preachers mind, and am I to judge that person? No, no, my God, pardon me therefore my rashnes, and if that man is guiltie of the thing, of which the Preacher speakes, let him now bewaile it, and ever after forbeare it: and
as for me, Lord, keep me from the like.
8. This is for me: my conscience is guiltie of this. O then good God, give me sorrow for what is past, and fortitude against all future occasions of displeasing thee in this thing.

9. How thin is this Congregation? Yet the Parish is large and full enough. Is it then the Ministers fault? Is he careles or incapable to feed his flock? Or are his sheep wearie of their pasture, though good, and of their Pastor, although Orthodox? If either of these be the cause, remove it, Lord, I beseech thee, either giving abilitie and diligence to the Shepherd, or if he hath these alreadie, making his flock adhere to him, and forsake strange and false teachers.

10. How full this Temple is! Yea what throng at the doores; and climbing up at the windowes! Is it because the Preacher is an able man in true learning and pietie? or that these will not endure the sound doctrine of their Pastors, but after their owne lusts, heap to themselves teachers, which please their itching eares with new doctrines or lights, fabulous inventions, damnable heresies, and devillish blasphemies? If the first cause drawes together this auditorie, let, O Lord, this man be still well follow'd, or indue all other Pastors with the same gifts. But if he be one of these last teachers, and these hearers such, as turne their eares from the truth unto fables,
recall them, O God, I pray thee, recall and convert them againe to the love of forsaken truth.

11. This man hath a low voice, or will not set it out, and so is he not fit for this great assemblie; to manie of which he preaches in vaine: sith they cannot heare distinctly his words. In this case may be well allow'd commutations of Benefices. Howsoever, I judge that man guiltie of presumption, who without great necessitie undertakes an office, he cannot well discharge, either through ignorance, negligence or weaknes. And I esteem those men careles of their soules food, who with an ungodlie patience will gape two houres on a silent Preacher, if they can find one, who speakes out the words of truth and pietie with zeale. Let me, O Lord, be none of these careles hearers, and let no more low voic'd Teachers intrude themselves into such large bodies, ample congregations; but be confin'd into places of lesse capacitie, where their words be not lost, their discourses fruitles, by the defect of a strong voice, or of pure zeale to put it forth.

12. How high and profound is this man? Who can dive into his matters, soare after his loftie language? Pietie may have a fine dresse, Divinitie may be adorn'd, but not so disguis'd, that it be not knowne. He preaches himselfe, and not Christ, who speakes above
the ordinarie capacitie of his Christian auditorie. There are too manie such Preachers, and that there be none, vouchsafe, gracious God, to shew the vanitie of all things without thee, even to those, who ought to preach downe vanitie, and teach selfe-deniall.

13. What strange faces doth this man make, and what ridiculous postures hath he? Is he in travell of the truth, and so in sorrow, till she be brought forth? But such faire Child should not be usher'd by anticks. These indecent gestures disgrace such noble birth. Let this man know so much, O Lord, and so compose his countenance to the gravitie of his profession, holines of his vocation, that his unseemlie behaviour hinder not his spectators to be attentive to the sound doctrine.

14. This man is mov'd, and moves: he speakes with zeale, and so kindles a divine fire in the hearts of his auditorie, suiting his voice and his modest postures to the matters, of which he speakes. Heare, how loud he thunders against infidelitie and sin! how highly he commends faith and good workes! How lovingly and earnestly he exhorts and rebukes! Let not, Lord, his strength faile, but make his lungs as good as his heart is, and give the like good hearts and lungs to all our Ministers.

15. How cold this Preacher is, or seemes to be! Ought the quick & pow'rfull word of God
to be so coldly deliv'red? Shew him, my Lord, that it must not be so. When yet 'tis so, let me not take it so, but receive it with joy and savour of the Spirit.
16. This is an excellent doctrine, a wittie and pious observation, a sweet application. Lord, let me not lose it, but print it in my heart, and so likewise in all the rest of this congregation.

17. Some say, this man walkes in craftines, and handles the word of God deceitfully, serving the time, and respecting persons. I must then heare him warily, and wisely examine whatsoever he sayes. My God, let all the rest doe so: and if this man be such, make him walke and speak in sinceritie.

18. What's this? An error, heresie or blasphemie, if I be not deceiv'd. O my God, stop that mouth, or let it recant these false words: or at lest, let them be all lost, not receiv'd or beleev'd by us; and suffer not, thy pure word be corrupt, thy holie word blasphem'd by its owne Ministers, thy truth eclips'd by those, who should manifest it.

19. The Proverb, Short and sweet, is now true in this man. He hath in few and sweet words delivered manie pious matters for instruction, exhortation, dissuasion, consolation, condemnation. Lord, I praise thee in him, and pray thee to send manie such, for the good of thy Saints.

20. How willing is the people to goe out,
and how manie sleeping and yawning persons this Preacher hath made with his long prayers & tedious Sermon! I wish, that both he & all such would consider, that Sermons and Prayers are not esteem'd good by their length, but that rather they lose often their grace and fruit by it, and their maker his thankes. Yet, Lord, let not my devotion be cool'd by long actions of religion, nor thy ambassadors marre their message by vaine repetitions, confounding, for their ease, the memorie of their hearers, by neglected method and careles expressions; or dulling their spirits by their prolixitie.

div.head: Against Wearines.
div.p:
I Am wearie: then my soule be sorrie, for this argues great want of grace. Wouldst thou be wearie at a play, or at thy Princes court, when the King should vouchsafe to talk friendly with thee about thine owne affaires? And what are the sports of a Play, or the pompes of the Court, with the smiles of a King; to the honor, thou dost receive in conversing with that great God, who makes dust of all Kings? Besides, if thou beest wearie here for two hours at the most, in singing, praying, and hearing, what wouldst thou doe for ever in heaven? since there they sing continually, Holie, holie,
holie Lord God Almightie. Good God, forgive my wearines, and remove the causes of it, that cheerfully I see the end of this present service.

div.head: Against Drowzines.
div.p: FRom whence proceeds this drowzines, but from ungodlines? I am sleepie, yet not for want of sleep, but of true devotion. The Devill feares, I please my God this day, and that he blesse me so, that I never follow his wicked suggestions: therefore he casts a slumber in my eyes, that by my drowzines I bring on me my Fathers curse, in stead of his blessing. Then wake my soule: shake off this heavines, and open both thy heart and eyes for the faithfull discharge of thy present dutie; and thou, O God, make me light and cheerfull in thy praises and in my pray'rs.

div.head: When there is a Mariage.
div.p:
HAth reason or passion made this match? Will these marrie to multiplie their kind, or to fulfill their lust? If they have this foule end, forgive them, Lord, I beseech thee, and rectifie their intentions. O let them not by unchast behaviour and unquiet life dishonour their honorable state; but joyne them now with the indissoluble bonds of a holie and
perfect love; and, Lord, blesse them with health and wealth, least the want of either make that soure unto them, which in godlines, strength and plentie may prove most sweet.

div.head: When there is a Christening.
div.p: THere is a little man, who hath got a spot in the womb, and therefore is he brought hither to be washed with that water. But can that element cleanse it? No, yet 'tis a holie signe of the bloud of Jesus, through which onelie such spot is washt away. O God! let this Infant receive now from thy majestie the full remission of its sin, and a renovation of that divine image, which Adam did deface both in himselfe and us: and when 'tis growne, let not its sin revive in it unto its damnation; but grant, it may resist that ill disposition we contract all from our parents.

div.head: When there is a Churching.
div.p: HEre's a woman, who after her late lying in, comes to acknowledge Gods mercie in her preservation. Good Lord, receive her thankes. Restore her her full strength: blesse her in the Child, she hath borne, or if it be alreadie dead, comfort her in her losse. Forgive her sins, root out her lust, and indue her with all vertues.

div.head: When there is a Catechising.
div.p: WHat's man without knowledge, knowledge without religion, and religion without good workes? The first is as a beast, the second but a flash, and the last but hypocrisie. Therefore our holie Church takes order, her children be well taught what doth concern their salvation. Faith and good works are committed to their memories, and commended to their practice. Good Lord, make these children susceptible of this wholesome doctrine; inlighten their understandings, to conceive divine mysteries; inflame their hearts, to love vertue; and strengthen their weaknes, to performe their dutie.

div.head: When there is a Confirmation.
div.p: THese Children had at their Baptismes sureties for beliefe and good life. Now being come to age, they will confirme what their friends promised for them. Behold, O Lord, their good resolution: powre a true faith into their hearts, that they hold still the word of life; and with thy grace strengthen their wils, that as thy blest children, they live pure and without rebuke.

div.head: When there is a Buriall.
div.p: HEre is a spectacle of our mortalitie, a looking-glasse of human miserie, a warning to a godlie life, and a remedie against sin. Here is the earthlie part of man, a feast for wormes, a bootie for the grave. What is become of th' other part, of that noble forme of this corps, of that excellent soule, whose presence made this flesh lovelie, and by whose absence 'tis loathsome? She's fled away to a blessed or cursed place, where Gods endles and gratuit joyes shall reward her vertues, or his perpetuall and well deserv'd torments punish her vices. Ought I not, Lord, to dye as well as this? Must not my flesh be turn'd to corruption? Why then •• e I dallie with her, and make her so wanton; that be may worke my damnation? O strengthen me against her allurements, give me the upper hand of her, and let me have an antidote against her infection, that when she is as this is now, my soule be blest with thy glorious vision, till in the day of the resurrection this flesh rise againe to glorie, having put on incorruption and immortalitie.

div.head: When an Excommunication is denounc'd.
div.p: ALas poore man! what hast thou done? Either thy fault must be grievous, or thy wilfulnes great; since it forces thy good mother, to shut thee out of her house, and denie thee the food and help, she affords her other children. Thou art in an ill case; for, now Satan beares such sway over thee; that he may keep thee still in thy wilful contempt, or bring thee to despaire, unles God be thy help. Thou, Lord Jesu, the great Shepherd of the sheep, seek quickly this stray'd one, and bring her againe to thy fold, that we may all rejoyce with thee.

div.head: When anie does Penance.
div.p: THis man confounds Satan; for, having got a fall by his treacherie, he foiles him now by publick repentance: and so he deserves praise and applause of us all, for his notable victorie. And because it is thy right hand, O God, the strength of the faithfull, which hath rais'd up this penitent sinner, and brought him out of hell, let our congregation praise thee, and his soule love thee for ever.

div.head: When the Excommunicated person is Absolv'd.
div.p: I Think, I heare the good woman our common mother the Church calling her friends or children together, to rejoyce with her, for the finding of her lost piece. She had thrust out of her heaven, yea of Gods heaven too, this soule for weightie causes; but lo, seeing himselfe in want, he is come to himselfe, and confessing his faults is receiv'd with kisses by his loving father, and with imbracements by his tender mother. Let such mother be ever blest, and such father ever lov'd, fear'd and serv'd by me, this person and all men.

div.head: When there's a Breeve.
div.p: FIre or water, robbers or stormes have made these men publick beggers. Had I part in their losse, how glad were I to receive help? Then I must be willing to afford it to them. Therefore for the love of Jesus, who being rich became poore for my sake, I will out of my abundance supplie their present want. Lord, receive at my hands a small portion of thy earthlie blessings.

div.head: When there's a Collection.
div.p: THese men doe gather for the poore what pitie moves rich men to spare for their brethren. Is my store great? Then my reliefe shall be answerable. Are my meanes small? Then my gift must be like. Here is, my God, what cheerfully I give, to help thy poore members. Accept my willing mind, and give me a blessing for this, though I confesse, 'tis a blessing from thee.

div.head: After the Service.
div.p: NOw all is done, and everie man retires: yet I will not goe hence, unles God come along with me. 'Tis not in houses made of stone, that he delights to dwell; but in the hearts of men. Come then, my Lord, take mine for thy dwelling, for, I dedicate it to thee. Let the good motions and notions, I have received here be my waiters and helps, to intertaine thee royally. And that thou find nothing, which may displease thine eyes, I leave here all the sins, I have committed these two houres; yea since I was conceiv'd in sin. Take them from me, good God, and impute them unto thy Son, for, he onely is able to beare them. O love me for his sake, and for his obedience to death never depart from me.

div.head: His going from the Church.
div.p: HOw shall I spend the rest of this day? Shall I goe to heare more Sermons? I feare, I shall heare more, then I can remember. I will practise what I have learn'd, then take a new lesson. Shall I then play, and recreate my mind, by some harmles pastime? I have no mind to play, and this day is not fit for playes. I have been with God in his house, I would see his Son too. But where is he? The prison, hospitall, or some sick persons house may help me to the sight of him. There, there I will seek thee, O Christ, the Son of man; knowing, that in visiting and relieving thy poore members, thou wilt take upon thee what for thy sake I shall doe unto them. Give me meanes to help their bodies, and good words to comfort their soules.

div.head: With the Prisoners.
div.p:
HAd not these soules abus'd their libertie, they might enjoy it still; but the riot of some, and violence of the others have brought them to this wofull place. I, who come now to visit them, might have been one of their number, had not the Lord blest me with wit to manage mine estate, and with an upright
mind to wrong no man in bodie, name and goods, and likewise kept me from false hearts or evill chances; for some are in prison guiltles of that, which is laid to their charge. I thanke thee then, O God, my preserver, for my present freedome, humbly desire the continuation of it, and earnestly intreat, thou wilt be with these prisoners, to give them all sorrow for their past transgressions, patience in their present affliction, and wisdome and goodnes in their future libertie. And if here are anie, who must dye shortly for their crimes, Lord, let them be as that good thiefe, who confessed his wickednes, and thy righteousnes, mercie and pow'r; that in their humble confession and livelie faith, thou maist remember them, and receive them into thy paradise.

div.head: With the Sicke.
div.p:
HE was a right Disciple of Christ, who was sick with the sick; sick in his mind, with the sick in their flesh, sorrowfull for their paines, vext for their afflictions; for, Christ himselfe, as the head of that mysticall bodie, of which we are members, takes a share in our griefes. As I am a Christian, I must imitate him in his morall vertues, chiefly in gentlenes and pitie towards my brethren. I cannot then but compassionate the weake estate
of this person, and afford him possible help. But because that's but little which I can doe to him, doe more, my God, I beseech thee; comfort his soule by forgiving her sins, and dispersing her feares; and ease his flesh, by removing or assuaging • er paine: or if the houre of his dissolution is neere, then be not farre from him: but, Lord Jesu, come quickly to deliver his soul from the power of hell, and the sharp clawes of the roaring Lion, who daily walks about this place, seeking to devoure thy creature, and enjoy thy purchace.

div.head: Foure other Imployments.
div.p:
THere are againe good things, which I can doe this day of rest: for, I know some of my neighbours, who are at Difference; others, whose minds are wrapt in Ignorance: some Living ill; others, who are in Affliction. I'le goe to them, or to anie of them, and (as well as I can) strive to doe God service, in Calm
•… ng angrie minds, and reconciling them; Teaching the ignorant what they must both beleeve and doe; Drawing evill persons, from wickednes to godlines; Cheering up those, whose hearts are full of griefe, either for sin, •… e crosse: and so shewing my selfe a faithfull servant of the Lord, in improving well my
talent, for my Masters both profit and credit. Thou, holie Ghost, by whose inspiration and help all these things may be brought to passe, vouchsafe to come with me, and blesse my intentions with desired successe. Give me strong persuasions, and let my words enter into their hearts.

div.head: The Close of the Day.
div.p: IF I have been this day as it becomes a true Christian, pure to my selfe, devout to God, and helpfull unto men by examples, counsels and almes, then receive now my thankes, O most mercifull God; for, my vertuous cariage is as water of thine owne Well, and a fruit of thy tree. By thee I have been both willing and able to doe good: let therefore the glorie be thine; and let thy mercie continue, that my goodnes increase. But if (as no doubt) I have past this day sinfully, impure unto my selfe, ungodlie unto thee, and crosse and scandalous to men, or mixt my best actions with much imperfection, my devotion with great coldnes, hypocrisie or vaine glorie, then shame belongs to me, yea damnation is my desert: yet in confidence of thy knowne compassion to the greatest sinners, I beg pardon of thee, and hope to enjoy thy glorie. O forgive my sins past, preserve me from the like, and grant, another day, I take warning by this.
