div.p: MY CATECHISME AND Child-bearing VVoman are now Printed, and My Beliefe Reprinted with Scripture-proofs.

div.head: HERBERTS QUADRIPARTIT DEVOTION. For the Day, Week, Month, Yeare. THE THIRD PART. FOR THE MONTH, For the Communion, in the Lords Supper.
The Lords Day, or the eighth before the Communion.
div.p:
THe great King of Heaven and Earth hath this day sent forth his servant, to bid me to his great Supper, where not his fat Oxen are kill'd, but his owne Son is crucifi'd in figure and commemoration. Shall wordlie cares or wanton sports make me forbeare that feast? Then woe is to my soule. I will therefore leave all to goe. I'le put out of my heart
the unrulie love of riches, and the uncleane lust of the flesh, with all things which might keep me back: and least, when I am there, I be cast out into utter darknes, I'le put on the wedding garment, make this week provision of vertues, and beg of God morning and evening freedome from sin, and indowments of grace. Heare my prayers, O Lord, and grant my hearts desires.

div.head: Of Sloath.
div.p:
SLoath being a drowzines of the mind, and wearines of well-doing, I must first shake it off, that cheerfully I passe this week, in devotion, and the better overcome all those sins, which remaining in me, would hinder me to come neere the Lords Table, with that puritie, he desires of me. But because men (though borne unto labor) seek ease, and desire rest, loath to vexe and crosse their nature, I call on thee for help, O God most gracious and pow'rfull. Powre now into my mind those motions, which may awake her. Rowse up my fainting sp'rits to all godlie actions, by these and the like considerations, that he's cursed, who doth thy work negligently • that thy Kingdome is gotten by violence: that everie tree, which brings not forth good fruit, is hewed downe and cast into the fire: that idlenes is the mother of vice,
the stepdame of vertue, the forerunner of want, both corporall and spirituall. O then let me hate sloath in my worldlie calling, but above all in my Christian duties. Make me laborious in the first, and diligent in the second.

div.head: Sunday Evening. Of Fortitude.
div.p: AS Fortitude is an aggression, or undertaking of hard things; so 'tis the first vertue I beg of thee, O God my strength and tow'r. My designe is, to fight with Satan, the world and my selfe, all stout champions, which (no doubt) shall foile me, unles thou holdst me up. O then, my Lord, teach now my hand to fight, and gird my loines with strength. O let nothing daunt my courage; but let it be as great, yea farre greater then the perill. Make me in all good occasions as bold as a Lion, and grant I resist unto bloud against sin, looking unto thy Son Jesus, who for the joy, which was set before him, endur'd the crosse and despised the shame. So in hope of that crowne, thou hast laid up for me, let me sleight affliction, scorne voluptie, tame my perverse nature, overcome ill, and practise good: that so I be a worthie guest unto the sumptuous feast, thou dost prepare for me.

div.head: Monday Morning. Of Wrath.
div.p:
IT is equall folie to be angrie, when we should not; and be not angrie, when we should: for, wrath being a heat of bloud, about the heart, is either good or bad, as the object makes it. Anger is just, when we see God abus'd, and innocence injur'd; and 'tis injust, when without cause, our bloud boiles in our veines, our hearts devise revenge, and our tongues utter curses. O Lord, let me be in wrath like thy Son, highly incensed in thy cause; but meek in mine owne wrongs. Let me be a Lion to maintaine thy glorie, and a Lamb to beare injuries: yet grant my zeale be such, as worke the correction, and not aime at the destruction of them, who offend thee and me; and grant likewise my meeknes be discreet, that so I may discerne what I must beare, and what I may repell. If any man hath injur'd me, behold, my God, I forgive him; and if I have wrong'd others, both pardon me, good Lord, and make my reconciliation with them. Before the next Lords day, yea if I can, before the Sun be set, I'le seek to appease them, either by words or by letters; that so I may bring unto thy altars the pure and pleasant gift of a gentle and Christian heart. Accept it then, my God; and
grant till then, yea till my death, that all bitternes, anger, wrath, clamor, and evill speaking be put away from me, with all malice, being alwaies courteous unto others, and forgiving all men, even as for Christs sake thou hast forgiven me.

div.head: Monday Evening. Of Justice.
div.p: JUstice alone is able to settle things in good order, and should we love it, as we ought, the golden age was never more happie, then ours should be: for 'tis not the chiefe of vertues, but rather everie vertue. Whosoever is just, will be religious towards God, innocent towards men, and pure towards himselfe. He will render to all their due, to God honor and obedience; to men help and friendship; to himselfe love and care. O then, good God, adorne my soule with that vertue: for although since Adam lest his uprightnes, there is no man righteous; yet I humbly intreat, thou wilt make me as just, as mortall man can be. And if my righteousnes come short of thy glorie, as (doubtles) it shall come; O justifie me by thy grace, through saith in the bloud of Jesus, to whom thou didst impute our sins, that his righteousnes might be ours by imputation.

div.head: Tuesday Morning. Of Envie.
div.p: ENvie is a Spider, which turnes good meat into poison; a diabolicall vice, whose object is the good and felicitie of others; yet is it selfe wicked and unhappie: for, as the Devill wrought mans fall; so the envious desires the miserie of others, ever tortur'd at the sight of their happines. Although this vice be opposit to good, and contrarie unto justice: yet it is just in this, that it torments its host, and deprives him of all pleasures. Let it, O God, never take root in me; yea let it not come neer my thoughts, to disturb my quietnes; but grant, that I rejoyce at other mens felicitie, imitate their vertues, and give thee heartie thankes, for thy favors to them.

div.head: Tuesday Evening. Of Prudence.
div.p:
IT is Prudence, which guides our soules aright in the labirinth of this world; for, it shewes us what's good or bad, and how to chuse the first, and reject the second. Of past observations it gathers experience, and as it
orders the present, so it provides for the future. It doth take care of the whole man, and so by providence makes our lives sweet, in affording what we do need, and removing what we doe feare. Such vertue is desirable; and therefore, Lord, I beseech thee, to let me enjoy it. I leg knowledge of thee, my onelie wise God and Sa
• i • ur; then let discretion preserve me, and wisdome promote me.

div.head: Wednesday Morning. Of Gluttonie.
div.p:
IF Gluttons and Drunkards shall not inherit the Kingdome of God, I must not presume to take that sacrament, which is an earnest thereof, if I am guiltie of these vices, Gluttonie, Drunkennes. must first abhorre them, is the two pooles, wherein reason is drown'd, lust bred, and contention nurst. The sacrament of Christs bodie is ordained for men, therefore not for Gluttons, sith th'are more beasts, then men. Besides, in that action we must lift up our hearts, which Gluttons cannot doe; for, theirs lie downe in the bellie, the sweetest god, they acknowledge. Then, Lord, let me hate Gluttonie, and shun exces of drinke. Let me consider, that those vices have drawne disgrace
and confusion on manie men, who otherwise seemed perfect; that they have kill'd manie bodies, damn'd manie soules, and destroy'd whole countries; and that where they doe reigne, there is no health, no peace, no trust, no honestie.

div.head: Wednesday Evening. Of Temperance.
div.p: SInce Temperance is a vertue, which rules according to reason, all the motions of the soule and bodie, and keeps the appetit in a sober temper: Vouchsafe, my Lord, to infuse it into my soule; that so my thoughts be pure, thy counsels wise, my affections holie, my lookes modest, my words warie, my behaviour honest, and my whole person temperate.

div.head: Thursday Morning. Of Lust.
div.p:
THis is our common plague, a generall disease, a swelling streame, which sweeps away the highest towers, puls downe the holiest men; for, who lives but to twentie or thirtie yeares of age, and doth not defile his vessell, or taint his mind with lust? There is
no vice so inherent to our nature, as this; none so powerfull, to draw consent; nor so common, to worke our fall. The coldest men into the act may be hot in the lust of it; and those who will not touch women, may yet lust after them. For my part I must say with the leprous under the Law, I am unclean, I am uncleane; therefore, my God, cleanse me (I beseech thee) from all the spots, I have contracted by this vice; that in all puritie I may receive the sacrament of thy Sons pure bodie and bloud, least in taking it in my uncleannes, I be cut off from thy people. From this day till my death keep me, O God, from all lewd thoughts, unchast motions, and lascivi
• us copulations. O let me not pollute the temple of thy spirit, by a short voluptie, which leaves a long remorse: but since lust doth consume our meanes, and taint our names, weaken our bodies, and damne our soules, let my heart ever abhorre it, and alwayes keep a watch upon the sences, at which death enters in.

div.head: Thursday Evening. Of Faith.
div.p:
THose, who will goe to the Lords Table, must have Faith 'bove all things; that when they take the bread and wine, they beleeve, there's bodie and bloud; and when they
eat the sacrament, they conceive the thing signified. Faith is well call'd the evidence of things, which are not seen: for, by it we see Christ, whilst our eyes view the elements; and by it we touch his bodie, whilst our sences feele and tast bread and wine. With faith the sacrament is an antidote 'gainst poison, and without faith 'tis strong venom: for he, who beleeves, Christ is there off'ring unto out soules the merits of his bodie and bloud broken and shed for them, may be assur'd of the pardon of his past sins, and receives strength 'gainst the future; whereas unbeleevers take the shell without the kernell, the bread without the Lord, and the signe of Christ without Christ: or if they find him there, 'tis as poison, to infect them; not as wholesome meat, to feed them; 'tis as a Judge, to condemne them; not as a Saviour, to save them. Consider then, my soule, whether thou hast an intire faith of Christian mysteries, revealed to the Church, and contained in the Scripture, and namely about the sacrament of Christs bodie and bloud. If thou hast it, thank God for it; if thou wantst it, desire it thus from him. O thou great God, whose nature is above our reach, & whose secret operations no human reason can conceive! give me that faith, without which no man can know thee, without which no soule can please thee.
Lord, I beleeve; but that I beleeve unto righteousnes, O God, increase my faith. Concerning the great sacrament of thy flesh and bloud, I beleeve, that in the night that thou, Lord Jesus, wast betray'd, thou didst give thy disciples bread and wine, which then thou didst call thy bodie and bloud, with charge to eat and drinke, and doe the same in remembrance of thee. For, as thou wast upon thy departure, thou wouldst leave us a signe of thy bodie, a figure of thy bloud, a memoriall of thy passion; least we should forget thee, who for our sakes wast readie to lay downe thy life. Therefore I take those elements of bread and wine, for holie signes of thy bodie and bloud, beleeving, that though they remaine after the consecration in their substance both bread and wine, yet they are more then common bread and wine, being made by prayer and thy word, the figures of thy flesh and bloud, which in the action and use of the sacrament are really and effectually taken by the faithfull. So though I see, feele and tast bread and wine; yet I beleeve to eat thy flesh and drinke thy bloud, in a spirituall sort, conceiving, thou didst die for me, and by faith and the operation of thy Spirit, applying to my soul the merit of thy death. O Lord, let me live in this faith: O Lord, let me die in this faith. So shall my soule live after death; for, who eates thee, can never die: now we eat thee by faith: therefore, my God, confirme my faith; my Christ, pray that my faith faile not, either concerning this, or anie other point of holie mysteries.

div.head: Friday Morning. Of Avarice.
div.p:
IF Avarice is the root of all evill, and the wrack of our faith, I must never presume to goe to the Lords Table, if my soule is possest with it: for he, whose heart is full of earth, cannot tast heavenlie dainties. Yet desiring to take the sacrament of the redemption of sin, in the bloud of Jesus, shed therein in commemoration, and fearing to take it to my condemnation, I lift up my soule unto thee, O thou the Son of God, who didst become poore for my sake. O pluck out by the roots the evill weeds of covetous desires, which hinder the growth of good seeds. Let me not set my affections upon that, which is not, for riches passe away from one to the other, breeding care in their stay, and sorrow in their departure. O let me consider, that I brought no meanes out of the womb, neither can I carrie anie into the grave, to doe me anie good: that great riches become not foolish men, which cannot rule them well; but instead of possessing them, are pow'rfully possest by them; and that the best way to be rich is to rule affection, and put limits unto desire; and therefore let me pray, as I doe even now, that my conversation be without covetousnes, and I content with those things, which I have. If I
on poore, O let me seeke sufficient meanes, with a quiet and just conscience: and if I have more, then I need, then grant, I help others, with a bountifull hand, and charitable heart.

div.head: Friday Evening. Of Hope.
div.p:
WHat anchors are to ships, the same is Hope unto our minds: it stayes them, when they are tossed; it comforts them, when they are afflicted. Were it not for this divine vertue, there is no creature so unhappie, as man should be: for here our miseries are great, and (no doubt) should be far greater, if hope should not lift up our hearts to that glorious and eternall Kingdome, God hath prepar'd for us. But as long as we hope, to enjoy the glorie and pleasures of Heaven, purchast for us by Christ; what can all earthlie crosses and worldlie disgraces doe to us? Transitorie labor is light, when the reward is eternall; and present griefe is not considerable, nor future paines, diseases or disgrace formidable, when perpetuall joy followes them. Thou, O God, art my hope. In all my afflictions and tentations, in my paines and sorrowes, I will remember thy promises, consider thy goodnes, expect thy help, and looke for
thy gratuit glorie. Let me ever doe so, and so strengthen my hope, that nothing daunt my heart, and make it saint in thy service: and if present pleasures seem sweet, let me sleight them (if unlawfull) in hope of the future.

div.head: Saturday Morning. Of Pride.
div.p:
SInce Pride and Humilitie cannot agree, I must beware to carie a proud mind, before an humble God. Christ himselfe hath warn'd me, to learne of him lowlines of heart; and should he find me to morrow, puft up with high conceits of mine owne worthines, and burning with desire of temporall honor, he would (I feare) cast abroad the rage of his wrath, to punish my stout heart, and abase my high lookes. Therefore in feare of his anger, and out of desire to please him, I doe humble my selfe before his majestie, truly acknowledging that the grounds of my pride are meere gifts of his grace: for, if riches, friends, bloud, honors, beautie, wit, or vertue make me raise up my thoughts, doe they not all proceed from God, who might have formed me as vile a man as ever liv'd, or the basest of all creatures? I have therefore good reason, to
be thankfull to him, but none at all to be loftie; unles I be wearie of that, which seeds my pride; for, it is the way to loose all Away then, cursed Pride, the stumbling-block of bright Angels, the cut-throat of mankind, the sleep downe-fall to hell for both. O Christ, the Son of God, free my soule from this vice. Teach me to follow thy example of lowlines of heart. Make me little in mine owne eyes; that I be great in thine, Let the consideration of my assured death and future corruption, and of deserved hell for my grievous offences, keep me from swelling thoughts, for what I am and possesse now. O let me ever acknowledge, that all my goods proceed from thee without anie merit of mine; and so let me returne▪ thee thankes and service for them all, without despising those persons, whom thou hast not blest with the like.

div.head: Saturday Evening. Of Charitie.
div.p:
I Have this week swept my house as cleane, as I co • ld; and by prayers and endeavours cast out of my heart those foule vices, which would offend that God, whom I purpose to intertaine: and withall I have made provision of such things, as I know he doth like. Yet because man is so miserable, that he can doe
nothing perfect, but his vertues are stain'd with some imperfections, I will put on a cloak, which may hide all faults from his eyes. That's Charitie, which dothSee my Catechism, Quest. 1008. Cover a multitude of sins. If he see that on me, he will dislike nothing; but will either wink at my faults, or shew them me in all meeknes, giving grace to mend them: for, it is love, which reconciles man with his God, and appeases his wrath. But how shall I compasse this rare vertue? How shall I love my God, when my heart is set on those things, which are opposite unto him? My affections are in the world, and his pomps and riches: I love the flesh with her pleasures and volupties, and I dote on my selfe; what love then can I beare to God, who will be lov'd alone, and for whose sake I must hate all these things? Why, Charitie is a divine vertue, infus'd by God into mans heart. I must therefore expect it from above. O then, my God, let now my prayers come to thee, and grant what I require. O Lord, let me now consider, how transitorie are all things, how wicked is the world, how impure is the flesh, and how my selfe am deceitfull; that so I loose my affections from all such unworthie objects. Then let me know how eternall is thy nature, how permanent is thy glorie, and how infinit is thy love; that my whole heart be fixt on thee, and on men for thy sake. Bring me, O bring
me to morrow to thy banquetting house, and let love be my badge. So shall I be thy welcome guest, having on the wedding garment: and both by love and by eating thy flesh and drinking thy bloud, I shall for ever dwell in thee my glorious Creator, and thou in me thy blessed creature.

div.head: Morning Meditations. In the Day of the Administration.
div.p:
1 I Ought this day to sit with a Ruler, not such, as Solomon doth meane, when he gives me counsell to put a knife unto my throat, because his meat is deceitfull, and often his mind too; but with him, whose meat is wholesome, and his invitation as sincere, as common. As I imagine, he now cries: If anie man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink, so I answer him thus. I thirst, my God, I thirst for grace; therefore I will now goe to drinke a full draught of thy sweet water, that so I never thirst. Give me a strong appetite of that heavenly meat, of that angelicall bread, that bread of life, which comes downe from heaven; that I eat well of it, and so live for ever. Onely let me not be desirous of that daintie, which did prove deceitfull both to Angels and man; but let me wisely consider, that albeit by eating
thy flesh and drinking thy bloud, I dwell in thee, and thou in me; yet there is none like unto thee both in heaven and earth, and that thou wilt not give thy glorie unto man. Therefore, O Lord, let me desire union with thee, by faith, pietie and charitie, but never strive for an impossible equalitie of greatnes, glorie and wisdome.

2. Wisdome hath kill'd her beasts, mingled her wine, • urnisht her table. Mans folie wrought his fall by a bit, wisdome repaires it by a feast. A fruit did corrupt us, and flesh and bloud doe preserve us. A Lamb is slain for the Goat, the just for the unjust, the Son of God for the children of men, and is this day offred as meat, for the life of manie. I will goe to that feast, to eat that meat and drink that wine, which is mingled for me, the fruit of the vine with the bloud of Gods Lamb. O then, good Lord, let me be found in that puritie, thou desirest in them, who come neere thine altars. Wash thou my feet, that I be cleane, and may have part with thee.

3. Was Horebs journie too great for Elijah, without the meat, which an Angell brought him? Then how can we goe to heaven, unles we be strength'ned, by some heavenlie food? The feares of the soule, and the labors of the bodie should quickly make us faint, unles God feed us by the way. Now the food he gives us in our spirituall journie,
is his Sons flesh and bloud, which we doe daily eat and drink, when we beleeve that he dy'd for us; but more fully, when in that faith, we take the signes, he hath ordain'd. I aspire to heaven, and (by Gods grace) have alreadie begun my way. Least then I faint, sleep or loiter, strengthen me, Lord, by the spirituall meat, thou giv'st all faithfull travellers. Let me be partaker of the merits of thy passion, and let thy bloud be upon me, to wash my crimson sins, and comfort my languishing heart, till I come to thy Mount, and dwell in thy holie Hill.

4. Man cannot live long without meat. Bodilie life is preserved with bread and wine, and the spirituall with Gods word. As bread strengthens the heart, and wine doth cherish it; so the word of God comforts the soule, and preserves her in health. And this is daily done, when God feeds us with good notions, either by the Scripture, godlie bookes, and Sermons; or by speciall motions proceeding immediatly from the holie Ghost; but this is chiefly done in the most blessed sacrament of Christs bodie & bloud; for, there it is, that he gives us a full banquet of spirituall comforts, by imparting us the merits, his Son purchast for us, by a most cruell death. This communication is the meat of our soules, and the imputation of our Saviours satisfaction is the
seed of eternall life, sowne in our hearts, to comfort them. We find both these in the sacrament, if we beleeve the remission of sin, in the bloud of Jesus, and receive the signes bread and wine, in remembrance of his passion, and in figure of his great sacrifice. Let me anon doe so, O thou mercifull God, who hast given thy Son, for the ransome of men. Quicken my saith, to apprehend those mysteries, and let my heart fully conceive what's hid under the holie signes. As I take bread and wine, let me consider flesh and bloud; bloud shed to wash away my sins, flesh kill'd to feed my soule, and give her everlasting life: that so with love to thy goodnes, with respect to thy majestie, with sorrow for my sins, and with desire of better life, and full resolution of amendment, I receive both the signes and the things signifi'd.

5. After mans fall, Cherubims kept the way of the tree of life, least man should eat of it, and so live for ever: for, since God had ordain'd, that Adam should dye for his sin, he deprived him of that fruit, which had vertue to keep off death. Although Christs flesh and bloud were figur'd by that tree, yet they are not kept so from men, at least generally from all: nay rather, because they are the meanes of our eternall salvation, they are daily offered us with a loving invitation. Goe then, my soule, goe to the place, where that meat is readie,
by whose vertue thou maist live now in grace, and hereafter in glorie. And thou, O God, who call'st those, who travell and are heavie laden, ease me now of all sins, then refresh me with thine owne flesh and bloud, by whose vertue I may be renew'd, and by whose merits I may be sav'd. And since, O Lord, thou art our passover, let me, O let me keep this feast, not with the leaven of malice and wickednes, but with unleavened bread of sinceritie and truth.

6. Are they blessed, who are call'd to the Lambs Supper? Then I challenge that blessednes; for (by Gods grace) I am bid to the feast, where that innocent Lamb gives his bodie for meat, his bloud for drink, his whole person for the comfort of them, who mourn for their offences, and doe hunger and thirst after his righteousnes. Yet I must see before I goe, that I discerne the Lords bodie; think how worthie is such a meat, and how unworthie is the guest; that so with great respect to Christs divinitie, and with perfect knowledge of my infirmitie, I eat that bread, and drink that wine, which figure unto me his flesh and bloud. O holie Sp'rit, teach my soule that knowledge, which this sacrament doth require. Without thy help I cannot conceive such high things; therefore lighten my mind, that I may see the depth of this great mysterie, and with a heart humble for my manifold sins, and
thankfull for thy love, I take the memoriall of my Saviours passion, and share in the merits both of his life and death.

div.head: In Going to the Table.
div.p: I Will wash my hands in innocence, and so goe to the Lords Altar. But where is innocence? Have I lived till now without offence to God and man: yea these eight dayes of my preparation to this holie action, have I kept my soule and bodie blamelesse? No, no, but rather I have defiled both with evill thoughts, lewd affections, sinfull deeds, idle words. Therefore, my God, finding in me but guilt, it is in thy Sons innocence, that I will wash my hands, humbly intreating thee to impute it to me, and in the sea of his vertues, to drowne the streames of my vices and sins, least I be drown'd by them, and damn'd for them.

div.head: Concerning the Posture.
div.p:
SIth this is a Supper, I may lawfully sit; yet if the Church, in which I live, allowes not that posture, I'le not be singular: for, Christ, who said, Doe this, said not, Doe thus. I conceiv • then, that the action is commanded, but the po •• ure and time left free. Make me, O God,
verie zealous in thy service, verie devout in religi
• us actions; but withall give me discretion, both to • rder my zeale, and to limit my devotions; least zeale make me peevish and singular, or devotion in
• line me to superstition.

div.head: In Sitting.
div.p: 1 I Will sit here, because this is a Table and Supper, yet • it with reverence, because the Boord and Supper are the Lords, in whose comparison I am a worme and no man; or if a man, a vile and sinfull man, Thee then, Lord, I • dore; before thee I humble my soule, beseeching thee to make me a fit guest, for thy heavenlie banquet.

2. Is anie Judas here, or am I not my selfe like that curs'd son of perdition? Is my heart right with Christ; or will I betray him to sin? to the lus • s of my Fl • sh, or corrupt nature? to the vanities of the World? to the will of Satan? I may doe so, I shall doe so, if thou dost not pretent me by thy grace, O thou the Preserver of men. Then assist me effectually in my present resolutions, and all future actions. Come in, sweet Jesus, come into my soule; and there make thy selfe strong, against Satan, the World and • lesh.

div.head: In Kneeling.
div.p: IS not God here, and is not this a religious action? Why then should I refuse to kneele? 'Tis not the bread and wine, which upon my knees I adore; but the great and infinit God, my sweet Saviour Jesus, whom those elements represent. Jesu, the Son of God and man! behold this my adoration, and fix on thee my attention.

div.head: At the sight of the Bread and Wine.
div.p: I See upon that table Bread and Wine, which make me remember, that Christ was once upon the crosse, where through the eternall Spirit he offered himselfe without spot unto God, to purge with his owne bloud my conscience from dead workes. O that my wilfulnes in sin may not make void to me thy sacrifice for sin, O most loving Saviour! O that by the meanes of thy death I receive now the seale of the promise of eternall inheritance, and strength to serve thee faithfully.

div.head: Before we take the Sacrament.
div.p:
BEhold, my soule, he comes to thee, by whose hands thou wast made, by whose goodnes thou art preserv'd, and upon whose
merits thou maist ground all thy hopes of e
• erlasting life. What a favour is it, that he comes under thy poore roofe, whom the hea
• ens cannot containe; and that he dwels with • hee, in whom sin hath reigned so long? Therefore being amaz'd at thine unworthines • nd at his infinit majestie, thou might'st with S Peter pray him to goe from thee, because thou art sinfull; yet in consideration of the profits thou maist now reap in intertaining him, receive him joyfully, as Zacheus did once; and thou, my God, being entred, say to my s • ule what thou didst say then of his house, This day is salvation come to thee.

div.head: In taking the Bread.
div.p: I Feele but bread with my fingers; yet by faith I see Christ, who sitting in heaven, at his Fathers right hand, feeds my soule, with his flesh and bloud, offering to God the merit of his life and death, for the purgation of my sins, and desiring for me a strength'ning in vertue, and an increase of grace. Father, receive that thy Son offers thee, and give me what he begs for me.

div.head: In Eating the Bread, and after.
div.p: 1 IS not this bread the communion of the bodie of Christ? O then, great God, make me now partaker of his glorious merits, in remembrance of whose most cruell death, I eat this holie breed. And are not all those one bodie, who are partakers of this bread? O then, Jesu! let my soule ever be in the communion of thy Saints, lead with the same holie sp'rit, taught the same saving faith, and affected with the same Christian love; since she is fed with the same divine food, thy precious flesh and bloud: and, Lord, blesse those, who here or anie where else receive the Sacrament of their redemption, through thy death.

2. Manna was to the Jewes, what this bread is to us, a Sacrament of Christ, in the wildernes of this world; untill we come to the borders of the heavenlie Canaan. Tho • e, who receive the Sacrament, with faith in the thing signifi'd, shall be kept here blameles, unto the coming of Jesus, who shall transport their blessed soules into that glorious place of perpetuall rest and pleasure. Grant, good Lord, I ever doe so, as I conceive that I doe now. Yet if my faith is weake, and my devotion cold: O God, strengthen the first and heat the last, that I performe duely
these holie mysteries, and so be one of those, who shall enter into thy rest.

3. My teeth have chew'd this bread, that it may nourish me: and hereupon I consider, that my Saviours bodie, which is figur'd thereby, was broken with torments, to be made my spirituall food. O Christ the man of sorrowes, offer thy death to thy Father, for my sinfull soule, which rejoyces at thy coming.

4. This bread is gone downe into my stomach, where in few houres 'tis disgested and turn'd into mine owne substance. It is not so with the thing signifi'd; for thou, O Lord, entrest into the soule, which thou changest into thy selfe, or at least unitest to thee, with so strong bonds of love, that death it selfe cannot breake them. O burne in the furnace of that eternall love, which made thee dye for me, the drosse and chaffe of my corrupt nature, and make my whole person as pure in thine owne eyes, as gold refined seven times.

5. I feele some comfort by this bread; for, though it was but a morsell, yet it doth strengthen my stomach. What may therefore thy flesh doe to my soule, O Christ my Lord and God? May not the whole merits of thy holie life and cruell death, being communicated to her, recreate her in wearines, assure her in fear, strengthen her in weaknes, protect her in dangers, help her in tentations, hearten her in vertue, and quicken her in devotion.
Then, sweet Jesu, keep not from me what thou hast done for me; but let thy fast and pray'rs, thy feare and sweat, thy scoffes and blowes, thy wounds and death be now imparted to my soule without revocation. O let me find ease in thy paines, life in thy death, and glorie in thine infamie.

6. Israel was fed with Manna, that he might know, man doth not live by bread onely, but by the word of God. Indeed bread feeds the flesh, but can goe no farther. Least therefore man should want a perfect nutriment, God did ordaine this Sacrament, in which he makes a spirituall conjunction of bread with his bodie, and so doth feast both flesh and sp'rit. Bread is for the bodie, and the word of God for the soule; for here Gods word is read to teach & comfort her, and the Word made flesh given her, to feed her with the assurance of everlasting life, through the merits of his life and passion. O then, good Lord, let my soule live by thine incarnate Word in all graces on earth, till with him she live in glorie, in the blessed heaven.

div.head: In taking the Cup.
div.p:
MY eyes see but wine in this cup; yet by faith I behold the Son of God, doing some thing to it; that it be not a naked signe;
but a Sacrament of the bloud, which he shed for my sins. Then for thy sake, most loving God, I take this holie cup.

div.head: In Drinking the Wine, and after.
div.p: IS not this Cup the communion of the bloud of Christ? O then, my God, make me now partaker of his glorious merits, in remembrance of whose most bloudie death, I drinke this holie wine.

2. This wine made of manie grapes figures me the bloud of Jesus, running out of manie veines, to wash and cleanse my polluted conscience: and therefore I doe curse the cause of his torments, whose love deserv'd other usage of me. I grieve for my most grievous sins, my wilfull transgressions, my wicked rebellions. O sweet Jesu, let me still so grieve for the same, that I never sin willingly; and my good Lord, let that be done in me, which is here signifi'd: let thy bloud be the remission of all my sins, the increase of all graces, the comfort of my soule, and the preservation of both s • ule and bodie, for everlasting life.

3. This wine is sweet to my palate, but that which it doth represent will be farre sweeter to my soule, if I consider its value. Tis the bloud of Jesus, that most delicious drink, which may quench the soules thirst. O then, good Lord, let me conceive its worth from both
thy greatnes and goodnes; least in treading it under foot, that fearfull judgement and fierie indignation befall me, which shall devoure thy adversaries.

4. As wine makes the heart glad, and gives an edge unto our wits; so the bloud of Jesus cheeres up the soule, by the feeling of Gods favor; and rowses up the mind, from the dulnes, which keeps it creeping upon earth, by the knowledge of earthlie vanities. Let me, O God, feele these effects; let thy face shine on me, and be thou gracious unto me. O raise my affections from all worldlie creatures, loose them from base objects, and so draw now my soule to thee, that nothing please her hereafter, but the meditation of thy glorious divinitie, of thy Sons pure humanitie, of his love towards men, in feeding them with his owne flesh, and of my dutie towards thee, to shew my thankfulnes, for the unspeakable favor, thou hast vouchsafed me.

5. When men have their fill of good wine, then their secret thoughts come to light; and when we have receiv'd Gods sp'rit, in eating Christs bodie and drinking his bloud, then we have an insight of what was hid in our hearts: we see our corruption and in-bred propension to ill, and how Satan weaves with nature our present affliction and future damnation. Shew me all this, good Lord; and with thy holie Sp'rit sanctifie my nature, and with thy
power foile Satan; that I may as a bird escape out of his snare.

6. As wine warmes the stomach, and helps the digestion; so Christs bloud drives away the coldnes of the soule, kindles her devotion in religious actions, and helps her to digest the hardest afflictions. Lord, let me now and ever find it so. When my heart is frozen, melt it with the heat of thy bloud; and when it is opprest by anie paine or feare, relieve it with the thought, that thy precious bloud was once shed, to redeem me from eternall torments, and comfort me in temporall adversities.

7. Wine is a cunning wrastler; for, so it intangles the feet, that it throwes downe the strongest man. O let Gods Sp'rit deale ever so with me, strike at the root, make sure work of my affections: for, that's the way, to make me yeeld to him. If thou, O Lord, canst win my heart, thou shalt easily command the rest. Thou canst win it; for, both thou art pow'rfull, and I willing, to submit it to thee; for though 'twas thine, by creation; yet thou hast purchast it, by an incomparable act of love, in dying on the crosse for me, who was then a sinner, and so thy sworne enemie. Then take, good God, what thou hast made and bought, and I willingly render thee.

8. Wine makes him bold, who otherwise is faint-hearted, a faire embleme of one of the effects of the holie Ghost; for, when by grace
he dwels in us, admitted in our hearts, through faith in the bloud of Jesus; then though we be of a fearfull disposition; yet he makes us more hardie then Lions, in all vertuous undertakings. O then, my God, since I must strive to overcome Satan, despise the world and tame my flesh, let me feele thy strong help, so that I remaine victorious: and if ever occasion be given, to maintaine truth, keep honestie, glorifie thee, and confesse Christ, with the losse of friends, goods, name, life; then redouble thine assistance; that with courage I expose all, to shew my selfe an honest man and a perfect Christian.

div.head: Thanksgivings.
div.p:
THis Sacrament is called Eucharist, because in it we render thankes to God, for having redeem'd us, by the death of his Son, for feeding our soules with his flesh, for making us members of that mysticall bodie, of which Christ is the head, and so giving us assurance of everlasting life; and in a word, for all his mercies towards us in soules, bodies and goods. Then see, my soule, how thou maist shew thy thankfulnes to God, for his manifold benefits. Gratitude is a vertue rendring thankes to the benefactor, by acknowledgement and service, according to our
pow'r. Follow now this order, and with heart and tongue first thank him, of whom thou hast receiv'd unspeakable favors.

div.head: The Thanksgiving of Acknowledgement, to God the Father.
div.p:
BEcause, O God, the Maker of heaven and earth, and the giver of all good things, thou hast hitherto heap'd upon me thy blessings, receive my thankes for them; and let earth, aire and sea with all the creatures, which are in them, and the heavens with their bright lights, holie angels and blessed soules, joyne their voices with mine, to praise thy majestie for thy unspeakable benefits of Election from the generall lump of corruption in Adam, before Adam had a being: of Creation, concerning the soule, and making out of my parents substance, concerning the bodie: of Redemption from sin and hell, by the death of thy Son: of Vocation from false gods, erroneous religions, unfaithfull people, with whom I was (or might have been) brought up, to the knowledge, service and worship of thee alone, in the bosome of thy holie Church, and fellowship of thy servants: of Adoption, in taking me for thy child, joynt-heire with Christ: of Justification, in the forgivenes of
all my sins, and the imputation of thy deare Sons merits: of Sanctification, in the pouring of thy Spirit into my heart, through whose grace I amend my life: of promised Glorification, by changing corruption and mortalitie into incorruption and immortalitie: of Preservation from manie dangers, which daily compasse me: of Long-suffering, in sparing me till now, and giving me time to rep nt: of Bountie, in granting me either a healthie bodie, or a strong heart; a good name, or patience; friends, or comfort; a prosperous estate, or a contented mind: and finally for this last favor, thou hast vouchsafed me, in admitting me a sinner unto the communion of the bodie and bloud of Christ, by which my soule receives comfort in griefes and afflictions, loathing of sin, and love unto vertue, dislike of earth, and desire of heaven. For which great benefits and manie oth • r more, which are as much beyond my expression, as above my merits, I magnifie thy name, which is excellent in all the world; praise thy goodnes, which shines in all thy workes; adore thy majestie, whose glorie is above the heavens, and in whose comparison earthlie greatnes and worldlie pomps are but shadowes. O that my soule never forget these thy blessings; but still remember them, and love thee, from whom
they proceed. So should I be likewise both remembred and lov'd of thee, to whom all pow'r and glorie be ascrib'd.

div.head: Another, to God the Son.
div.p:
ADam for disobedience was cast out of Eden, to shew, both he and we were shut out of heaven: but thou, O Christ, didst by thine obedience to death open it both to him and us, and when thou wast here amongst us didst promise everlasting life to thy faithfull servants. And to make thy promises sure, thou didst subscribe them with thy bloud, and seale them with thy flesh, and so left them in the Scripture and to thy Church; that we should both see and receive the assurance of salvation. The Gospel containes thy promises, and thy Church hath thy seales, the holie Sacraments, one of which I have now receiv'd by thy goodnes, O Lord, whose lest crums of comfort I am unworthie to gather. O then let my heart and tongue give thee thanks for such a high favor, as to make me dwell in thee, yea be in thee, as thou art in thy Father, and thy Father is in thee, a most happie union for such a wretch as I am by nature. But thou art great, and so thou raisest up the poore out of the dust: thou art holie, and so thou sanctifiest
them through Gods truth, whom the Devils falshood made impure. This deserves manie thankes, yet I can yeeld but few; for, my heart is barren, for the conception of such thoughts, as may be worth thine acceptance, and set forth thy favors. Yet I desire to remember thy great goodnes, and so shew thee my thankfulnes. Thy name is holie and reverend, thy power infinit, thy majestie incomprehensible, thy workes honorable and glorious; but thy mercie is above all thy workes. It was a glorious worke, to create man after thine owne image; but to take upon thee his likenes, and so redeem him by thy death, is a thing which surpasses all epithets. Then to give thine owne flesh and bloud for meat unto them, who feare thee, and so command them thy covenant for ever, and give them an infallible earnest of thy glorie, is above the short reach of my understanding, and the expression of my tongue. I doe therefore borrow the words of the blessed citizens of heaven, to magnifie thy glorious name, saying with them, Power, riches, wisdome, strength, honor, glorie and blessing be given to the Lamb, who was slaine for my sins, and by his precious bloud hath redeem'd me to God.

div.head: Another, to God the holie Ghost.
div.p: IT was by thee, O blessed Spirit, that the Word was made flesh, in the pure Virgins womb; and 'tis likewise by thee, that in the Sacrament I eat his flesh and drink his bloud, in a wonderfull sort, and that I dwell in him, and he in me. O then I sing to thee with thanksgiving, desiring thy workes to praise thee, and thy Saints to blesse thee; for, thou O Lord, dost lift up my mind from this our sordid earth to thy glorious heaven, upon the wings of faith and love, to unite it to Christ, • nd make me a member of his mysticall bodie, and so renewest me, by the grace of sanctification, and comfort'st me with th' assurance of life, both for soule and bodie: for, thou dost seale me his promise, that whosoever eates his flesh and drinkes his bloud hath eternall life, and shall rise up at the last day. Therefore my soule praises thee once againe, and whatsoever is in me doth blesse thy holie name.

div.head: The Thanksgiving of Service, to the holie, blessed and glorious Trinitie.
S. Pauls Warning.
div.p:
THe Jewish Sacraments being indeed the same as ours, the punishments of their abuse must be our example. If therefore manie of them (which did eat the signes of that spirituall meat figur'd to them under Manna and Water, and to us under Bread and Wine) were overthrowne in the wildernes, for their lust after evill things, idolatrie, covetousnes,
&c. I must not think, to escape Gods revenge, if as a dog, I returne unto my vomit, doe as ill as before. O rather let me die, before I offend my good God, whose mightie hand hath formed me, whose precious bloud hath redeem'd me, and whose holie Spirit gives me these good motions. Shall I, my Lord, drink thy sweet cup of blessing, and the bitter cup of cursing, which the Devill will present me? Shall I take the tokens of thine infinit love, then provoke thee unto anger, by giving my selfe unto sin? Shall I make my bodie, which is one of thy members by sanctification, the member of a harlot by fornication; or whereas 'tis by right the temple of thy holie Spirit, and a schoole of vertue, shall I make it a palace for Satan, and a sink of all vice? O rather let my God take up my soule to him. Even so come Lord Jesus, come quickly (I beseech thee) for my death, either in the world, or to sin. Let this be the last houre of my corporall life, or the first of a spirituall. O let not sin reigne more in my bodie; but renew within me a right and constant spirit, which look well to his wayes, and walke aright in thine, never offending thee willingly, but in all things seeking how to please thee my mercifull God and Saviour. So shall I expect thy glorie, through the merits of thy passion, and relying on thy mercie feare not the damnation allotted unto them, which eat and drink unworthily the Sacrament of redemption, and the pledges of salvation.

div.head: The Relish, for the next day after the Communion.
div.p:
IF God did chuse under the Law those beasts for sacrifice, which did ruminate or chew the cud, it was (I think) to shew, that he sets his heart on those men, who when they have receiv'd anie favor of him, revolve it often in their minds. Since then he admitted me yesterday, unto the communion of his Sons flesh and bloud, I will (to draw his love, and become fit for his service) remember againe that mercie, not onely this day, but as long as I live. I • pure wine hath a good r • lish, long after it is drunk, shall not the precious bloud of Christ leave a good savor in the soule? We drink wine in the Sacrament for remembrance, and therefore must not forget that, which is represented thereby. It is, O sweet Jesu, to remember thy cruell death for us, that we doe take the holie signes, which thou didst ordaine in thy Church: then let that death be the subject of my daylie meditations. Let me seriously consider what out of love thou didst once suffer for my sins; and thereupon make my heart yeeld thee love for love, and conceive a loathing of sin, the murtherer of my Saviour. Let me studie these two lessons, to love thee, who lov'st me; and hate sin, which kill'd me and thee. And that I
learne them perfectly, be thou, wise God, my Schoole-master. Open my understanding, that I may apprehend the greatnes of thy love, and the basenes of sin: incline my will to the affection of the first, and the aversion of the last: and let my memorie keep them both well; yet not in equall ranke, locking up love, as the cause of my salvation, and sin as the worker of my eternall damnation, had not thy love been greater then my sin. Then in that thought let me give thee such thankes, as may expres my gratitude, even as I doe now saying: Ʋnto God my Saviour praise and service be giv'n, by me and all his creatures, now and ever. Amen.
