p.hi: This Monthlie Devotion hath 50. Meditations and Pray'rs.

div.head: HERBERTS QUADRIPARTIT DEVOTION. For the Day, Week, Month, Yeare. THE FOURTH PART. FOR THE YEARE.
The First day of the Yeare.
div.p:
ALthough the Remembrance of Christs Circumcision be not now publick here, yet I desire this day, which is known and call'd by that name, to Circumcise my flesh, my old and perverse affections. Sweet Jesus, let it be as I desire. Grant, I begin this Yeare with noveltie of life, putting off the sinfull bodie of the flesh through thy Circumcision. O let me circumcise my heart, cut off all my unrulie affections, tame my wild
and wandring desires, subdue my lustfull flesh. And as I shall thus holily begin, grant my good Lord, I end; not looking back to my vicious habits, but going still forward from vertue to vertue, till that happie moment the beginning of my blessed eternitie, in which thou shalt mercifully regard, and bountifully reward my perseverance in good things. Till then, let my Soule and Bodie, my Friends and Goods, remaine under thy protection, to be alwayes, and in all things rul'd by thy gracious providence, and willingly subject to thy revealed will, which be done in Earth by all men, as it is in Heaven, by thy holie Angels, and the blest soules of our brethren.

div.head: To God.
div.p:
FRiends use this day, to give and receive some tokens, without Superstition, to renew their love with the yeare. Thou art O Lord, the greatest friend I have; and therefore thou shalt be the first, to whom I will present some thing, and that is this foule heart, which I hold from Adam. Receive it in good part, as the best thing I can now give: and withall let me intreat thee, that if thou wilt returne me some token, thou wilt vouchsafe to consider, that I cannot live without heart. Therefore
good God, give me a cleane heart, for the foule; pure and holie desires, for corrupt affections.

div.head: To the Poore.
div.p: CHrists poor members shall have my second gift. Let me O God, disperse my goods amongst them all, with such sincerity of heart, that my righteousnesse endure for ever, and my horne be exalted.

div.head: To Friends.
div.p: MY friends must have something, to expresse my love towards them. And thou O Lord, give them what they doe need, both in soule and bodie. Make them holie, healthie, wealthie.

div.head: Unto Enemies.
div.p: I Have a gift for mine enemie. I forgive him the wrongs, he hath done me. If I see him▪ I'le speak him faire; and if he need, I will help him, with all my heart. Blesse him O God, and be mercifull unto him, in making him thy faithfull Servant, and my loving Friend.

div.head: To Debters.
div.p: DOth anie man owe me what he is not able to pay? Then I will forgive him the debt, and let him have his Bond. And so let God crosse in his bookes, what I owe his Justice.

div.head: His Birth-day.
div.p:
BEfore these In the number of thy yeare, adde •• d for that time, thou wart in the womb. years, I was nothing; and if it had not pleas'd the Lord, to blesse my parents copulation, I should be nothing yet. But now I am by his blessing, not a sensles stone, not a growing weed, not an unreasonable creature; but one, in whom the perfections of all creatures doe meet. I am a man, that master-peece of God under heaven, yea, for whose sake heaven seems to be made: a man set here as a tree, to grow up, and bear sweet fruits of all vertues, untill time come, that I shall be transplanted into a better soile. Then what thanks shall I render thee, O God my Creator, for my noble being; for my education, preservation, consolations, healthie disposition, moderate provision? My heart cannot conceive, nor my tongue expresse well what I can give thy Majestie, unlesse it be my selfe. But alas! I am unworthie to be presented unto thee, being not such,
as thou mad'st me in Adams creation: therefore my God, I beseech thee, not to remember now the sin, which I have drawn from my parents, nor those likewise, I have committed since my birth. Then receive my person, for thankesgiving of thy favor, in creating my soule, and forming my bodie; then drawing me safely out of my mothers womb, upon this day, preserving my life till this houre, and blessing me with those inward and outward things, which have made it sweet and pleasant; or not so sowre, as it could have been without them. And gracious Lord, as thou dost receive me, so let me receive thee. Let thy holie Spirit dwell in me, with such fulnesse of grace; that I forbeare those sinnes, to which my weake nature is prone; and lead a life so sober, godlie and Christian, that I end it in the peace of a good conscience; and so in heaven blesse the day of my nativitie, and praise the God, who both made and sav'd me, even thee my wise Creator, and mercifull Saviour.

div.head: His Baptism-day.
div.p:
MAn was made a noble creature; yet once falne from Gods grace, he became so wretched, that he might have curs'd the day of his creation, had not the Lord most mercifull sent down his Son, to redeem him from his sinfull estate, and give him a new birth, in holines
and righteousnes. Baptisme is the Sacrament of his spirituall regeneration, ordain'd for those, who are appointed unto salvation. Happie are they, who receive both the signe and the thing signifi'd, having their bodies washt or sprinkled with water; and their souls throughly cleans'd with the bloud of Gods Lamb. As I am one of them, who have receiv'd this Sacrament; so I thanke thee most gracious God, by whose grace I was on this day borne of water, and as I conceive of the Spirit. 'Twas much, O Lord, thou wouldst make me a man; but 'twas much more, when thou mad'st me Christian, in drawing me from Christian parents loines and womb, (if yet I can say,I have f •• cr • c •• s • to insert this. my parents were such) and giving me grace to receive the first Sacrament of the New Testament; in which (as I conceive againe) I was ingraft into the mysticall bodie of Jesus Christ thy Son, did obtaine remission of sins, and a renovation of thy decay'd Image; and being made thy Child through the grace of adoption, receiv'd the seale and assurance of everlasting happines. Now therefore I praise thee againe, my most mercifull God and Saviour. Yet if my Regeneration was not wrought in Baptism, nor since; then I pray thee, to looke now in mercy on me; and forgiving my sins, to give me such faire lights and pow'rfull motives, such knowledge of thee by thy Word and Spirit, and such love unto thee; that my darkned understanding be illuminated, my hard
heart mollifi'd; the corruption of nature purified; and my whole person sanctifi'd. Call daily to my remembrance what on this day I promis'd thee; that strength'ned by thy grace, I doe faithfully performe it. Let me, O let me now truly forsake Satan and all his wicked workes; the world and all his vanities; the flesh and all her evill lusts. Then grant, I beleeve what I ought; doe what thou dost command; forbeare what thou forbid'st; and enjoy what thou dost promise.

div.head: In Foraine Wars. See the Meditation in the dailie Devotion, Page 78.
div.p:
WE have sinned, O Lord, we have all sinned against thee, and therefore thou com'st against us. Thou hast from time to time call'd us to repentance, both by inward motions and outward instructions; yet we have not knowne the time of our visitation, but have hardned our hearts, to do ill in thy sight. We have done ill, but if we repent now, wilt thou not forgive us, and divert the stroke, we doe feare? Thou dost not thirst after our bloud, nor seeke our destruction; but onely dost desire our conversion to thee. O risen good God, speake once againe peaceably to
our soules, by thy Spirit and Ministers; for now we will heare thee, and let no more drums and cannons fright us; for, now we do feare thee. Yet if thy wrath be so kindled, that it must consume some of us; Lord, spare our Kings Person, and what belongs to him. Spare me likewise thy poore servant, and let my friends and goods be in thy protection. O let not the sword destroy them, who put their trust in thee; nor those likewise, in whom we trust to defend our Countrey, and vindicate our right. Spare them, good Lord, spare them (I beseech thee) for whom thou hast not spar'd thy Son. Keep thy elect from the power of their enemies; yea, deliver this Land and her Inhabitants from them, who seek our ruine. Preserve our right against their violence; our Countrey from their invasion; our persons from their rage; and let not our goods be their prey: but, O good Lord, give us the victorie, that we may yeeld thee the glorie of our deliverance; and in token of thankfulnes, both sing thy praise, and keep thy Law.

div.head: In Civill Wars. See the Meditation in the daily Devotion, Pa. 78.
div.p:
1. IF we judge of our sins by their punishments, we must now acknowledge, they are exceeding
great: sith thou, O God, dost inflict upon us the greatest of thy plagues. Thou send'st us that, wise men esteem much wor • e then the Pestilence: we are in War, yet not with Forraine Nations, which perchance we might overcome, and make bootie of them; but with our Countrey-men, whose victorie must be our losse, and whose defeat shall weaken us. Our grievous sins are the cause of this division; therefore, O Lord, have mercie on us all, and forgiving our common faults, withdraw thy scourge from us Quiet our minds, end all our strifes, decide our contentions; and let love unite those againe, whom hate or ambition hath dis-joyn'd. And if Religion is the cause or motive of these unhappie and irreligious Wars, O God, maintaine thy truth, defend thy Church, assist thy Spouse; and let her children know, their best weapons to uphold Religion, are Faith, Prayers, Repentance, and Patience. But as Religion is often a common cloke for the ambition of many, a step to raise their houses and greatn • s upon the Publick ruines; or a motive to zealous men without knowledge, to kindle a great fire, which often consumes Church and State; or a faire opportunity to the angrie and malicious, to engage fooles in their quarrels: if the case be thus now with us, reveale O Lord, reveale speedily
the malice of all such hypocrites; that their desired conversion or necessarie confusion bring a speedie end of our jars. Let all our hearts be right, or if alreadie so, make them constant to thee, aiming at thy glorie & at our common good; then let our hands be strong, our swords sharp, our armies invincible and victorious of them, who shall oppose our just and religious designes. Lord, fight for us; and, Lord, let none of us ever fight against a good cause; but grant, we know where the right is, to persuade it meekly unto the ignorant, and to maintaine it valiantly against the obstinat.

2. This is a time of division and insolence, in which there is little regard of naturall and civill rights; small respect of justice, and safetie for honest persons. Now are Parents 'gainst their Children; now the Son seeks to supplant his Father, the Mother and Daughter differ, the Brothers sight, Sisters quarrell, Infants curse, Servants betray, Neighbours threaten, and he's esteem'd an evill man, whose tongue and hands lie still. Must then all men be mad, that the ruine be generall? And are Christs blessed Peace-makers become accurs'd among Christians? Is now moderation a vice, love an enemie to the greatnes of States, and quiet soules dangerous in Kingdomes? I'le
judge no man, and God assisting me, no man shall compell me to •• ght against my will, and my will is, to add • no fewell to the fire, no drop of bloud unto the bloudie streames. Thou God of love, lover of peace, and full of compassion, behold the distractions of this divided Land. Touch speedily the hearts of these Ilanders with thy feare, with that feare, which begets or begins wisdome; least their folies grow to madnes, and their rage bring forth destruction. If yet they will not heare the voice of peace, nor incline their hard hearts to reconciliation, extend thy compassion and protection on me and the children of peace. Preserve us, I pray thee, from violence and insolence of all parties; that none prevaile in their attempts against our persons and estates, compelling us to serve their turnes, neglecting our affaires; or to give, lend or pay e'en what they list, though more then we can, or should spare. Lord, what we are, and what we have is thine: then as such protect us and what by thy grace we enjoy. And, gracious God, look now in mercie upon us, and blesse us all with such sound wisdome, and sincere goodnes; that we agree in the truth of thy religion, and in the speedie meanes, to make truly our King glorious, our Countrie prosperous, our selves happie, recalling that sweet peace, ease and plentie, our sins and folies have exil'd.

div.head: In Famine. See the Meditation in the Daylie Devotion. Page 79.
div.p:
LEt not, O Lord, thine anger continue; but be appeas'd, before we be consum'd. We cannot live long, without food; and we cannot have food, unles thou blesse our ground: yea meat cannot satisfie us, if thou withdraw thy blessing from't. We deserve this Famine, yea all thy plagues at once; but after whom wouldst thou come out, O thou great King of heav'n and earth? After those, who humble themselves? Then where is thy promise, to exalt such? After them, who repent? Then where is thy mercie, to pardon such? After them which mourne? Then where are thy comforts for such? Hast thou not said, those should be fill'd, who doe hunger and thirst after righteousnes? Then, O God, let this be done now. We loath our sins, injust dealings, wicked devices; and desire to be blest with that divine vertue, which may teach us to render thee and man what we owe both. O then most true and faithfull God, doe what thou hast promis'd. Fill our emptie soules with vertue, and our hungrie bodies with necessarie
food. Let not hunger make our faces blacker then coales, our skins cleave to our bones, our favor wither like dead trees, nor the tongues of our sucking children stick unto the roofe of their mouthes, because their mothers breasts are drie: but as thou hast bid us, to crave of thee our daylie bread; so give it us this day. Doe not in thy wrath chasten us, nor in anger contest with us; for, we can never answer thee: but in thy mercie forgive us, because thy Son is dead for us. Turne our complaints into voices of mirth, our groanes into good songs, our weake cries into thanksgivings. O blesse againe all the fruits of our ground; blesse the grasse of our fields, and the cattell, which feed on it, and blesse our basket, store and barnes. Satisfie us in these dayes of Famine, and keep alive those, who feare thee: but above all, feed our soules with thy word, and send us not that spirituall famine, in whose comparison bodilie hunger is nothing. Remove not thy Gospel from us, but give us grace, to live still in that faith and love, which are taught us in it.

div.head: In time of Plague. See the Meditation in the Daylie Devotion. Page 80.
div.p:
WE see, O Lord, how deadlie our sins are, in that thou hast sent us a loathsome messenger of death, who infecting our vitall sp'rits, and corrupting our bloud, doth deprive us of those comforts, dying persons may challenge of their friends. His verie name makes us forsake what otherwise is deare to us. We violate nature it selfe, and neglect all mutuall duties of kindred and friendship, to save our selves from the danger; and so poore sick persons are left unto the care of those, who care not much what may become of them; and in this we doe perhaps commit new sins, instead of amending the old: but thou, O God, forgive us these, and preserve us from those: and as for me, if thou visit'st my friends, Lord, give me a good heart, to afford them my help: and if thou sendst me that disease, Lord, let my friends shew themselves such, in not forsaking me. O God, regard our health and life; or if thou wilt not preserve it, O let our death be precious in thy sight. Remember thy mercies
of old, and set not thy selfe against man; for, what is he, that thou shouldst poure thy wrath on him? Thou hast made us, and so thou knowst what is in us, weaknes in all, wickednes in manie: and wilt thou bruise a broken reed, or shew thy selfe unmercifull, because we are wicked? No, no, my God; this must not be, yea I am sure, this cannot be. Indeed thou must be just, in plaguing injustice; but hast thou not done it, in the person of Christ? Did he not drink the full cup of thy wrath, when he bore all our griefes, and carried our sorrowes? Then for his sake, use us mercifully, and for his stripes heale now our soules from sin, and our bodies from that fearfull disease, which doth afflict manie of us, and affright all the rest. Cleanse our hearts from the contagion of sin, our aire from infection; preserve and cure all our bodies of pestilent feavers, malignant biles and deadlie sores: that we may meet againe safely; and in our just dealings one towards another, and religious cariage towards thee our good preserver: shew, that affliction hath wrought our conversion, and in our words and works give thee praise and glorie, for our deliverance.

div.head: In Dearth.
div.p: WE live, O Lord, in a deare time; for, now things are at a high rate. It is (no doubt) for the sins of the people; yet who suffers most, but those, whose faults are perhaps lest? This burden is chiefly laid on the poore, whose sins are not of so deep hue, as those of our cou • tiers, gallants, wealthie persons. Then O good Lord, regard (I beseech thee) the sighing of thy poore, and the groanes of our husbandmen, and make either our ground fruitfull, or rich men pitifull. Let those receive the increase of their seeds and cattle, or these open their barnes, and set upon their corne a reasonable price; least their cruell covetousnes drag their soules downe to hell.

div.head: In too much Raine.
div.p:
BEcause, O God, we make ill use of thy blessings, thou dost turne them into cursings; and often plague our rebellion with those same things, wherewith thy mercie rewards our obedience. Raine is the thing, the husbandman expects, for the sowing and growing of his seed; for, when it fals in season and measure, then he expects a plentifull harvest: but
if it come too much and unseasonably, then it blasts all his hopes. It doth so now, and makes us justly feare the spoil of corn and fruits: There fore let my God give me leave to beg of his goodnes a cessation of raine, and also such weather, as may both raise our hopes, and cheere our hearts. Grant good Father, what I require, and so blesse the fruits of our ground, that we rejoice all in her store.

div.head: In Drowth.
div.p: BEcause, O God, our hearts are burnt with lust and avarice, and inflam'd with malice and desires of revenge, thou dost justly drie up our ground, and kill her fruits, for want of raine. But now, O Lord, convert us unto thee, and humect our soules with thy grace; then be thou converted to us, and moisten our fields with thy dew, and the former and latter raine. Heavens by their inclination would do good to our earth; but thou dost stop their influence, by reason of our sins. Grant therefore, we doe now repent, and leave our evill wayes: then Lord, heare the Heavens, that they heare our chop'd earth, and let this heare the corne, and yeeld the fruits, we doe expect from her.

div.head: In Flouds.
div.p:
WAter was the first Element, God made use of, to punish all mankind, save Noah and his Familie: for, when their bloud was too hot after faire women, and their hearts were inflam'd with lust, he did (as a wise physician) cure a disease by its contrarie, and put out their fire with water. And though he did after the Floud promise, he would ne're use such meanes to destroy wholly Adams seed; yet Histories teach us, many places have been destroy'd, and thousands of men drown'd by seas and rivers breaking forth; yea, by the raine it selfe, which fals oft in such abundance, that it makes of small brookes great streames, which by their swift violence, and violent swiftnes, sweep away men and beasts, pull downe houses, and root out trees. We are now like to have a Floud, in which many mens goods and lives may be drown'd; Ʋnlesse O Lord, thou wilt rule these roaring waters, and abate their violence. Thou maist do it: for, all things are subject to thee: then doe it (I pray thee) that we may praise thee for mercie. Let sorrow and teares wash our sins, that we die not in them, nor loose our goods or lives for them. Yet if this Fl • ud must doe some harme; either O Lord, let it not be to men or
mine, or give us grace to beare the losse, we shall receive by it, with a patient and constant mind.

div.head: In cold Weather.
div.p: IT is with Gods grace and our soules, what with the Sun and our bodies. These are then the coldest, when the Sun is farthest from them, and those in the worse case, when God with-drawes his grace. But would to God, we were all as sensible of the privation of Gods grace, as of the Suns longest distance. Then we would doe as much, or more to seeke and obtaine it, then we doe to get heat. Grant, O good God, we feele our want, that fearfull to be starv'd with the spirituall cold, we (with thy help) put on speedily the warme clothes of fervent desires of thy grace, and likewise stirre so hard in the exercice of vertue, that thy face shine againe on us, and our soules see the light of thy mild countenance. Then O God, regard our bodies, and either strengthen them against this pinching frost, or qualifie the cold weather. Pittie the poore, who suffer want of garment, fire and meat; and send them cold according to their clothes; and afflictions, according to their strength.

div.head: In Snow.
div.p: 1. THis is a faire Emblem of Hypocrits. The surface of the earth is all cov'red with a pure white, which keeps from sight manie foul things; and this carpet is not lasting, but may suddenly melt. So is the outside of a dissembler, vertue and religion hide his vices and impietie; yet as those are but counterfeit, they can hardly last a season, but vanishing, leave his false heart and corrupt mind naked to the sight of the wise. O let never my Lord permit me to be such: but give me reall honestie and sincere pietie. The God of truth make me true in all things, inwardly before him, that so he may love me; outwardly before men, who thus may praise his Name, and imitate my pietie.

2. This Snow may doe good to the corne, if it last not too long; and so doth moderat affliction make all good soules take a deeper root in vertue. Let mine O God, be such, and work in me the like effect.

3. Snow lying long may doe much harme both to the corne and cattle, kill the first in the earth, starve the last above ground. So long afflictions doe. Then my God, let not mine be such, neither let this Snow continue, least it cause a dearth in this Land.

4. 'Tis unsafe for the eyes and feet, to travell in much snow, unles the way be sound and known: for, the snow may weaken the eyes, even unto blindnes, and make the feet and the whole bodie fall into dangerous holes. So is it perillous to walk in great prosperitie; for honors blind the heart, and dignitie is a slipperie hill, whence many fall into deep pits of povertie and infamie. Happie then is the man, whom God leads in prosperitie, and supports in his dignitie. Let me O Lord, be thus happie. Be thou my guid and stay, in greatnes and basenes, riches and want.

div.head: In a mist.
div.p: 1 SEe this thick Mist, an embleme of my sins, darkning, and making the aire unwholesome. So doe my transgressions: for through them I cannot see God, nor savour the sweetnesse of grace. But thou my Lord, cast thy beames on my soule, to disperse the darknes of my understanding, and purifie my corrupt affections; and let thy materiall Sun resolve these fogs, and cleare the aire, for the comfort and health of men.

2. Who travels in this Mist, is in danger to lose his way, and can hardly see far enough, to discerne and avoid an enemie or other
danger. And such is he, who lives in Ignorance. He hath alwaies a mist before his soule; so that he cannot see the blocks, pits and other perils of his way. Lord, let me not be such, but give me that knowledge, which is necessarie, to make me prudent and Christian.

div.head: In a Cloudie Day.
div.p: 1 THese Clouds rob me of the sight of the Sun; and so doe my sins hinder me from beholding my God: but thou, most gracious Spirit, blot out my transgressions as a thick cloud, and as a cloud my sins; that I may truly say: Sing, O you heavens; for, the Lord hath done it, the Lord hath redeem'd me, and glorifi'd himselfe in me.

2. This Cloud refreshes me, in interposing her thick bodie betwixt the Sun and me: for which I thanke thee, my good God, beseeching thee to use some meanes, to preserve me from the scorching heat of my lust.

3. Is not this morning Cloud like my goodnes? O no, my goodnes doth not last so long. I am good but by fits of short continuation. Then, good God, pitie me, and make me constant in good things; otherwise I may thinke, that I have no goodnes at all.

4 These Clouds make me remember him, whom a Cloud receiv'd once out of the Apostles
sight, and shall bring againe unto ours, Christ Jesus, my life and my hope. To whom then I now lift my heart, desiring him that his appearance be gracious to me, in the great and terrible day. So, Jesus, let it be, and place me then at thy right hand, that so I ever be with thee.

5. Good men are like Clouds full of rain, emptying themselves on the earth, humecting those by their knowledge, and relieving by their riches, whom ignorance and povertie make as heavie and drie, as the earth in a hot Summer. Lord, make me speedily one of those good soules, and till then, let those who are such full clouds emptie themselves on me and on such drie persons.

6. Ill men are like Clouds without raine, there is no good in them, yet there are too manie of them. Lord, scatter them by the breath of thy mouth, that they make no vaine shew in the aire of thy Church, and let me not be one of them.

div.head: In Raine.
div.p: 1 SEe, how finely the Raine falls on the ground and softens it. O that my God would doe so to my heart, mollifie its hardnes. Doe, doe my Lord, as I desire: let thy Spirit make me soft to thy hands, pliable in all things.

2. If Raine, which is most soft, can make
holes in hard stones, we may beleeve as much of the soft Spirit of God. Lord, I beleeve thy mollifying pow'r, and desire to feele it.
3. Raine is a fine washer, and so is the Spirit of God. Sith then I am all foule, I beseech thee, most holie Spirit, to make me cleane throughout.
4. Raine is a refresher, and so is thy grace, O my God. Then let it kindly coole mine inordinate heat.
5. The Raine doth moisten the drie earth, that it bring fruit: the grace of God doth so unto the soule. Let it doe so to mine: make me, O Lord, fruitfull in all vertues.

6. 'Tis not the first, nor the last drop of Raine, which makes holes in the stones, but a continuation of them. A faire lesson of assiduitie in instructions and corrections. Let me, O Lord, learne it, and so be not wearie to instruct and correct the ignorant and vicious amongst us: and cease not thou to doe the like office to me and to all erring soules.

7. As the Raine falls on the just and injust, so must my kindnes doe, if I will be the Child of my heavenlie Father. Holie Father, make me such Child, courteous to all, friendly to my greatest enemies.

8. As Raine falls first on the mountaines; so Gods blessings are first bestow'd on those
high soules, who are neerer heaven, and on such should our first regards be. Let, O Lord, mine be upon such: let me willingly extend my goodnes to the Saints, who are in the earth, and set my delight on the excellent.
In too much Raine. See Page 16.

div.head: In a Dewie Morning.
div.p: THis is an embleme of Gods grace, in its reviving, refreshing and fructifying pow'r. Then let thy grace, most loving God, worke now in me these three desir'd effects; revive my soule from sin, refresh her against lust, wrath and such hot passions, and make her fruitfull in good workes.

div.head: In Frost.
div.p: THe Suns absence causes this Frost, and so God withdrawing or denying his grace to our unworthie soules, they are quickly congeal'd. O let not mine be so hardned for want of thy mollifying heat; but my, good Lord, let alwayes thy face shine on me and on all thy servants.

div.head: In Haile.
div.p: THis is one of the plagues of wilfull Egyptians, and a minister of Gods wrath upon a rebellious Nation. As then we are such, we may well feare it: yet in confidence of the Lords infinit mercie, I am bold to pray thus. O God, save a Citie for ten, yea a Nation for one. If thou canst not find ten righteous amongst us all, seeke one at thy right hand, even thy Son the righ • eous, who makes intercession for us. Heare what he sayes, and grant what he desires for us.

div.head: In an Earth-quake.
div.p:
WHo moves the mightie Gods immovable footstoole? Is he rising to judge the dwellers of the earth? Or is this earth wearie of her heavie burden, poore, sinfull man, and so willing to shake him off? O God, who onelie canst make the pillars of the earth tremble, for the declaration of thy pow'r and anger, grant now, my soule acknowledge and adore the first, with a voluntarie submission to't; and stand in awe of the second, with a prudent caution never to provoke it. Let this Earth-quake shake downe all my evill resolutions, sinfull designes and wicked intentions,
never to rise and stand againe, but let it not overthrow or swallow my person, friends or goods.

div.head: In hot Weather.
div.p:
THe weather is so hot, that our bodies are faint, and our strength melts as wax set neer the fire, or in the sun: yea, it seems, my braines are dry'd up, their moisture being drawne by the heat of the aire; so that I may well feare some dangerous disease. Worldlie prosperitie is much like this season. It takes away spirituall strength, dissolves goodnes and vertue to nothing, and parching all solid judgement, makes us (like light-headed persons) unable to take rest, in the pestered state of wealth, honors, greatnes and preferment. As therefore we need clouds, or shadowes, to keep off the Suns heat; so we must find some means, least prosp • ritie undoe us, and happines make us wr • tched. Thou God, by whose knowledge the clouds drop downe the dew, least too much heat should parch our grasse! vouchsafe to temper this season, that our bodies may continue in health and strength. And if honors and riches be so great, that they would burn our hearts, with lust or ambition; and effeminate our bodies, with voluptuous exces; then give us grace to withdraw our selves for a while, to meditate the vanitie
of state; the instabilitie of riches; and the brevitie of our life, that so our love to them be no greater then their desert to us. And if they be too heavie for our strength, then Lord, do unto us what the husbandman to a tree overloaden with fruit: either prop us, least their weight do bow or breake us; or shake down some of them, that we may easily beare the rest.

div.head: In Thunder.
div.p:
THe great King of heaven and earth is besieging some place; for, I heare his cannons, whose fearfull noise doth appall me, because I have offended him: yet I conceive this thunder is not made for me, because I acknowledge my transgressions, and humble my soule before him, who uses not to make a breach, when the gates are open to him, and no resistance made. Though then I have made some, yea great to the sweet motions of his Spirit; yet now summon'd by this terrible thunder, I yeeld the place to him, as to the right owner. Enter, my Lord and King; enter now peaceably my heart, and pardoning my rebellions, receive me in favor. And to shew me, thou art appeas'd, preserve my life in the present danger; and let my friends and goods be kept safe from all harme. Let this thunder but affright me, and strike my soule, not my bodie.
Let it teach me, thou art mightie, in making such an instrument of sudden destruction; and mercifull, in sparing me thy poore creature: and so let me both feare thy power, and be thankefull to thy mercie, in spending that in thy service, which thou shalt save from this thunder and lightening. Heare me, good Lord, heare me, and for Christs sake, spare now my life.

div.head: In great Winds.
div.p: THis is a fearfull wind, which may blow downe houses and trees, and wrap men in their ruine. I may feare my person and goods: therefore, O God, I put them in thy protection, beseeching thee, to come to me in a still voice, to convert and comfort my soule; and not in a strong wind renting the mountaines, to destroy my bodie, and take away my life. O let me live, to mend my wayes; and prepare my selfe to die well. Regard my life, O Lord, and for his sake, who willingly lost his for me, let me have time to mourne for sin, and make provision of vertue: and in that time, Lord, give my eyes penitent teares, my heart holie desires, and my desires vertuous effects.

div.head: In Burning of Houses.
div.p: HOw busie are we all, to extinguish this fir; but how slow and careles, to avoid that, which cannot be put out? O God I awake our minds, by the apprehension of those eternal flames, which in hell shall torment all those, who regard thee not upon earth: then help us (I pray thee) to quench this fire, least it consume our goods. O let not this comfortable element be the cause of publick sorrow, in making ashes of our houses and goods, and dust of our bodies; but in mercie deliver them, from this present burning; and our soules from that, we doe feare.

div.head: In time of some dangerous Disease.
div.p:
THou dost, O Lord, visit now my neighbours, with a running disease, which sweeps away manie of them. As I am sensible of their affliction; so I heartily intreat thee, thou wilt take pitie upon them, in sending health in their dwellings. And as I am as great sinner as they; so I may justly feare their present punishment; and therefore humbly crave, thou wilt likewise take pitie upon me, in withholding from me what thou hast laid on them. I might have been one of the first, who are
now dead of this sicknes; for, I am not better then they: but thou hast kept me safe till now, to give me time of repentance. O thou mercifull God, grant, I bestow it well, and love thee sincerely, for this speciall favor.

div.head: Against mad Dogs.
div.p: O That men were to God, what dogs are unto men, faithfull and officious; for, it is seldome seen, that those creatures offend men, chiefly their owne masters; unles they be mad, as I heare, there are now some, running abroad, and doing harme to man and beast. I feare, O Lord, to meet such dogs; least their venemous teeth cause me a kind of death, which I may well abhorre; for, what is man, without the use of his reason? O let therefore thine angels wait on me and all my friends, to preserve us from what I feare. Let not, O God, mad beasts punish my madnes, in forsaking thy lawes, and rebelling from thee my Maker and Master: but rather give me grace, to returne now to thee, and flie under thy wings, for protection 'gainst all dangers.

div.head: Against private Enemies.
div.p: THere is one, who hates me, and seeks (as I conceive) to doe me displeasure; and who is he, who cannot hurt, if he set his mind on mischiefe? Therefore, O God, be thou my protector against the harm, he intends to do me; and either convert him, or confound his devices. If I can, I will appease him: but if he will not be reconciled with me, keep me, O Lord, from both his hand and mind. Let him not prevaile against me, and let never my heart be possest with such ill and revengefull disposition, as I feare his is now. My God, let me love them, who hate my soule to death: yet grant, I be both wise, to shun their cunning plots; and strong, to repell at all times their injust violence.
See the Daylie Devotion, Page 159.

div.head: Against Witches.
div.p:
WItches are Satans ministers, to persecute mankind, and (no doubt) can doe much mischiefe, by the power of their master; yet God oversees them and him; so that their charmes faile them, when God will not, they take effect. Then they, who trust in him, have no cause to feare the spels of those mischievous soules. I know, O God, I am a great sinner, and
so deserve great plagues: yet spare me, Lord, for thy Sons sake, or if thou wilt afflict me, doe it thy selfe, O good Father, and let not the Devill take thy rod, nor Witches and Conjurers execute thine office either on me, my friends or goods; but rather, Lord, shut Satan up, that he deceive the nations no more; and reveale his servants, that they receive their due deserts in a consuming fire, or upon the gallowes. Let not our Magistrats suffer those to live, whom thy Law doth condemne to die; nor leave those unpunisht, who resort unto them in losses and diseases, leaving thee their Maker and onelie Benefactor, to crave help of the destructor and his damnable ministers.

div.head: Against Theeves.
div.p:
THere are some men, who refusing the doom God pronounced against Adam, will not eat bread in the sweat of their face, but will have it by craft or violence. Some use fraud in bargaines, false measures and weights in selling; others rob the fields and orchards, and the boldest venture upon purses and houses, and often upon lives. As there is no place without theeves, so this Countrie affords manie. O then, my God, looke (I pray thee) to my goods and person. Make me upright in my dealings, and make all men such towards me. Let none covet my goods, let none lie in wait for my life. And if
anie does it, then Lord, help me to keep mine owne, from all theevish and bloudie hands: and, good God, convert them, who by their frauds, thefts and murthers disturb the Common-wealth.

div.head: Against Detractors.
div.p: THere is a kind of theeves, whose condition shewes them to be of the Devils kindred: for, he's a Detractor. They goe about to blast mens fame, and disgrace their good name. They publish secret sins, make small faults seem grievous, devise false crimes, and set on faire vertue the ouglie name of vice. Though I must not seek vain-glorie; yet I feare calumnie, and cherish my reputation; therefore, O Lord, I beseech thee, to keep me from those slanderous tongues, whose daylie office, is to staine the purest names. Let both my conscience be so good, and my conversation so just; that those may be asham'd, who speake evill of me; and let no man beleeve their tales, before he heares what I can say for me. Let me not likewise give them eare, when they will blemish other men: but grant, I shew them their basenes with such efficacie, that they forsake their wicked course, and keep their tongues to pray for their neighbours, if they be vicious; and if vertuous, praise thee for them.
See Good and Ill Name in the Daylie Index.

div.head: A Thanksgiving after a Deliv'rance from War, Famine, Plague, Thunder, &c.
div.p:
THou hast, O Lord, dealt graciously with me; yet I am not better then those, who in the last _____ have lost goods, friends or lives. I know not what they were in grace, but I confesse before thy majestie, I am so vile and sinfull creature, that I must wholly impute my deliverance from losse or death to thy tender mercie. 'Tis thy goodnes, not my vertue; thy wisdome, not my policie; thy Sons righteousnes, not mine owne uprightnes, which hath preserved me till now. O then let my heart melt in love towards a God so good. I will love thee, O Lord my deliverer: I will praise thee, O Lord my preserver: I will serve thee, O Lord my redeemer. Our dead praise thee not in their graves; but I who live must praise thee Lord, untill I be, as they are now. O love the Lord all you his Saints: for, the Lord preserves the faithfull: and thou, O my soule, blesse the Lord, and forget not his benefits. Blesse him, who forgiveth all thine iniquities, healeth all thy diseases, redeemes thy life from destruction, and crownes thee with loving kindnes. Most gracious God, let
my soule listen well to this invitation, and remembring the danger past, let her reflect her thoughts, and fix her love and hope on thee, who hast dealt graciously with me.

div.head: The fift of November. The Prayer.
div.p:
'TIs no matter, that Hell and Rome, the Devils and Jesuits plot mischiefe against us, as long as God our hope doth keep us safe under his wings: yet it may seem most strange, that those, who beare a name, which might teach them love to mankind, should agree with Satan, to root us from the earth. Indeed Satan fell downe from heaven, having a great wrath 'gainst the Church and the inhabitants of the earth; but the Son of man came downe with greater love, to save mens lives, and not to destroy them. How comes then, meeke Jesus, that those, who brag to be of thy blest companie, and so usurp a name, which thine Apostles never claim'd (for 'twas enough for them, to call themselves thy servants and messengers) seek by all meanes to ruine those, who for the safetie of their bodies, and the salvation of their soules relie wholy on thee? Are those Jesuits indeed, are those saviours of men, who curse
mens soules to hell, and indeavour to blow up their bodies, with a most barbarous and unnaturall invention? What had we done to them, to be adjudg'd to so strange kind of death? And what had we done unto thee, to be so graciously preserv'd? As we consider their inhumanitie, in laying their cruell project; so we must acknowledge thy goodnes, in revealing the same; for, we can not denie, that our Land was then (and is still now) full of manie vices, and guiltie of great sins, which deserved great punishments: yet thou wouldst not then put the rod into the hands of our enemies; for thou dost desire but our correction, and they did seeke our destruction. Then let all thy people praise thee now; and let never our Kings, Nobles and Commons forget thy compassions, in our wonderfull deliv'rance: but let them rejoyce on this day, and from this day to the worlds end, professe sincerely that holie religion, which the Devils would abolish; and love that God, who maintaines his Gospel, and protects his servants.

div.head: A Prayer for the Parliament. Novemb. 3. 1640.
div.p:
THe chiefe men of our Land are now gathered together, as so manie sweet smelling flow'rs, to be made up in a pleasant nosegay.
Therefore I beseech thee, O thou most skilfull Gardiner, who hast dispos'd all the Nations under the Sun, as so manie severall knots of thy curious Garden, to set these flow'rs of our Kingdome in a decent order, and bind them up with the strong thread of charitie. And as sweet Roses have sharp pricks, so that they may as well draw bloud from the veines, as recreate the braines; so let those men even now doe the same; pricke the wicked by sharp statutes, and comfort the godlie by the sweet odor of good lawes. Poure thy wisdome into their minds, and thy goodnes into their hearts; that first they see and love, then enact that, which may conduce to thy glorie and our generall good. O make them wise in their counsels, religious in their intentions, impartiall in their judgements, upright in their sentences, and courageous in their pious resolutions. Let neither love nor hate, hope nor feare make them swerve from that way, they shall once know, may lead from vice unto vertue, from error unto truth, from mens traditions to thy word, from the Devill to thee: but strengthen them, O God, by the serious consideration, that the cause being thine, happie are those, who lose their lives, to maintaine it. Yet, Lord, have speciall care of their persons, on whose safetie our present happines doth mediatly depend. O watch about, above and under them, that no harme befall them. Let thine eyes search where theirs can not, and thy wisdome confound
what theirs can not prevent. Let not the man of bloud have power to shed theirs: but as thou hast heretofore shew'd thy loving care, in the wonderfull deliv'rance of such great assemblie from an infernall plot; so continue, gracious Father, thy blessings upon them and us, in their preservation. Heare me, my God, heare me for thy Sons sake, and even now say Amen to these my desires.

div.head: Another.
The last Day of the Yeare.
div.p:
LOng life is a blessing, which all men doe naturally desire, chiefly when wealth, health, ease and pleasure wait on it. Adde unto these a good conscience, then earth is a little heaven, where good men have a fore-relish of those infinit joyes, they expect after death. Yet as earth is but earth; so we must look for crosse in happines, for losse in wealth, for sorrow in pleasure, for death in life. Happie is he, who enjoyes sweet things with wisdome, eats honie with sobrietie; and when he must tast gall, does it with such grace, that his stomack rise not at it. I am not such, as may challenge this happines; for I have (like a bad scholar) trifled away my time: yea these twelve months, which God hath granted me, to learne wisdome, and studie godlines, have been foolishly spent, in vanitie and sin: which considering now, I thanke thee, gracious Lord, for the addition of this yeare unto thy servants life,
and beg pardon of thee, for my manifold omissions and commissions of what thy Law bids and forbids. Forgive, O God, my sinfull thoughts, idle words, injust workes. Forgive my propension to vice, and my aversion from vertue. Forgive my wilfulnes, in resisting thy good motions; mine oblivion of those duties, I owe both thee and men, and my losse of that time, thou hast granted for repentance. If it be thy pleasure, Lord, grant me more, and withall grace, to make the best of it. O let me consider, there is here nothing more precious; and therefore, Lord, let me not abuse it, least I repent too late, and desire more, when no more shall be giv'n. If thou wilt number the next yeare 'mongst the dayes of my life, & thou be pleas'd, to make it prosperous; then make me also wise, least felicitie deceive me. But if thou hast ordain'd, to make me drinke with thee the bitter cup of affliction; then, Lord, grant me patience, least I faint in adversitie. Whether my life be sweet or soure, O God, make it holie, and my selfe thankfull unto thee, for all thy favors towards me. But if the time drawes neere, in which my soule must leave this earthlie part, this bodie of death: O then, my God, as the stones motion is quicker, when 'tis neerer the ground; so let my soule redouble all her affections towards thee her Maker; and by love and service, make hast to thee, the center of her happines.

div.p:
This Devotion hath 55. Meditations and Pray'rs, and should containe 38 more, to make above the full number of 700. in all the foure parts: but these 38. bein • Meditations, Prayers and Songs upon the Church-Festivall dayes, dare not appeare in these sad times. I
made them for the instruction of the blind multitude, who was verie zealous in the observance of such dayes, yet err'd grosly in their right object and manner. But sith those Feasts are falne through age, I might sooner fall with them, then raise them. I will then suffer them to rest, in a long holie day, and not awake them here.

lg.head: Christian Reader,
lg.l: I will pray God, to give me more for thee.

div.head: Octob. 14. 1646.
div.p: I Have perused these spirituall Meditations and Devotions, and finding them to contain much matter pious and profitable, I doe allow them to be printed and published.
